summary_llm:
The play opens on Christmas Eve in the Helmer household, a comfortable, tasteful room. Nora Helmer, in high spirits, arrives home with numerous Christmas parcels. She instructs the maid to hide the Christmas tree from her children until it's decorated. She then secretly eats macaroons, which her husband, Torvald Helmer, has forbidden her to eat because he believes they will spoil her teeth.

Torvald, who refers to Nora affectionately as his "little lark" and "little squirrel," emerges from his study. He playfully chastises her for being a "spendthrift" while giving her money for Christmas, reminding her that they shouldn't spend recklessly despite his recent promotion to bank manager, which he starts after the New Year and promises a large salary. Nora expresses her joy at their newfound financial security and her hope that their past "hard times" are over.

Shortly after, Nora's old school friend, Christine Linde, arrives. Christine is a widow, having lost her husband three years prior, and has no children or financial means. She explains she has spent years working to support her sick mother and younger brothers, who are now grown. Feeling "unspeakably empty" and in need of purpose, she has come to town seeking work. Nora, delighted for her friend, promises to speak to Torvald about getting Christine a position at the bank, emphasizing Christine's excellent bookkeeping skills.

During their conversation, Nora, prompted by Christine's comment that Nora knows little of life's troubles, reveals a profound secret. She confesses that when Torvald was gravely ill early in their marriage, and doctors said he needed to go south to Italy to recover, it was she, not her dying father, who secretly procured the necessary two hundred and fifty pounds. She did this by borrowing the money, knowing Torvald would never consent to borrowing, and couldn't bear to tell him the true extent of his illness. Since then, she has been secretly working odd jobs like needlework and copying late into the night, and saving money from her household allowance (even denying herself new dresses), to repay the debt in installments, all while keeping it a secret from Torvald to protect his "manly independence" and their "beautiful happy home." She believes he would find it humiliating to owe her.

Their conversation is interrupted by the arrival of Lawyer Krogstad, who comes to see Helmer about bank business. Mrs. Linde recognizes Krogstad and is visibly distressed. Doctor Rank, a close family friend, also arrives and goes to Helmer's study. Rank later tells Nora and Christine that Krogstad has a "diseased moral character" and is with Helmer regarding the bank. Nora, feeling empowered by Torvald's new position, playfully offers macaroons to Rank, defying Torvald's prohibition.

When Helmer emerges, Nora introduces Christine and subtly pushes for Helmer to hire her. Helmer agrees to look for a position for Christine. Helmer, Rank, and Mrs. Linde then depart together.

Nora is left to play with her children, but Krogstad returns, having found the outer door ajar. He confronts Nora, revealing that he knows she has influence with her husband regarding bank appointments and that Mrs. Linde is set to take his job. He demands Nora use her influence to keep his subordinate position, stating he needs to "win back as much respect as I can in the town" for his sons' sake after an "indiscretion" (forgery) in his past. He threatens to expose Nora's secret loan.

Krogstad then reveals the full extent of Nora's legal vulnerability: the bond for the loan contained a surety signed by her father, but Krogstad has proof that her father died three days *before* the date on the signature. Nora admits that she forged her father's signature and filled in the date because he was too ill to sign, and she couldn't burden him with the knowledge of Torvald's critical condition. She argues that the law must permit such actions motivated by love. Krogstad warns her that if he is dismissed, he will expose her. Nora is horrified, especially when Helmer returns and, unaware of the full truth, lectures her about the corrupting influence of lies on a home and children, citing Krogstad's own moral failings as a reason he cannot work with such a man. Nora, terrified by the thought of corrupting her own children, pushes them away.

**Act II**

The next day, Nora is anxious. The Christmas tree stands stripped, reflecting her mood. She speaks with the Nurse, asking if her children would forget her if she left, and questions how the Nurse could have sent her own child away to become Nora's wet nurse, learning that the Nurse's daughter still remembers her.

Mrs. Linde arrives to help Nora mend her Tarantella dress for the fancy-dress ball that evening. Nora confides in Christine about Doctor Rank's terminal spinal consumption, inherited from his immoral father. Christine, observing Rank's daily visits, suspects he might be Nora's secret lender. Nora denies this, explaining that Rank had no money at the time. Nora, however, admits she needs to "make an end of it" with her actual creditor. Christine realizes something more serious has happened.

Helmer returns, and Nora desperately tries again to convince him to keep Krogstad, citing Krogstad's ability to publish "scurrilous" articles about him. Helmer adamantly refuses, citing Krogstad's past "indiscretion" and, more importantly, his personal dislike for Krogstad's overly familiar tone, which would undermine Helmer's authority as the new bank manager. Helmer dispatches the maid with Krogstad's dismissal letter. Nora, in a panic, tries to stop the letter, warning Helmer that he doesn't know what it will cause. Helmer dismisses her fears as "childish nervousness" and proclaims he is man enough to take "everything upon myself."

Doctor Rank then arrives and reveals to Nora that his illness has worsened and he will soon die. He explains that he will send her a card with a black cross when his death is imminent, wishing to spare Helmer from seeing him in his final suffering due to Helmer's "refined nature." Nora, desperate, tries to ask Rank for a "tremendously big favour," but Rank misinterprets her hints as an invitation for him to confess his love for her. Shocked, Nora deflects his romantic advances and abandons her plan to ask him for help.

Krogstad appears, having returned through the back entrance. He confirms his dismissal and reveals he has sent a letter to Helmer detailing Nora's forgery. He states he no longer wants money but instead demands a higher position at the bank, intending to become Helmer's "right hand" and ultimately control the bank. He warns Nora that he will still have power over her, even if she were to run away or do "something worse." As he leaves, he drops the letter into Helmer's locked letter-box.

Nora, in despair, shows Christine the letter. She confesses the forgery and, fearing for her sanity, asks Christine to be her witness that she "alone, did the whole thing." Nora speaks of a "wonderful thing" that is about to happen, but it is "terrible." Christine, realizing the gravity of the situation, offers to intervene with Krogstad, revealing a past romantic connection with him where he "would gladly do anything for my sake." She rushes out to find him.

Nora, knowing Helmer is about to check the letter-box, desperately distracts him by making him help her practice the Tarantella dance for the ball, dancing wildly to keep him from the letters. She extracts a promise from him not to open any letters until after the ball. Helmer attributes her agitated state to "childish nervousness."

**Act III**

Later that night, Mrs. Linde is waiting in the Helmers' living room. Krogstad arrives, having received her note. Christine reveals that her earlier rejection of him was not out of heartlessness but necessity, to support her family. She confesses her enduring love for him and proposes they reunite, offering to be a mother to his children and to find purpose in their shared life. Krogstad is overjoyed and believes he can now clear his name.

Mrs. Linde informs him that his letter to Helmer is already in the letter-box. Krogstad wants to retrieve it, but Christine stops him, insisting that "Helmer must know all about it." She believes the "unhappy secret must be disclosed" for a true understanding to exist between Nora and Helmer, taking responsibility for this decision. Krogstad accepts and leaves, planning to wait for her.

Nora and Helmer return from the ball. Helmer is euphoric, praising Nora's dancing and beauty, but also calls her "terribly self-willed" for wanting to stay longer. Mrs. Linde briefly speaks with them, then departs. Helmer expresses his relief at her departure, calling her a "frightful bore."

Alone with Nora, Helmer makes romantic advances, speaking of his desire for her as his "secretly promised bride." Nora resists him. Doctor Rank then makes a final, brief visit. He requests a cigar from Helmer and reveals, cryptically, that his "scientific investigation" has yielded "absolute certainty" – confirming his impending death. He departs, and Helmer remarks that he has drunk too much.

Helmer goes to empty the letter-box, finding it locked and tampered with. He discovers Rank's cards with black crosses, which Nora confirms are Rank's farewells, signifying his intention to withdraw and die. Helmer is saddened but finds comfort in the thought that he and Nora are now "thrown quite upon each other." He declares he has often wished for some great danger to threaten Nora so he could prove his love by risking his life for her.

Nora, composed, urges him to read his letters. Helmer hesitates but eventually opens Krogstad's letter. His joy quickly turns to horror and rage. He calls Nora a "hypocrite, a liar—worse, worse—a criminal!" He blames her father's "want of principle" for her actions and declares she has destroyed his happiness and ruined his future, placing him "in the power of an unscrupulous man." He states that he must appease Krogstad and hush up the matter for appearance's sake, but their happiness is over. He will keep her in the house for appearances, but he will not allow her to raise their children, deeming her untrustworthy.

Just then, the doorbell rings again, and the maid brings another letter for Nora. Helmer seizes it and reads it. He shouts with joy, proclaiming, "I am saved! Nora, I am saved!" Krogstad has enclosed the bond, expressing regret and repentance due to a "happy change in his life." Helmer tears up the bond and both letters, throwing them into the stove, declaring the whole nightmare over. He assures Nora he has forgiven her, believing she acted "out of love for me," and attributes her actions to "womanly helplessness" and lack of "knowledge," promising to advise and protect her. He says she has become "both wife and child to him."

Nora, in "everyday dress," returns from changing. She tells Helmer she will not sleep and requests a serious conversation, stating that after eight years of marriage, this is their first serious talk, and that they have never truly understood each other. She reveals that she has been treated like a "doll-child" by her father and a "doll-wife" by Helmer, merely performing "tricks" for him. She feels they have committed a "great sin" against her by preventing her from making anything of her life. She confesses she has never been happy, only "merry," and their home has been a "playroom."

She declares Helmer is "not the man to educate me into being a proper wife for you" and that she is "not fit for the task" of raising the children. She announces she must educate herself and needs to stand "quite alone" to understand herself. Therefore, she is leaving him and the children. Helmer forbids it, calling her "blind, foolish," and accusing her of neglecting her "most sacred duties" to her husband and children. Nora counters that she has "other duties just as sacred" – duties to herself. She no longer believes she is primarily a wife and mother, but "a reasonable human being" who must think for herself. She questions the law that prevents a woman from sparing her dying father anxiety or saving her husband's life, finding it "impossible to convince myself that the law is right." She states she is going to "see if I can make out who is right, the world or I."

Helmer thinks she is delirious, but Nora states her mind has never been so clear. She explicitly states she no longer loves him. She explains that her love died when the "wonderful thing" she had hoped for didn't happen: she had expected Helmer, upon discovering the forgery, to "come forward and take everything upon yourself, and say: I am the guilty one." Instead, his only concern was his own reputation. Helmer retorts that "no man would sacrifice his honour for the one he loves." Nora replies that "hundreds of thousands of women have done" so. She concludes that she cannot bind herself to a man who thinks and talks as he does, realizing she has been living with a "strange man" for eight years.

Helmer suggests they could mend their relationship, but Nora insists it's impossible. She states she cannot spend the night in "a strange man's room." She will not see the children, believing they are better off without her. She takes off her wedding ring and demands her own back, declaring herself free from all obligations, just as she frees him from his. She states she will go to her old home and will not accept anything from him, nor will he write to her. Helmer asks if she can never be more than a stranger to her. Nora replies that "the most wonderful thing of all would have to happen" for them to have a "real wedlock," meaning they both would have to change profoundly. She says "Goodbye" and leaves through the hall.

Helmer sinks onto a chair, calling out "Nora! Nora!" He then questions, "The most wonderful thing of all—?" A door shutting is heard from below.

summary_llm:
Alice is sitting on a riverbank with her sister, feeling bored and sleepy. Her sister is reading a book with no pictures or conversations, which Alice finds useless. While contemplating making a daisy-chain, she suddenly sees a White Rabbit with pink eyes run by, exclaiming, “Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!” To Alice’s surprise, the Rabbit takes a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket, looks at it, and then hurries away. Driven by curiosity, Alice follows it down a large rabbit-hole without thinking about how she will get out.

The rabbit-hole plunges steeply downwards like a deep well. As Alice falls, she notices the sides are lined with cupboards and bookshelves. She grabs an empty jar labeled “ORANGE MARMALADE” and places it in a cupboard. During her prolonged fall, she speculates about her depth and whether she will fall through the earth. She also thinks about her cat, Dinah, and wonders if cats eat bats. Just as she begins to doze off, she lands safely on a heap of sticks and dry leaves.

Alice finds herself in a long passage, seeing the White Rabbit hurry around a corner, lamenting how late it is. She follows but loses sight of him in a long, low hall lit by lamps. The hall is lined with locked doors. On a little three-legged glass table, she finds a tiny golden key. This key is too small for the main doors, but she discovers a small, fifteen-inch-high door hidden behind a low curtain, which the key fits. Through this door, she sees a beautiful garden but cannot fit through it.

Returning to the table, Alice finds a bottle labeled “DRINK ME.” After ensuring it’s not poisoned, she tastes its pleasant, mixed flavor and drinks it all. She then shrinks to ten inches high, the perfect size for the small door. However, she realizes she left the golden key on the now out-of-reach table. After trying and failing to climb the table leg, she sits down and cries, scolding herself for her tears.

Her eye falls on a small cake under the table, marked “EAT ME.” She decides to eat it, hoping it will change her size appropriately. After eating a bit, she remains the same size, which she finds dull. She then finishes the entire cake.

Immediately, Alice begins to grow rapidly, becoming more than nine feet tall and hitting her head on the hall’s roof. Her feet are so far away they are almost out of sight. She tries to enter the garden, but is now too large. She sits down and cries so many tears that a pool, four inches deep, forms around her, filling half the hall.

The White Rabbit returns, splendidly dressed, carrying white kid gloves and a large fan, muttering about the Duchess. Alice timidly asks for help, startling the Rabbit, who drops his gloves and fan and flees. Alice picks up the fan and gloves and uses the fan, as the hall is hot. She wonders who she is, testing her knowledge, but her recitations and facts come out wrong (e.g., "How doth the little crocodile" instead of "busy bee"). She concludes she must be Mabel.

As she talks, she notices she put on one of the Rabbit’s gloves and realizes she is shrinking again. She discovers the fan is causing her to shrink and drops it just in time, preventing her from vanishing entirely. She is now about two feet high, but the little door is shut, and the key is back on the table, still out of reach. Her foot slips, and she splashes into the pool of tears she had wept, now up to her chin in saltwater.

Alice swims about and soon sees a Mouse who has also fallen in. She attempts to speak to it, first in English, then in French ("Où est ma chatte?"), which frightens the Mouse. She apologizes, realizing mice dislike cats, but then accidentally mentions her cat Dinah’s prowess at catching mice, further offending the Mouse, who swims away. Alice calls it back, promising not to mention cats or dogs. The Mouse returns, agreeing to tell its history on shore. The pool has become crowded with various birds and animals (a Duck, Dodo, Lory, Eaglet) who have also fallen in. Alice leads them all to the bank.

On the bank, the wet creatures discuss how to get dry. The Mouse, taking charge, proposes telling them “the driest thing” it knows: a history lesson about William the Conqueror. The others are unimpressed, and Alice remains wet. The Dodo then suggests a "Caucus-race." The Dodo marks a circular course, and everyone runs when they like and stops when they like. After about half an hour, they are all dry, and the Dodo declares that "Everybody has won, and all must have prizes." Alice is designated to give the prizes and distributes comfits from her pocket to everyone. For her own prize, she offers a thimble, which the Dodo solemnly presents back to her.

Alice asks the Mouse to tell its history, reminding it of its promise to explain why it hates "C and D" (cats and dogs). The Mouse begins a sad "tale" (story), which Alice misinterprets as referring to its "tail" (appendage). The story is a poem about a legal proceeding where Fury acts as judge and jury to condemn a mouse. Alice’s confusion about the Mouse’s tail and its story makes the Mouse angry, and it walks off, feeling insulted by her misunderstanding. Alice and the other creatures try to coax it back, but it refuses. Alice then mentions her cat Dinah, describing her as excellent at catching mice and eating birds. This causes alarm among the birds, who quickly disperse under various pretexts, leaving Alice alone and crying again.

The White Rabbit soon reappears, searching anxiously for his dropped fan and gloves, muttering about the Duchess. He mistakes Alice for his housemaid, "Mary Ann," and orders her to fetch them from his house. Alice complies, entering a neat little house marked "W. RABBIT." Upstairs, she finds a fan and gloves, but also a bottle. Drinking from it, she rapidly grows to an enormous size, filling the room, with one arm out the window and one foot up the chimney.

The Rabbit returns, calls for "Mary Ann," and tries to open the door, but Alice’s elbow blocks it. He decides to enter through the window. Alice, much larger than the Rabbit, makes a snatch with her hand outside the window, hearing a shriek and breaking glass. The Rabbit calls for "Pat," who is "digging for apples." Pat identifies Alice's arm in the window. The Rabbit demands it be removed. After another snatch from Alice, more shrieks and broken glass are heard. They then try to remove Alice by putting a ladder up to the chimney, and send a small animal named Bill the Lizard down. Alice kicks her foot, sending Bill rocketing out of the chimney. The Rabbit suggests burning the house down, but Alice threatens to set her cat Dinah on them, causing silence. They then throw pebbles at the window, which turn into small cakes. Alice eats one, shrinks, and runs out of the house, escaping the crowd of animals and birds, including a dazed Bill the Lizard.

Alice finds herself in a thick wood, needing to grow back to her proper size and find the garden. She encounters an enormous puppy, which she distracts with a stick, then escapes its playful but terrifying attention. She realizes she needs to eat or drink something to grow. She finds a large mushroom and, looking over its top, sees a large blue Caterpillar smoking a hookah.

The Caterpillar asks Alice, "Who are _you_?" Alice replies she hardly knows, having changed so many times. The Caterpillar is unimpressed, leading to an argument about her identity. Alice gets irritated and suggests the Caterpillar introduce itself first. The Caterpillar calls her back to advise her to "Keep your temper," then reveals that eating one side of the mushroom will make her grow taller, and the other side will make her grow shorter. The Caterpillar then crawls away. Alice, after some difficulty determining the "sides" of the round mushroom, breaks off a piece with each hand. She nibbles one bit and shrinks so rapidly her chin hits her foot. She quickly eats from the other bit, and her neck extends immensely, rising above the trees like a serpent. A Pigeon attacks her, mistaking her for a serpent trying to steal its eggs. Alice insists she is a "little girl." The Pigeon scoffs, saying her long neck proves otherwise. After arguing, Alice finally manages to nibble the mushroom pieces carefully until she returns to her "usual height." She then shrinks herself to nine inches high after discovering a small house in a clearing, wanting to be small enough not to frighten its inhabitants.

Alice approaches the house, where a Fish-Footman delivers a croquet invitation from the Queen to a Frog-Footman for the Duchess. Alice tries to enter, but the Frog-Footman gives her nonsensical reasons why knocking is useless. Eventually, Alice simply opens the door and enters a smoky kitchen. Inside, the Duchess is nursing a sneezing, howling baby, and a Cook is stirring a peppery cauldron of soup, throwing kitchenware at the Duchess and baby. A grinning Cheshire Cat sits on the hearth. Alice asks why the cat grins, and the Duchess says it's a Cheshire cat. The Duchess frequently offers obscure morals and sings a violent lullaby to the baby while tossing it. The Duchess then flings the baby at Alice, telling her to nurse it, and rushes off to play croquet. Alice struggles to hold the oddly-shaped baby, which she realizes is turning into a pig. She sets it down, and it trots off into the wood.

Alice then sees the Cheshire Cat reappear in a tree. She asks it which way to go. The Cat says it depends on where she wants to get to. When Alice says she doesn't much care, the Cat replies that then it doesn't matter which way she goes, as long as she walks long enough. The Cat tells her that a Hatter lives one way and a March Hare the other, and both are mad. Alice expresses reluctance to go among mad people, but the Cat insists everyone there is mad, including Alice. The Cat vanishes and reappears several times, eventually leaving behind only its grin, which Alice finds most curious. Alice decides to visit the March Hare’s house, cautiously shrinking herself before approaching.

At the March Hare’s house, Alice finds the March Hare and the Hatter having a never-ending tea-party with a sleeping Dormouse used as a cushion. They claim there's "no room," but Alice sits down. They offer her wine (which doesn’t exist) and the Hatter makes a personal remark about her hair. The Hatter asks a riddle: "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?" but neither he nor the March Hare knows the answer. They argue about semantics and then reveal they are stuck at tea-time (always six o’clock) because the Hatter offended Time during a concert, and now Time won't cooperate with him. They keep moving around the table as tea things get used up. The Dormouse, after being pinched awake, tells a sleepy story about three sisters who lived in a treacle-well and drew treacle. Alice, frustrated by their rudeness and illogic, leaves the tea-party, declaring it the "stupidest."

She then finds a door in a tree, which leads back to the long hall. Remembering her earlier attempts, Alice retrieves the golden key and, by carefully eating from her mushroom piece, adjusts her size to about a foot high, finally entering the beautiful garden.

In the garden, Alice sees three gardeners (playing cards) painting white roses red, fearing the Queen of Hearts will behead them if she discovers they planted the wrong color. The Queen’s grand procession arrives: soldiers, courtiers, royal children, and guests (including the White Rabbit and the Knave of Hearts), followed by the King and Queen of Hearts. Alice remains standing, puzzling the Queen. The Queen, upon learning Alice does not know who the lying-down gardeners are, screams "Off with her head!" Alice defiantly says "Nonsense!" and the Queen is momentarily silenced. The King intervenes, pointing out Alice is a child. The Queen then discovers the gardeners’ deception and orders their execution, but Alice hides them in a flower-pot.

The Queen asks Alice to play croquet. The game is chaotic, played with live hedgehogs as balls, live flamingoes as mallets, and soldiers bent double as arches, all constantly moving. The Queen frequently shouts "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" and orders the execution of players. Alice feels uneasy, fearing her own beheading. She spots the grinning Cheshire Cat, whose head appears in the air. She complains to the Cat about the game. When the King orders the Cat removed, the Queen orders, "Off with his head!" but the executioner cannot decide how to decapitate a head without a body. Alice suggests asking the Duchess. The Queen sends for the Duchess, but the Cat’s head fades away entirely before the Duchess arrives.

The Duchess returns, now in a pleasant temper, and links arms with Alice, offering more convoluted morals. The Queen reappears, angrily ordering the Duchess away, threatening her head. The Duchess vanishes instantly. The Queen then sends Alice with the Gryphon to hear the Mock Turtle’s story. The Gryphon reveals that the Queen never actually executes anyone. They find the Mock Turtle sitting sadly, and he begins his story by stating he was once a "real Turtle." He recounts his school days in the sea, learning subjects like "Reeling and Writhing" and "Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision," and how lessons "lessen" each day.

The Mock Turtle and the Gryphon then describe the "Lobster Quadrille," a whimsical dance involving lobsters, swimming, and somersaults. The Mock Turtle sings a song about a whiting and a snail. They explain that whiting have their tails in their mouths because they were thrown out to sea for dancing with lobsters. They also explain that "whiting" are used to shine shoes under the sea. The Gryphon then demands Alice tell her adventures. Alice recounts her experiences from that morning, including her changing sizes and her failed recitation of "Father William." When Alice attempts to recite another poem, it too comes out as nonsensical verse about a "Lobster" and an "Owl and Panther sharing a pie." The Mock Turtle demands explanations, but the Gryphon dismisses it. As the Mock Turtle begins to sing a song called "Turtle Soup," a cry of "The trial’s beginning!" is heard in the distance. The Gryphon quickly pulls Alice away to the trial.

They arrive to find the King and Queen of Hearts on their throne, presiding over a trial for the Knave of Hearts, who is accused of stealing the Queen's tarts. The White Rabbit acts as the Herald. Alice notes the King is the judge and that the jurors (various creatures) are busy writing their names to remember them. Alice removes Bill the Lizard’s squeaky pencil. The White Rabbit reads the accusation: a poem about the Knave stealing the Queen's tarts.

The King calls the first witness, the Hatter, who arrives with a teacup and bread-and-butter, claiming he hadn't finished tea. The Hatter gives rambling, contradictory evidence about tea, time, and the March Hare. Alice starts growing larger again, causing the Dormouse to complain and move. The King and Queen threaten the Hatter with execution, eventually dismissing him. The Queen orders his head removed outside, but he escapes.

The next witness is the Duchess’s Cook, who testifies that tarts are "Pepper, mostly." The Dormouse interjects, "Treacle." The Queen orders the Dormouse beheaded, causing commotion, and the Cook disappears. The White Rabbit then calls "Alice!" as the next witness.

Alice, having grown very large again, jumps up and knocks over the jury-box, spilling all the jurymen. She hastily picks them up, realizing she put Bill the Lizard in head-downwards. The King asks Alice what she knows about the business. Alice replies, "Nothing." The King declares this "very important," but the White Rabbit quickly corrects him to "unimportant." The King then reads "Rule Forty-two: _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_," clearly aimed at Alice. Alice refuses to leave, stating the rule was just invented. The King, flustered, tells the jury to consider their verdict.

The White Rabbit then produces a newly discovered paper, which turns out to be a set of nonsensical verses, supposedly written by the prisoner, but not in his hand and unsigned. The King insists not signing it proves guilt. The Queen demands, "Sentence first—verdict afterwards!" Alice cries out, "Stuff and nonsense! The idea of having the sentence first!" The Queen, furious, screams, "Off with her head!"

At this, Alice, now at her full size, defiantly declares, "Who cares for you? You're nothing but a pack of cards!" The entire pack of cards flies up and descends upon her. Alice screams and tries to beat them off, only to find herself lying on the riverbank with her head in her sister's lap.

Her sister wakes her, asking about her long sleep. Alice recounts her "curious dream" to her sister. After Alice runs off for tea, her sister remains on the bank, contemplating Alice's dream. She imagines the fantastical characters and events, picturing how they would transform into mundane reality (rustling grass instead of the White Rabbit, tinkling sheep-bells instead of teacups, farmyard noises instead of queer creatures). Finally, she imagines Alice as a grown woman, retaining her childlike heart and sharing tales of Wonderland with future generations of children.

summary_llm:
This detailed plot summary is derived exclusively from the provided text of "Anna Karenina", avoiding any external or prior knowledge of the book.

**Part One**

The story begins with the **Oblonsky family** in disarray. The wife, **Darya Alexandrovna (Dolly)**, has discovered her husband, **Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky (Stiva)**, is having an affair with their French governess. Dolly declares she cannot live with him, causing three days of chaos in their household, with servants giving notice and children running wild.

Stepan Arkadyevitch wakes in his study, recalling a pleasant dream before being struck by the painful reality of his quarrel with Dolly. He regrets not hiding his infidelity better and finds Dolly's lack of forgiveness difficult, though he acknowledges his fault. Dolly, whom he considers limited, had confronted him with an incriminating letter, and his "idiotic smile" at that moment had intensified her fury.

Stepan, a handsome and susceptible man, cannot genuinely repent not loving his wife. He had vaguely assumed she knew and would overlook his infidelity. He decides to distract himself with daily life. His valet, **Matvey**, informs him that his sister, **Anna Arkadyevna**, is arriving from Petersburg, a visit Matvey hopes will lead to reconciliation. Dolly, through Matvey, expresses her intention to leave. **Matrona Philimonovna**, the nurse, urges Stepan to apologize for the children's sake, but Dolly refuses to see him.

Stepan gets dressed, feeling clean and physically at ease despite his unhappiness. He reviews office papers and reads a liberal newspaper, whose views align with his own, particularly on marriage. He is troubled by a financial matter involving the sale of his wife's forest, which is now complicated by their estrangement. His children, **Grisha** and **Tanya**, greet him. He notes Tanya's subtle awareness of his and Dolly's quarrel. He gives them sweets. Matvey announces a petitioner, a widow, whom Stepan kindly advises. After a moment of internal debate about the futility of reconciliation, he resolves to face Dolly.

Dolly is in her bedroom, attempting to pack the children's things to move to her mother's. She feels unable to leave because of her five children and her lingering love for Stepan. She perceives Stepan's health and radiance as offensive in contrast to her own suffering. Stepan timidly informs her of Anna's arrival. Dolly screams at him to leave, expressing her agony over his affair with the governess and calling him "loathsome" and a "stranger." A child's cry briefly softens her. When Stepan attempts to touch her, she threatens to expose him to the servants and children. She then leaves, slamming the door. Stepan is chagrined by her "vulgar" outburst. Dolly returns to her room, still wondering about Stepan's affair and feeling that reconciliation is impossible, but immerses herself in domestic duties to escape her grief.

Stepan attends a board meeting at his office, where he is respected for his tact and liberalism. His old friend, **Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin**, arrives from the country. Levin, shy and earnest, has come to Moscow with the intention of proposing to **Princess Kitty Shtcherbatskaya**, Dolly's younger sister. Levin is a country gentleman, occupied with farming, and feels unworthy of Kitty's perfection, especially compared to his perceived rival, **Count Alexey Kirillovitch Vronsky**. After previously leaving Moscow in despair, Levin has returned, determined to marry Kitty if accepted.

Levin visits his elder half-brother, **Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev**, a philosopher, who is engaged in a deep discussion about psychological and physiological phenomena. Levin's simple questions are dismissed. Sergey Ivanovitch then reveals their brother, **Nikolay Levin**, a ruined and dissolute man, has reappeared in Moscow. Levin is horrified and wants to see him. Sergey Ivanovitch advises against it, showing Levin a note from Nikolay asking to be left alone. Levin decides to visit Nikolay later.

Levin goes to the Zoological Gardens, where Kitty is skating. He is overcome with rapture and terror at seeing her. Kitty, radiant and graceful, invites him to skate with her. His compliments make her withdraw slightly. Stepan Arkadyevitch arrives and takes Levin to dinner. At the restaurant, Stepan reveals that Dolly believes Kitty is destined to marry Levin, causing Levin immense joy. However, Stepan also mentions Vronsky, a wealthy and charming officer, as a rival. Levin feels his deep love for Kitty is profaned by this talk of rivalry. Stepan, revealing his own marital difficulties, asks Levin for advice on balancing love for his wife with attraction to another woman. Levin struggles with this, rejecting any compromise with what he considers "fallen women." Stepan dismisses Levin's "all of a piece" nature, arguing that life requires "light and shadow." Levin leaves to dress for the Shtcherbatskys' house, where he plans to propose.

Kitty, anticipating the evening, feels a mix of pleasure and awkwardness regarding Levin, and a vivid hope for Vronsky. She is radiant in her ball gown. Levin arrives early at the Shtcherbatskys', finding Kitty alone. He quickly proposes marriage. Kitty, after a moment of ecstasy, remembers Vronsky and hastily refuses, saying, "That cannot be... forgive me." Levin is devastated.

The princess enters, relieved by Kitty's refusal. Countess Nordston, who dislikes Levin, arrives and teases him. Vronsky then appears, and Kitty's eyes brighten, confirming to Levin that she loves Vronsky. Vronsky greets Kitty with tender admiration, ignoring Levin. The conversation shifts to spiritualism. Levin dismisses it as superstition. The old prince, Kitty's father, arrives and greets Levin warmly but Vronsky coldly, expressing his preference for Levin. Vronsky, unperturbed, asks Kitty about an upcoming ball. Levin leaves, heartbroken, his last impression Kitty's happy face with Vronsky.

Kitty, though remorseful for Levin, is glad she received an offer and believes she acted rightly. Her happiness is marred by the image of Levin's suffering. The prince scolds his wife for pushing Kitty towards Vronsky, whom he considers a "peacock," and praises Levin. The princess, in turn, blames Vronsky for leading Kitty on. Dolly tries to mediate, revealing Levin's past proposal, which her mother denies knowing. Kitty confesses her inner turmoil to Dolly, feeling everything is "hateful, loathsome, coarse." She criticizes her sister for staying with an unfaithful husband, then breaks down, confessing her misery stems from refusing Levin and being deceived by Vronsky. Kitty goes to stay with Dolly to recover from her illness, which is identified as scarlet fever, and the family later goes abroad for her health.

Vronsky, unaware of the pain he has caused Kitty, feels a strong spiritual bond with her, believing she loves him. He enjoys their secret communication and his newfound purity. He returns to his hotel, feeling content.

**Part Two**

Kitty, still unwell, goes abroad with her mother. A celebrated doctor recommends Soden waters. The prince, who understands Kitty's illness is emotional, is annoyed by the medical farce and expresses his preference for Levin over Vronsky. Dolly visits, sharing her own marital struggles (Stepan's continued absence and suspected infidelities) and worries about her children's health. Kitty, in a moment of distress, lashes out at Dolly for forgiving Stepan's infidelity, then breaks down, revealing her "hateful" feelings about herself and her past actions. Kitty eventually goes to stay with Dolly and helps nurse her children through scarlet fever, but her health does not improve.

Meanwhile, Levin, back in Moscow, visits his sick brother Nikolay, who is emaciated and living in squalor with his mistress, Marya Nikolaevna. Nikolay is irritable and rejects help, accusing Levin and Sergey Ivanovitch of aristocratic views. He expresses his fear of death. Levin is deeply disturbed by Nikolay's condition and the philosophical discussions they have. Levin tries to implement new farming methods, aiming to create a partnership with his peasants. He struggles against their ingrained habits but finds joy and connection in the physical labor of mowing with them. During this time, he receives a letter from Marya Nikolaevna, informing him that Nikolay is at death's door.

Levin is deeply affected by the peasant Fyodor's simple faith, which provides a clear meaning for life that he has been searching for in philosophy. He realizes he has been "living rightly, but thinking wrongly." He finds that the truths he needs are "given" by faith, not reason. This profound spiritual revelation gives him peace, but he decides to keep it a "secret for me alone." He hears Kitty is ill and coming to Moscow, and all his new thoughts are overshadowed by his love for her.

He travels to Sviazhsky's estate, where he is once again drawn into intellectual debates about farming and social issues. Levin is frustrated by Sviazhsky's detached intellectualism and the self-serving arguments of other landowners. He further refines his ideas about labor, believing that a successful system must align with the "Russian peasant's" instincts. He resolves to revolutionize his own farming system.

Anna and Vronsky are living in Petersburg. Anna's social life is divided between her husband's official circle, the religious-philanthropic circle of Countess Lidia Ivanovna, and the fashionable world of Princess Betsy Tverskaya. After her visit to Moscow, Anna avoids her serious friends and embraces the fashionable world, where she frequently meets Vronsky. She realizes her delight in his pursuit, despite her initial protests. At the opera, Vronsky confesses his frustration with their undefined relationship. Anna reveals she is pregnant, which sends Vronsky into a panic about their situation. He suggests she leave her husband. Anna refuses to leave her son, fearing eternal separation, but eventually agrees to consider a divorce and to be with him intimately.

At the races, Vronsky makes a mistake during a steeplechase and breaks his mare's back, causing him immense despair. Alexey Alexandrovitch, Anna's husband, observes her desperate reaction to Vronsky's fall, confirming his suspicions. In the carriage home, Anna confesses her love for Vronsky and her hatred for Alexey Alexandrovitch. Alexey Alexandrovitch is shocked and devastated, but quickly decides to maintain an "external status quo" to avoid scandal, while secretly resolving to punish Anna. He writes her a formal letter, demanding she return to Petersburg and abide by his conditions. Anna, seeing the letter, feels trapped and miserable, contemplating suicide. She decides to go to Princess Betsy's, where she secretly sends a note to Vronsky to meet her.

Vronsky, after his own "day of reckoning" where he settled his debts and burned Anna's letters, is confronted by his brother and Serpuhovskoy, who urge him to pursue his military career and avoid entanglement with Anna. Vronsky, however, is consumed by his passion for Anna. He meets Anna in the Vrede garden, where she tells him she confessed everything to her husband. Vronsky is initially proud, but then realizes his own ambiguous position. He urges her to leave her husband, but she cannot, due to her son. She confesses her dream of dying in childbirth. He, in a display of devotion, rejects a promising military appointment in Tashkend and retires from the army. They plan to go abroad, without divorce, as Anna cannot bear to leave Seryozha.

**Part Three**

Levin and Kitty are engaged. Levin, in a state of delirious happiness, leaves all wedding arrangements to others. He is reminded that he needs a confession certificate to marry, which, as an unbeliever, causes him distress and a sense of hypocrisy. During confession, he expresses his doubts about God, but the priest, hearing of his upcoming marriage, stresses the importance of faith for raising children. Levin feels relief but also a vague sense that he needs to clarify his religious doubts.

On their wedding day, Levin is late due to a lost shirt. He is overcome with love for Kitty, who appears radiant and truthful. The ceremony is filled with deep meaning for Levin, especially the idea of two souls being "joined together in love." Kitty, overwhelmed with joy, barely hears the words, but feels a profound shift in her life, leaving her old self behind for a new future. After the ceremony, Levin confesses his past lack of chastity and faith to Kitty. She forgives him, though his lack of purity brings her to tears. He feels unworthy but immensely happy. They leave for the country.

**Part Four**

Alexey Alexandrovitch and Anna live as strangers in the same house. Alexey Alexandrovitch, trying to uphold appearances, continues his official duties, while Anna meets Vronsky outside the home. Alexey Alexandrovitch, though deeply hurt, finds a false peace through Countess Lidia Ivanovna's influence, who encourages him in a new, mystical Christian faith. He convinces himself that death for unbelievers does not apply to him, and that his forgiveness of Anna has granted him salvation. He believes his "saintly" behavior allows him to look down on others. Lidia Ivanovna, obsessed with Karenin, works to keep Anna away from Seryozha. She sends Anna a cruel letter, denying her access to her son.

Anna, desperate to see Seryozha, decides to visit him on his birthday, bribing servants to get in. She finds Seryozha in bed. He recognizes her, and they share a tearful, loving reunion. Seryozha, though initially shy, expresses his love and confirms he never believed she was dead. Anna tells him to love his father, saying she has "done him wrong." Alexey Alexandrovitch enters, and Anna, filled with repulsion, leaves quickly, still carrying the toys she bought for Seryozha. Back at the hotel, Anna feels unable to love her baby daughter, Annie, as she does Seryozha. She fears Vronsky has grown cold to her. She sends for him. They argue; she accuses him of not loving her, and again mentions her nightmare of dying in childbirth.

Vronsky, back in Petersburg, has his military career aspirations rekindled by his friend Serpuhovskoy's success. He decides he must not compromise his future by marrying Anna. However, upon hearing that Alexey Alexandrovitch has agreed to a divorce, he rushes to Anna. They reconcile passionately. Anna, still concerned about Seryozha, does not want a divorce if it means losing her son. Vronsky, in a spontaneous act of love, declines a prestigious appointment in Tashkend and resigns from the army. They go abroad together, without divorce.

**Part Five**

Levin and Kitty's early married life is marked by unexpected joys and frequent quarrels. Levin finds his previous idealized dreams of marriage replaced by mundane domestic realities, which he struggles with but eventually learns to appreciate as Kitty's "nest-building" instincts. He realizes his philosophical arguments are less important than the simple truths of family life. He learns to accept her as she is, and not be offended by her.

News arrives that Nikolay Levin is dying. Kitty insists on accompanying Levin to the provincial town. Levin is uneasy about Kitty meeting Nikolay's mistress, Marya Nikolaevna, but Kitty's determination to help overrides his objections. At the hotel, they find Nikolay terribly ill. Kitty, with her practical and compassionate nature, takes charge of his care, cleaning the room and arranging for a new doctor. Levin is distressed by the physical reality of his brother's suffering but finds solace in Kitty's unwavering care. Nikolay, in moments of lucidity, expresses gratitude to Kitty.

Nikolay receives the sacrament and extreme unction. Levin, an unbeliever, is agonized by his brother's desperate, temporary faith. Nikolay briefly improves, then rapidly declines. He dies, saying "I'm setting off... It’s the end." Levin is deeply affected by his brother's death, feeling the "insoluble enigma" of it, but Kitty's presence and her impending motherhood offer him strength and a renewed sense of life and love. The doctor confirms Kitty is pregnant.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, left alone with Seryozha, struggles with his new, humiliating position. He clings to Countess Lidia Ivanovna's fanatical religious advice, which offers him a false sense of salvation and allows him to avoid confronting his emotions. He refuses Anna's request to see Seryozha.

**Part Six**

Dolly and her children spend the summer at Levin's estate. Stepan Arkadyevitch visits occasionally. The Levins also host the old princess and Varenka. Levin feels his "Levin world" is being overtaken by the "Shtcherbatsky element." Kitty observes Sergey Ivanovitch's growing affection for Varenka and wishes for their marriage. Stepan Arkadyevitch arrives with Vassenka Veslovsky, a charming but flirtatious young man. Levin becomes intensely jealous of Veslovsky's attentions to Kitty and, in a fit of rage, expels Veslovsky from his house, causing a family uproar. He later feels guilty but would do it again to protect Kitty.

Dolly visits Anna and Vronsky at their estate, Vozdvizhenskoe. She is struck by Anna's "temporary beauty... only found in women during the moments of love," and Vronsky's dedication to building a hospital and improving his estate. Vronsky confesses to Dolly his anguish over their illegitimate child, who is legally Karenin's, and his desire for a divorce. He begs Dolly to persuade Anna to write to Alexey Alexandrovitch. Anna, however, reveals to Dolly that she had an operation to prevent more children, shocking Dolly. Anna feels trapped and miserable, unable to accept Alexey Alexandrovitch's refusal of divorce. She expresses her deep love for Seryozha and Vronsky, but feels they cannot coexist. Dolly, disheartened, decides to return home.

**Part Seven**

Levin and Kitty are in Moscow for her confinement. Levin feels restless and out of place in the city, but Kitty is calm and happy in her pregnancy. Kitty meets Vronsky by chance and is surprised by her composure. Levin, after hearing of the encounter, is initially jealous but then reassured by Kitty's honesty. Levin attends various social and intellectual events, but finds most discussions superficial. He makes friends with Professor Katavasov and meets Metrov, a scientific writer, with whom he has a philosophical discussion.

At the club, Levin makes peace with Vronsky, but refuses to visit Anna. He finds his previous views on life and society shifting, and struggles with his own perceived inconsistencies.

Anna and Vronsky are living in Moscow, awaiting the divorce. Anna, consumed by jealousy, feels Vronsky's love is waning. She accuses him of being cold and not understanding her suffering. She again expresses her premonition of dying in childbirth. They argue constantly.

Kitty begins labor. Levin is terrified and overwhelmed, but Kitty is courageous and calm. He is filled with a new, spiritual faith, praying to God for help. After a long and agonizing labor, Kitty gives birth to a son. Levin is initially filled with disgust and compassion for the tiny, red creature, but then feels a "strange thrill of senseless joy and even pride."

**Part Eight**

Sergey Ivanovitch's book is a failure. He finds a new purpose in the **Slavonic question** (the Servian War), seeing it as an expression of the Russian people's will. He and Katavasov travel to the country, observing volunteers for the war. At a provincial station, Sergey Ivanovitch meets Countess Vronskaya, who describes Anna's death (throwing herself under a train) and Vronsky's subsequent despair. She views Anna as a "bad woman" whose "very death was the death of a vile woman." Vronsky, now a volunteer, is on the platform, looking "aged and worn by suffering." He tells Sergey Ivanovitch that life is "worth nothing" to him, finding meaning only in facing death for the cause. He is haunted by the memory of Anna's body at the station.

Levin, back at his estate, continues to struggle with his farming system and his philosophical doubts. He finds inspiration in the simple faith of a peasant, Fyodor, who "lives for his soul" and "does not forget God." This revelation brings Levin a profound sense of peace and understanding, realizing that goodness is "outside the chain of cause and effect" and "given" by faith. He recognizes that his previous intellectual pursuits were a "deceitfulness of intellect" and that he has been living rightly but thinking wrongly. He resolves to live by the spiritual truths he has instinctively known, though he will still struggle with daily imperfections.

At home, Levin and Kitty continue to navigate their married life, learning to communicate and reconcile their differences. Their love deepens, and Levin finds joy and meaning in his family and work, albeit with constant self-reflection and struggle. He no longer feels meaningless, but sees life having a "positive meaning of goodness." The novel concludes with Levin finding a new, personal faith in God, not through reason, but through the innate sense of right and wrong revealed to him, and in the love for his family and the simple life of the peasantry.
