Sancho, hearing Rocinante neigh, takes it as a good omen and urges Don Quixote to make another sally. Carrasco advises going to Saragossa for jousts. Sancho again stresses caution in battle. Don Quixote asks for the acrostic verses for Dulcinea, and Carrasco agrees. They plan to depart in three days, keeping it secret from the housekeeper and niece.

**CHAPTER V: Of the shrewd and droll conversation that passed between Sancho Panza and his wife Teresa Panza, and other matters worthy of being duly recorded**
Sancho returns home, overjoyed, and tells his wife Teresa he is going back to Don Quixote to seek adventures, hoping for more money and the promised island. Teresa doesn't understand his roundabout speech. Sancho asks her to care for Dapple. Teresa expresses concern for his safety, but Sancho is confident he will become governor. Teresa worries about their daughter Mari-Sancha's social standing if she marries above her station. Sancho insists Mari-Sancha will be a countess. Teresa argues that true nobility comes from virtue and that people will scorn them for rising above their station.
Sancho, exasperated, declares that he will become governor to raise his family out of poverty. He says Teresa will be "Doña Teresa Panza." Teresa continues to object, citing proverbs about humility and caution, and fears gossip. Sancho insists on seizing opportunity.
The narrator interjects that Sancho's cleverness here is unusual, making the chapter seem "apocryphal." Sancho continues to insist on his plan, saying he can be a good governor. Teresa, weeping, reluctantly agrees. Sancho then returns to Don Quixote to prepare for departure.

**CHAPTER VI: Of what took place between Don Quixote and his niece and housekeeper; one of the most important chapters in the whole history**
Don Quixote's niece and housekeeper, fearing a third sally, try to dissuade him. The housekeeper threatens to complain to God and the king. Don Quixote dismisses this, comparing his knight-errantry to courtly service, arguing that true knights face real dangers, unlike armchair courtiers. He describes their valor in confronting giants and monsters. The niece calls these stories "fable and fiction." Don Quixote gets angry, defending the honor of Queen Madasima (from his books). He explains that true gentlemen can be found in all social classes, and that virtue, wealth, and generosity define nobility. He states he follows the path of arms, not letters, as destiny dictates. He quotes a poet about reaching immortality through rugged paths. The niece comments on his poetic skill. Sancho arrives and is welcomed by Don Quixote, but the housekeeper hides. Don Quixote and Sancho then confer in private.

**CHAPTER VII: Of what passed between Don Quixote and his squire, together with other very notable incidents**
The housekeeper, fearing Don Quixote's third sally, runs to Samson Carrasco for help. She describes Don Quixote's previous returns (belabored on an ass, caged in a cart). Carrasco, amused, tells her to prepare breakfast and he will "work miracles."
Don Quixote and Sancho discuss their agreement. Sancho complains that Don Quixote corrects his speech. Sancho then reports his wife's insistence on fixed wages. He explains that life is fleeting, and he needs financial security, suggesting a monthly wage, from which his island's revenue could be deducted. Don Quixote rejects fixed wages, saying knights' squires serve on "reward" (islands, titles), as per tradition. He threatens to dismiss Sancho if he insists on wages.
Sancho, dejected, is observed by Carrasco, who (to deceive Don Quixote) praises his new sally and offers his own service and money. Don Quixote rejects Carrasco's offer, saying he is a "pillar of letters." Sancho, moved, tearfully agrees to follow his master. They embrace. Carrasco, the curate, and barber agree on a plan to bring Don Quixote home. Carrasco will provide a closed helmet. The housekeeper and niece loudly lament Don Quixote's departure. Don Quixote and Sancho, having prepared, leave secretly at night for El Toboso, accompanied by Carrasco for half a league.

**CHAPTER VIII: Wherein is related what befell Don Quixote on his way to see his lady Dulcinea del Toboso**
Don Quixote and Sancho set out for El Toboso. Rocinante neighs and Dapple sighs, which Sancho interprets as good omens, believing his fortune will outstrip his master's. Don Quixote intends to get Dulcinea's blessing before new adventures. Sancho reminds him of her "yard wall" (which Don Quixote believes was a palace gallery) and her "sifting wheat" (which Don Quixote attributes to an enchanter's malice). Don Quixote fears the printed history of his deeds might be inaccurate if written by an enemy enchanter. Sancho worries his reputation is being dragged in the dirt but is pleased to be in a book.
Don Quixote sees the desire for fame in others (poet and Emperor Charles V story) and emphasizes that Catholic knights-errant seek eternal glory, not just earthly fame. He outlines the virtues required of a knight-errant. Sancho questions the fate of ancient knights (heathens in hell, Christians in purgatory or heaven) and the nature of saintly relics compared to knightly fame. Sancho suggests they become saints for quicker fame, citing the recent canonization of friars. Don Quixote agrees there are sainted knights but notes not all can be friars.
They approach El Toboso at daybreak. Don Quixote is eager to see Dulcinea, but Sancho is anxious, as he has never seen her. They decide to enter the city at night.

**CHAPTER IX: Wherein is related what will be seen there**
Don Quixote and Sancho enter El Toboso at midnight. The town is silent. Don Quixote, believing they are near Dulcinea's palace, tells Sancho to lead the way. Sancho insists her house was small. They mistake the chief church for her palace. Don Quixote, again, admits he has never seen Dulcinea and is in love by reputation. Sancho confesses his previous report of seeing her sifting wheat and delivering a letter was a lie. Don Quixote is outraged.
They encounter a laborer, who tells them the curate and sacristan might know of a "princess." Sancho suggests they leave the city, hide in a forest, and he will return during the day to find Dulcinea and arrange a discreet meeting. Don Quixote agrees. Sancho, eager to prevent his lie about Dulcinea from being discovered, hurries his master out of town.

**CHAPTER X: Wherein is related the crafty device Sancho adopted to enchant the Lady Dulcinea, and other incidents as ludicrous as they are true**
Don Quixote, filled with troubled thoughts about Dulcinea's enchantment, waits in a forest. He instructs Sancho to deliver his message, observing Dulcinea's reactions for signs of love. Sancho, alone, schemes: he knows Don Quixote is delusional and believes things appear transformed by enchanters. He decides to present the first country girl he finds as Dulcinea.
Sancho finds three peasant girls on asses. He rushes back to Don Quixote, who is deep in lamentations. Sancho declares he has seen Dulcinea, arriving with two damsels, adorned magnificently, on "piebald cackneys." Don Quixote, looking, sees only three country girls on three jackasses. Sancho insists they are hackneys and that Don Quixote's vision is distorted by enchanters.
Sancho kneels before one of the girls, proclaiming her the "Queen and princess and duchess of beauty" and introducing Don Quixote as the "Knight of the Rueful Countenance." Don Quixote, seeing only a "platter-faced and snub-nosed" peasant, is speechless. The girls are bewildered and angry, telling them to get out of the way. Don Quixote, believing an enchanter has transformed Dulcinea's beauty, tells her not to refuse his love, as his soul adores her despite her "transformed beauty." The girl curses him and rides off, her ass bucking and throwing her.
Don Quixote runs to help her, but she quickly remounts. Sancho comments on her agility. Don Quixote laments the enchanters' malice for transforming Dulcinea into a peasant with a garlic smell. Sancho, knowing he invented the enchantment, pretends to be angry at the enchanters. He then adds that Dulcinea has a mole with "seven or eight red hairs" on her right lip. Don Quixote questions the size of the hairs but accepts it. Sancho also claims the pack-saddle was a rich "jineta" saddle. They remount and head for Saragossa.

**CHAPTER XI: Of the strange adventure which the valiant Don Quixote had with the car or cart of “The Cortes of Death”**
Don Quixote, dejected by Dulcinea's supposed enchantment, lets Rocinante graze freely. Sancho advises him to shake off melancholy. Don Quixote still blames enchanters for Dulcinea's transformation and questions Sancho's description of her "pearl" eyes. Sancho replies his own vision was also affected. He expresses concern about how future vanquished knights will find an enchanted Dulcinea. Don Quixote plans to test this by sending the first two vanquished knights to her.
They encounter a cart full of strange figures: Death, an angel, an emperor, Cupid, and a knight. The driver is dressed as a demon. Don Quixote challenges them, believing it is a new adventure. The demon driver explains they are a theater company performing "The Cortés of Death" and are traveling in their costumes. Don Quixote, now understanding, lets them pass.
Suddenly, a jester from the company, dressed with bells and armed with inflated ox-bladders, startles Rocinante. Don Quixote's horse bolts, throwing him. Sancho, dismounting to help his master, sees the jester jump on Dapple and beat him, making the ass bolt towards the village. Sancho, torn between his master and his ass, prioritizes Don Quixote. He helps his master up. Don Quixote, seeing Dapple returning (as the jester had dismounted), wants to avenge the "devil." Sancho advises against fighting actors, who are a "favoured class." Don Quixote, accepting actors are not knights, lets them go. The dread adventure of the cart of Death ends.

**CHAPTER XII: Of the strange adventure which befell the valiant Don Quixote with the Bold Knight of the Mirrors**
Don Quixote and Sancho pass the night under trees. Sancho, regretting not choosing the emperor's crown as spoils, compares the real crowns to brass foil. Don Quixote discusses the value of theater as a mirror of life. Sancho extends the metaphor to a chess game. Don Quixote notes Sancho's growing shrewdness.
They fall asleep. Don Quixote is woken by a noise and sees two men on horseback, one dismounting and stretching on the ground, his armor rattling. Don Quixote, recognizing him as a knight-errant, wakes Sancho. They listen as the knight (the Knight of the Grove) tunes a lute and sings a sonnet to his lady, Casildea de Vandalia, lamenting her cruelty and his endless toils. He boasts of having made all knights of Spain confess her beauty, and specifically, of having vanquished Don Quixote of La Mancha.
Don Quixote is outraged, denying he was ever vanquished, and suggesting enchanters transformed him. He describes his own appearance and his squire Sancho Panza, and his lady Dulcinea. The Knight of the Grove confirms these details, but Don Quixote insists it was an enchanted likeness. They agree to fight at daybreak, with the vanquished being at the victor's disposal.
The squires are woken. The Knight of the Grove's squire (who has a monstrous nose) explains to Sancho that squires must fight alongside their masters. Sancho refuses, citing his peaceful nature and lack of a sword. The squire offers to fight with bags of pebbles. Sancho is horrified by the squire's enormous nose.
Don Quixote then challenges the Knight of the Mirrors, insisting he is not the one previously vanquished. They prepare to charge. Sancho, terrified of the nosy squire, climbs a cork tree. Don Quixote charges. The Knight of the Mirrors, whose horse is slow, is caught off guard. Don Quixote unhorses him with a powerful blow.
Don Quixote dismounts, unlaces the vanquished knight's helmet, and is astonished to see the face of Bachelor Samson Carrasco. Sancho, equally amazed, also recognizes Carrasco and his squire as Tom Cecial, his neighbor (without the fake nose). Don Quixote believes enchanters have transformed his friend. Don Quixote demands Carrasco confess Dulcinea's superior beauty and promise to go to El Toboso to present himself to her. Carrasco, from the ground, confesses and promises. He also admits Don Quixote was not the knight he vanquished. Don Quixote is pleased, attributing the transformations to enchanters. The two vanquished (Carrasco and Cecial) depart, and Don Quixote and Sancho continue their journey towards Saragossa.

**CHAPTER XV: Wherein it is told and known who the Knight of the Mirrors and his squire were**
Don Quixote, pleased with his victory, believes the Knight of the Mirrors will confirm Dulcinea's disenchantment. The history reveals that Bachelor Samson Carrasco's plan was to defeat Don Quixote and force him to return home for two years to recover his sanity. Carrasco, with Tom Cecial as his squire (disguised with a false nose), followed Don Quixote. They fought, and Don Quixote's delusions of enchantment saved Carrasco from a worse defeat.
Tom Cecial, seeing their failure, regrets becoming a squire. Carrasco, bruised, vows to pursue Don Quixote again. They find a bone-setter. Tom Cecial goes home, while Carrasco plans vengeance.

**CHAPTER XVI: Of what befell Don Quixote with a discreet gentleman of La Mancha**
Don Quixote, elated by his victory over the Knight of the Mirrors, imagines himself the greatest knight-errant. He longs for Dulcinea's disenchantment. Sancho questions if the Knight of the Mirrors was truly Carrasco. Don Quixote insists it was an enchantment to protect his friend.
They meet Don Diego de Miranda, a wealthy gentleman in green, riding a mare. Don Quixote identifies himself and his profession as a knight-errant, claiming his history is in print. Don Diego is amazed by Don Quixote's madness but notes his sensible speech. Don Diego introduces himself and describes his quiet, virtuous life. Sancho, impressed, kisses Don Diego's foot, believing him a saint.
Don Quixote asks about Don Diego's children. Don Diego expresses concern over his son, Don Lorenzo, who is a poet and neglects law. Don Quixote defends poetry as a noble science and advises Don Diego to let his son follow his inclination, provided he writes virtuously.
As they near Don Diego's village, Don Quixote still in full armor, calls for his helmet. Sancho, having bought curds from shepherds, puts them in the helmet. Don Quixote puts on the helmet, and the whey runs down his face. He is startled, thinking his brains are melting, but then realizes it's curds and accuses Sancho. Sancho, pretending innocence, blames enchanters.

**CHAPTER XVII: Wherein is shown the furthest and highest point which the unexampled courage of Don Quixote reached or could reach; together with the happily achieved adventure of the lions**
Don Quixote, having cleaned himself, puts on the helmet. He sees a cart with royal flags approaching, carrying two caged lions as a gift for the King. Don Quixote, believing it's an adventure, demands the keeper release the lions so he can fight them. Don Diego and Sancho try to dissuade him, calling him mad. Don Quixote, undeterred, threatens the keeper with his lance. The keeper unyokes his mules and retreats with them and the cart to a safe distance.
Don Quixote dismounts, throws aside his lance, and draws his sword, preparing to fight on foot. The author extols Don Quixote's unparalleled courage. The keeper opens the cage door. The lion, a huge beast, stretches, yawns, and looks around, then turns its back on Don Quixote and lies down again. Don Quixote orders the keeper to provoke it. The keeper refuses, saying Don Quixote has already demonstrated his courage. Don Quixote agrees, orders the cage closed, and demands a certificate of his brave deed. He renames himself "the Knight of the Lions."
Sancho pays the keeper and carter for the delay. Don Diego, amazed, now sees Don Quixote as a madman with lucid intervals. Don Quixote continues to defend his actions with chivalric reasoning. Don Diego invites them to his house.

**CHAPTER XVIII: Of what happened Don Quixote in the castle or house of the Knight of the Green Gaban, together with other matters out of the common**
At Don Diego's village house, Don Quixote sees wine-jars, reminding him of Dulcinea, and he laments her enchantment. Don Diego's son, Don Lorenzo, and wife, Doña Christina, are amazed by Don Quixote. Don Quixote is treated with great politeness.
Sancho removes Don Quixote's armor. Don Quixote washes, but the water remains "whey-coloured" due to the curds. Dressed in civilian clothes, he joins Don Lorenzo. Don Lorenzo, initially thinking Don Quixote sane, is confused by his talk of knight-errantry. Don Quixote explains that the "science" of knight-errantry encompasses all others (law, theology, medicine, astronomy, mathematics) and requires all virtues. Don Lorenzo agrees this science surpasses all others but questions the existence of such knights. Don Quixote asserts their existence and necessity.
At dinner, Don Lorenzo recites a gloss on some verses he wrote. Don Quixote praises him, calling him the best poet. Don Lorenzo then recites a sonnet on Pyramus and Thisbe. Don Quixote is still impressed. Don Quixote expresses his desire to visit the cave of Montesinos and the lakes of Ruidera before going to Saragossa. Don Diego and Don Lorenzo offer their help. Don Quixote and Sancho depart.

**CHAPTER XIX: In which is related the adventure of the enamoured shepherd, together with other truly droll incidents**
Don Quixote and Sancho meet two students and two peasants. One student describes a grand wedding of Camacho the Rich and Quiteria the Fair, noting the despair of Basilio the Poor, who is in love with Quiteria. Basilio is skilled in physical feats and music. Don Quixote declares Basilio deserves to marry Quiteria. Sancho agrees, wishing lovers could marry. Don Quixote discusses the importance of parental choice in marriage. The student mentions Basilio's extreme melancholy since Quiteria's engagement. Sancho is confident love will find a way, citing proverbs.
Another student, Bachelor Corchuelo, challenges the first student (who is a master of fence) to a sword fight. Don Quixote offers to judge. Corchuelo, strong but untrained, attacks wildly. The fencing master skillfully defeats him without injury, touching him with the button of his sword. Corchuelo, humbled, embraces the master. They proceed to Quiteria's village, arriving at night. The village is illuminated and filled with music for the wedding. Don Quixote insists on sleeping in the fields, despite Sancho's desire for an inn.

**CHAPTER XX: Wherein an account is given of the wedding of Camacho the Rich, together with the incident of Basilio the Poor**
At dawn, Don Quixote wakes Sancho, musing on the tranquility of his squire's sleep, free from knightly cares. Sancho wakes to the smell of a great feast. He praises the abundance of Camacho's wedding. Don Quixote orders them to the wedding, eager to see Basilio. Sancho, pragmatic, argues in favor of Camacho's wealth over Basilio's talents.
They enter the wedding arcade. Sancho is amazed by the lavish preparations: an entire ox roasted, six huge stewpots, countless game birds, sixty wine skins, piles of bread, and a wall of cheeses. He immediately begs a cook for food and is given a bucketful of hens and geese.
Various dance troupes perform, including sword-dancers and maidens. A "speaking dance" featuring Cupid, Interest, and nymphs representing Poetry, Wit, Birth, Valour, Liberality, Largess, Treasure, and Peaceful Possession, performs. Interest triumphs over the "Castle of Caution." Don Quixote correctly infers the dance reflects Camacho's wealth. Sancho openly sides with Camacho. Don Quixote laments Sancho's gluttony and love of proverbs. Sancho argues that Death takes all equally.

**CHAPTER XXI: In which Camacho’s wedding is continued, with other delightful incidents**
The bride and bridegroom arrive. Quiteria, beautifully dressed, appears pale. Sancho praises her beauty. They approach the theatre where they will be married. Suddenly, Basilio appears, dressed in black and cypress, holding a staff. He confronts Quiteria, lamenting her ingratitude and his poverty. He then uses his staff, which conceals a rapier, to stab himself through the body, declaring he will die if Quiteria does not take him as her husband.
Basilio's friends rush to his aid. The priest refuses to remove the rapier before confession. Basilio insists on marrying Quiteria before confessing, so he can die as her husband. Don Quixote declares his request just and honorable, noting that a marriage to a dying man would not affect Camacho's honor. Camacho, bewildered, is persuaded by Basilio's friends to allow Quiteria to give her hand, believing it to be a formality for a dying man.
Quiteria, seemingly distressed, takes Basilio's hand and, with a faint voice, declares her free will to be his wife, whether he lives or dies. Basilio also declares his will. The priest pronounces them married. Basilio then springs to his feet and pulls out the rapier, revealing it was a trick: the blade passed through a hollow iron tube filled with blood. Everyone is astonished. Quiteria confirms the marriage, implying complicity.
Camacho and his supporters are enraged and attack Basilio. Don Quixote, on Rocinante, intervenes, defending Basilio with his lance, proclaiming that love and war allow stratagems, and that God has joined Basilio and Quiteria. Camacho's anger subsides, and he is persuaded by the priest to let the marriage stand. Camacho and his party are appeased, and the festivities resume without the newly married couple or their followers. Don Quixote and Sancho accompany Basilio and Quiteria to their village. Sancho is sad to leave Camacho's feast, still thinking of the food.

**CHAPTER XXII: Wherein is related the grand adventure of the cave of Montesinos in the heart of La Mancha, which the valiant Don Quixote brought to a happy termination**
Basilio and Quiteria treat Don Quixote with great gratitude. Don Quixote advises Basilio to pursue wealth through honest industry, not just accomplishments, to support his wife. He discusses the virtue of a poor, honorable wife. Sancho, listening, notes his master's wide knowledge.
Sancho admits his wife Teresa is not "very good." Don Quixote chides him for speaking ill of her. They stay with the couple for three days. Don Quixote then requests a guide to the cave of Montesinos. The fencing licentiate offers his cousin, a scholar of chivalry books.
The cousin arrives with an ass. Don Quixote, Sancho, and the cousin set out. The cousin, a humanist and author, describes his books: "The Book of Liveries," "Metamorphoses, or the Spanish Ovid," and "The Supplement to Polydore Vergil." Sancho asks silly questions, such as "who was the first man that scratched his head?" and "who was the first tumbler?" Sancho answers the latter (Lucifer). Don Quixote attributes Sancho's wit to overhearing others.
They reach the cave. Don Quixote, the cousin, and Sancho dismount. The cousin and Sancho tie Don Quixote with ropes. Sancho worries Don Quixote will bury himself alive. Don Quixote, convinced this adventure is for him, prays to Dulcinea and God. He cuts away brambles at the cave mouth, releasing a multitude of crows and choughs. He lowers himself into the cave, with Sancho and the cousin praying for his safety.
Don Quixote calls for more rope. After a hundred fathoms, his calls cease. They wait, then pull up the rope, finding Don Quixote unconscious, seemingly asleep. They revive him. Don Quixote exclaims about a "sweetest and most delightful existence and spectacle" and laments Montesinos, Durandarte, Belerma, and the Ruidera lakes.

**CHAPTER XXIII: Of the wonderful things the incomparable Don Quixote said he saw in the profound Cave of Montesinos, the impossibility and magnitude of which cause this adventure to be deemed apocryphal**
Don Quixote, at four in the afternoon, recounts his experience in the cave. He describes being lowered, falling into a deep sleep, and waking in a beautiful meadow within the cave. He sees a crystal palace and a venerable old man, who introduces himself as Montesinos, the warden of the cave. Montesinos embraces him and explains they have been waiting for Don Quixote to reveal their enchantment to the world.
Don Quixote asks if Montesinos cut out Durandarte's heart with a dagger and carried it to Belerma. Montesinos confirms, adding it was a poniard. Don Quixote then sees Durandarte lying on a marble tomb in the palace, still alive but enchanted, moaning for Montesinos to take his heart to Belerma. Montesinos recounts how he fulfilled the request, preserved the heart, and how Merlin enchanted them all, including Guadiana and Ruidera with her daughters (who became lakes and a river). Montesinos says Don Quixote is prophesied to break the enchantment.
Durandarte, in a faint voice, says, "patience and shuffle." A procession of mourning damsels appears, led by a lady (Belerma) carrying a mummified heart. Montesinos explains her beauty is obscured by her grief. Don Quixote interrupts, asserting Dulcinea's unparalleled beauty. Montesinos apologizes, agreeing that nothing compares to Dulcinea.
Sancho expresses surprise that Don Quixote didn't beat Montesinos. Don Quixote defends respecting the aged. The cousin questions how Don Quixote saw so much in just an hour. Don Quixote claims he was in the cave for three days, as everything is enchanted. He says he ate nothing and did not sleep. Sancho attributes this to his master's company. Sancho then states he doesn't believe a word of it, thinking enchanters put it all in Don Quixote's mind.
Don Quixote insists he saw it all. He then tells them Montesinos showed him three country girls, one of whom was Dulcinea, and the others her companions. He states Montesinos said they were enchanted ladies. Sancho is about to lose his wits laughing, realizing Don Quixote believes his own lies. Sancho claims Don Quixote is stark mad. Don Quixote dismisses Sancho's words.
Don Quixote recounts that Dulcinea, as a country girl, did not speak to him, but fled. One of her companions, in great need, asked him for six reals, offering her dimity petticoat as a pledge. Don Quixote gave her four reals (from Sancho's alms) and sent a message to Dulcinea of his suffering and his vow to disenchant her. The damsel took the money and left. Sancho is further amazed by his master's madness.

**CHAPTER XXIV: Wherein are related a thousand trifling matters, as trivial as they are necessary to the right understanding of this great history**
The translator notes that Cid Hamete expressed doubt about Don Quixote's account of the cave, finding it improbable, but recorded it anyway. The cousin, still amazed, thanks Don Quixote for the knowledge gained (about Montesinos's cave, Guadiana's transformation, antiquity of cards, and source of Guadiana). Don Quixote questions who would print the cousin's books, to which the cousin replies there are many lords. Don Quixote says few accept books that require gratitude.
They decide to go to a nearby hermitage for the night. The hermit is absent, and the sub-hermit offers only water. Sancho laments the lack of better fare. They continue to an inn. They meet a young page, on foot, singing, on his way to join the army. Don Quixote praises military service. Sancho observes that Don Quixote sometimes speaks great sense, but then falls back into madness. They reach the inn, which Don Quixote now recognizes as an inn.

**CHAPTER XXV: Wherein is set down the Braying Adventure, and the droll one of the Puppet-Showman, together with the memorable divinations of the divining ape**
Don Quixote, eager to hear the courier's story, helps him in the stable. The courier relates the "Braying Adventure": two regidors in his village lost an ass. One, skilled in braying, suggested they bray to find it. They kept mistaking each other's braying for the ass's. The ass was found dead, eaten by wolves. The joke of braying spread to other villages, causing fights. The courier is now carrying arms for an impending battle between his village and another due to this insult.
A chamois-clad man, Master Pedro, arrives at the inn, announcing his divining ape and puppet show. Sancho, delighted, gives two reals for a prediction about his wife. Master Pedro refuses payment until service is rendered. The ape whispers in his ear. Master Pedro kneels before Don Quixote, recognizing him as the "illustrious reviver of knight-errantry," and Sancho as his squire, stating Teresa Panza is well and spinning flax at home, drinking wine. Don Quixote is astonished, attributing the ape's knowledge to magic.
Master Pedro offers a free puppet show of the "Release of Melisendra." Don Quixote has scruples about the ape's supposed demonic powers. Sancho, however, insists Don Quixote ask the ape about his Montesinos cave adventure. The ape, through Master Pedro, says the cave events were "part false, part true." Don Quixote is not satisfied.

**CHAPTER XXVI: Wherein is continued the droll adventure of the puppet-showman, together with other things in truth right good**
The puppet show begins. The boy narrator describes the story of Don Gaiferos, who plays tables, forgetting his wife Melisendra, captive in Sansueña (Saragossa). Emperor Charlemagne (Melisendra's father) scolds Don Gaiferos. Gaiferos, angered, calls for his armor. Melisendra, on a balcony, sees a Moor kissing her, and she spits. King Marsilio orders the Moor to be lashed. Don Quixote interrupts, correcting the boy about Moors not having bells. Master Pedro tells the boy to ignore Don Quixote's criticisms.
The boy continues: Don Gaiferos appears, Melisendra recognizes him, and lowers herself from the balcony. Her petticoat catches, but Gaiferos pulls her down and places her on his horse, and they ride off to Paris. The narrator wishes them well. Don Quixote, seeing the many Moors pursuing them, jumps up, draws his sword, and furiously attacks the puppet Moors, believing them real. He destroys the entire show, injuring King Marsilio and Charlemagne.
Master Pedro laments the destruction of his livelihood. Don Quixote, believing he has aided Don Gaiferos and Melisendra, declares how useful knights-errant are. Sancho is impressed by his master's fury. Master Pedro demands compensation. Don Quixote, convinced enchanters made the puppets appear as real Moors, agrees to pay. The landlord and Sancho are made arbitrators. Master Pedro itemizes the damages, valuing each broken puppet. Sancho pays the agreed amount. Master Pedro also asks for two reals for catching the ape, which Don Quixote grants.
Master Pedro says his ape will return that night. The storm over, they all sup at Don Quixote's expense. The man with lances and halberds, the cousin, and the page depart. Master Pedro, knowing Don Quixote's madness, leaves early with his ape. Sancho pays the landlord liberally. Don Quixote and Sancho depart for Saragossa.

**CHAPTER XXVII: Wherein it is shown who Master Pedro and his ape were, together with the mishap Don Quixote had in the Braying Adventure, which he did not conclude as he would have liked or as he had expected**
Cide Hamete, the author, states that Master Pedro was Gines de Pasamonte, whom Don Quixote had freed from the galleys. Gines had stolen Dapple from Sancho while he was asleep. Fearing the Holy Brotherhood, Gines disguised himself as a puppet-showman, covered his eye with a patch, and trained an ape to "divine" by whispering in his ear. He gathered information in each village to make his predictions seem real. This is how he astonished Don Quixote and Sancho at the inn.
Don Quixote and Sancho are on their way to Saragossa. On the third day, they hear drums and muskets and see two hundred men with a standard depicting a braying ass. Don Quixote deduces these are the men from the "braying town" going to battle. Sancho confirms the story of the regidors (or alcaldes) who brayed.
Don Quixote addresses the men, lecturing them on the folly of fighting over such a trivial insult, as a community cannot be insulted by a single person. He emphasizes that arms should only be taken up for the Catholic faith, life, honor, country, or king. Sancho, impressed, calls his master a theologian and a good soldier. To prove the braying skill, Sancho brays. One of the men, taking it as mockery, strikes Sancho, knocking him down. Don Quixote, enraged, attacks the man with his lance, but is surrounded by the numerous armed men. A shower of stones, crossbows, and muskets are aimed at him. He flees on Rocinante. The men, satisfied, do not pursue him. They put the stunned Sancho on Dapple, who follows Rocinante. Don Quixote waits for Sancho.

**CHAPTER XXVIII: Of matters that Benengeli says he who reads them will know, if he reads them with attention**
Don Quixote, fleeing the braying townsfolk, eventually waits for Sancho. Sancho, bruised, curses his master's rashness and blames him for leaving him to be beaten. Don Quixote justifies his retreat as prudence, not flight, citing examples of valiant men reserving themselves for better times. He tells Sancho his constant complaining is a sign he's not in pain. Sancho, still sore, expresses his disillusionment with knight-errantry and wishes to return home to his family. He complains about the lack of wages and comfort.
Don Quixote offers to pay Sancho extra, beyond what he earned from Tom Carrasco, but maintains that squires serve on "reward," not wages. Sancho demands twenty years' worth of back wages for the promised island. Don Quixote, angered by Sancho's "avarice" and "perversion" of knightly rules, threatens to dismiss him. Sancho, remorseful, apologizes and begs to stay, offering to serve as an ass if a tail is added to him. Don Quixote, moved, forgives him, but warns him against self-interest and excessive proverbs. Sancho promises to mend his ways. They rest in a grove. Don Quixote wakes, composing a madrigal about his love and sorrow. Sancho sleeps soundly.

**CHAPTER XXIX: Of the famous adventure of the enchanted bark**
Two days later, Don Quixote and Sancho reach the Ebro River. Don Quixote is delighted by the scenery, recalling the cave of Montesinos. He sees a small boat without oars, tied to a tree. He immediately declares it an enchanted bark, calling him to aid a knight or princess in distress. Sancho argues it's a fisherman's boat. Don Quixote insists on embarking, believing enchanters will guide them. Sancho, with a heavy heart, ties Rocinante and Dapple to a tree, lamenting leaving them.
They embark. Sancho is terrified as the boat drifts into the current. Don Quixote reassures him, believing they are traversing vast distances and may have crossed the equinoctial line (where lice die). Sancho tests this but finds lice. He observes they haven't moved far from the bank. Don Quixote dismisses Sancho's observations, citing his lack of knowledge of cosmology.
They approach water mills. Don Quixote declares them an enchanted castle with a captive knight. Sancho insists they are mills. Don Quixote attributes the appearance of mills to enchanters. The millers rush out, shouting warnings. Don Quixote, standing in the boat, threatens them, demanding they release the captive. He draws his sword and attacks the millers, who are trying to stop the boat from being sucked into the wheels. Sancho falls to his knees in prayer. The millers push the boat away, throwing Don Quixote and Sancho into the water. Don Quixote, a good swimmer, saves himself, though his armor is heavy. The millers and fishermen help them out. The fishermen demand payment for their smashed boat. Don Quixote agrees, if they release the captive in the "castle." The millers tell him he is mad. Don Quixote concludes two enchanters are working against each other. He pays fifty reals for the boat. Sancho grumbles about the expense. They return to their beasts.

**CHAPTER XXX: Of Don Quixote’s adventure with a fair huntress**
Don Quixote and Sancho, dejected, continue their journey. Sancho, disheartened by his master's delusions and his own diminishing prospects, considers leaving his service.
The next day, they encounter a hawking party led by a beautiful lady on a white palfrey. Don Quixote, believing her to be a great lady, sends Sancho to present himself as squire to the Knight of the Lions and offer his master's services. Sancho, proud of his message-carrying skills, delivers the message. The lady (a duchess) recognizes Don Quixote from his printed history and welcomes him and Sancho to her country house. Sancho, pleased, returns to his master, praising the duchess.
Don Quixote, exhilarated, rides to meet the duchess. Sancho, dismounting Dapple, trips and gets his foot caught in the pack-saddle ropes, falling. Don Quixote, expecting Sancho to hold his stirrup, also falls from Rocinante, whose saddle is loose. The duke's huntsmen help them. Don Quixote, limping, kneels before the duke and duchess. The duke apologizes for the mishap. Don Quixote thanks them and praises the duchess's beauty. The duke reminds him of Dulcinea. Sancho, released, praises the duchess's beauty as equal to Dulcinea's. Don Quixote apologizes for Sancho's talkativeness. The duke invites them to his castle, and Sancho, delighted by the prospect of good living, joins the duke and duchess.

**CHAPTER XXXI: Which treats of many and great matters**
Sancho is happy to be in the duke's castle. The duke, having read Don Quixote's history, instructs his servants to treat him as a knight-errant. Lackeys, dressed in crimson satin, greet Don Quixote. The duchess insists on dismounting in the duke's arms. In the courtyard, servants welcome Don Quixote as the "flower and cream of knight-errantry," showering him with scented water. Don Quixote believes himself a real knight-errant.
Sancho, worried about Dapple, asks a duenna (Doña Rodriguez de Grijalba) to stable him. The duenna scolds him for suggesting duennas do such work. Sancho retorts with a saying about ladies attending Lancelot's hack. The duchess intervenes, telling Sancho Doña Rodriguez is young. Sancho apologizes. Don Quixote chides Sancho for his impertinence. Sancho promises to be more careful.
Don Quixote is led to a richly decorated chamber, where damsels remove his armor. He refuses to strip naked, saying modesty is important for knights. He changes in private with Sancho. He scolds Sancho for his earlier rudeness, urging him to be more discreet so as not to discredit him. Sancho promises to curb his tongue.
Don Quixote, dressed in civilian clothes and a green satin montera, is led to dinner. The duke and duchess receive him with pomp. A grave ecclesiastic is present. Don Quixote is seated at the head of the table. Sancho, eager to speak, asks to tell a story about seating. Don Quixote, fearing a blunder, tries to stop him, but the duchess encourages Sancho. Sancho tells a long, rambling story about a rich gentleman and a laborer arguing over who should sit at the head of the table, ending with the gentleman forcing the laborer to sit, saying, "wherever I sit will be the head to you."
Don Quixote is embarrassed. The duke and duchess suppress their laughter. The duchess changes the subject, asking about Dulcinea. Don Quixote explains Dulcinea is enchanted into a peasant girl. Sancho confirms this, adding she jumps like a cat. The ecclesiastic, suspecting Don Quixote is the subject of the popular history, angrily reproves the duke for encouraging his madness and directly tells Don Quixote he is a "num-skull" for believing in knight-errantry.

**CHAPTER XXXII: Of the reply Don Quixote gave his censurer, with other incidents, grave and droll**
Don Quixote, trembling with rage, defends himself against the ecclesiastic, stating that his profession of knight-errantry is honorable and just. He criticizes the cleric for judging without understanding, emphasizing that he remedies injuries, rights wrongs, and chastises the proud. Sancho supports his master. The ecclesiastic, hearing Sancho mention the promised island, realizes he is Sancho Panza and angrily rises to leave, calling the duke a fool for sanctioning their madness. The duke and duchess are amused.
Don Quixote explains that women and ecclesiastics cannot offer an "insult" because they are unarmed and cannot defend themselves or maintain a challenge.
Four damsels come to wash Don Quixote's beard. One uses a basin and soap, covering his face in lather, while another goes to fetch more water. Don Quixote is left in a ridiculous state. The duke, not wanting the joke revealed, also lets himself be washed. Sancho notes the custom, wishing squires also got such treatment. The duchess promises Sancho will be washed.
At table, the duchess asks Don Quixote to describe Dulcinea. Don Quixote sighs, saying her beauty is beyond words, but then attributes her current appearance to enchanters, reiterating that she was transformed into a foul peasant. The duke and duchess express skepticism, having read the history and believing Dulcinea to be imaginary. Don Quixote defends Dulcinea's existence and noble qualities, even if she is "the daughter of her own works." He also defends Sancho's simplicity mixed with shrewdness, stating he would not exchange him for a city.
Sancho is brought in, angry and covered in dishwater, protesting the forced washing. Don Quixote intervenes, saying he and Sancho do not understand jokes. Sancho refuses to be washed with dirty water. The duchess, amused, orders them to leave Sancho alone, confirming he is clean. Sancho thanks her and reminds her of his promised government. The duchess promises to expedite it. Don Quixote retires. The duchess and duke plan a new joke.

**CHAPTER XXXIII: Of the delectable discourse which the duchess and her damsels held with Sancho Panza, well worth reading and noting**
Sancho, determined to stay awake, visits the duchess and her damsels. He is made to sit, despite his protests. The duchess asks Sancho how he dared to invent Dulcinea's letter and her enchantment, knowing he never saw her. Sancho, after checking for eavesdroppers, confesses he made it up to satisfy his master, whom he believes is mad. He then recounts the story of Dulcinea's "enchantment" by his trickery.
The duchess expresses doubt about giving Sancho a government, since he knowingly follows a madman. Sancho argues his loyalty and simple nature are sufficient. He cites proverbs about God's will and the inevitability of fate. Doña Rodriguez, the duenna, interjects with a ballad about King Rodrigo, supporting Sancho's view that poverty and suffering are common. The duchess assures Sancho he will get his island. Sancho again lists proverbs about ruling.
The duchess claims she knows from her own enchanters that Dulcinea is truly enchanted, and Sancho is the deceived, not the deceiver. Sancho, astonished, concedes this is possible, and admits he made up the story to avoid his master's anger, not to harm him. The duchess questions him about the cave of Montesinos, which he recounts. He then insists he will be a good governor.
Sancho asks the duchess to ensure Dapple is well cared for. The duchess, surprised by his concern for an ass, promises to put Dapple "on the apple of my eye." Sancho rejects this, insisting Dapple should be in the stable. The duchess, amused, agrees to ensure Dapple's comfort. The duke and duchess, finding Don Quixote and Sancho an endless source of amusement, plan more elaborate jokes.

**CHAPTER XXXIV: Which relates how they learned the way in which they were to disenchant the peerless Dulcinea del Toboso, which is one of the rarest adventures in this book**
The duke and duchess, using Don Quixote's story of the cave of Montesinos as a basis, plan a new adventure. Six days later, they take Don Quixote out hunting with a grand retinue. Don Quixote declines a hunting suit, but Sancho takes one. Don Quixote, on Rocinante, accompanies the duchess.
In the woods, a huge boar appears. Don Quixote and the duke confront it. Sancho, terrified, abandons Dapple and tries to climb an oak tree. He falls and is left hanging upside down, calling for help. The boar is killed. Don Quixote releases Sancho. Sancho laments his torn hunting coat. He complains about the dangers of hunting. The duke defends hunting as a kingly pursuit. Sancho argues governors should stay home.
Night falls, bringing a haze. Trumpets, drums, muskets, and Moorish cries (lelilies) resound through the wood, as if a battle is raging. Don Quixote is amazed, Sancho terrified. A postillion disguised as a demon appears, blowing a horn, and announces he seeks Don Quixote to deliver a message from Montesinos. He states that the peerless Dulcinea is coming on a triumphal car, enchanted, with Montesinos, to instruct Don Quixote on her disenchantment. Sancho believes the demon is an "honest fellow." The demon leaves.
Don Quixote wonders if the Montesinos cave story was true. The duke urges him to wait. More lights and strange noises (creaking ox-carts) fill the wood. Three carts appear. Each carries an aged sage (Lirgandeo, Alquife, Archelaus), who briefly identify themselves and pass. Sancho is terrified, believing mischief is afoot.

**CHAPTER XXXV: Wherein is continued the instruction given to Don Quixote touching the disenchantment of Dulcinea, together with other marvellous incidents**
To the sound of sweet music, a triumphant car arrives, drawn by six grey mules, with penitents and a nymph (Altisidora) on a throne. The figure in a black robe rises, reveals himself as Death, and in a sleepy voice announces he is Merlin. Merlin states he has come to reveal the remedy for Dulcinea's enchantment: Don Quixote's squire, Sancho Panza, must receive three thousand and three hundred lashes on his bare buttocks, "and that they smart and sting and hurt him well."
Sancho vehemently refuses, questioning what his backside has to do with enchantments. Don Quixote threatens to tie and whip him himself. Merlin clarifies that the lashes must be voluntary, and Sancho can choose the time or have someone else administer them (though this alternative is then rejected by Sancho).
The nymph (Altisidora), unveiling her beautiful face, berates Sancho for his refusal, calling him names and appealing to his pity for her "blooming youth" wasted under the "husk of a rude peasant wench." She also points out Don Quixote's soul "stuck in his throat." Don Quixote confirms this sensation. Sancho again refuses the lashes, criticizing Dulcinea's manner of asking favors and reiterating his torn coat and desire for his government.
The duke insists Sancho must comply to become governor. Merlin states the matter must be settled immediately. The duchess encourages Sancho. Sancho, giving in, agrees to the 3,300 lashes, on condition that he can administer them when he likes, without drawing blood, and that "fly-flappers" count. Merlin agrees, promising Dulcinea will be disenchanted instantly and thank him. Sancho accepts.
Clarions sound, muskets discharge. Don Quixote embraces Sancho. The duke and duchess express satisfaction. The car moves on, and Dulcinea bows to them.
Morning breaks. The duke and duchess, pleased with their successful joke, return to the castle.

**CHAPTER XXXVI: Wherein is related the strange and undreamt-of adventure of the Distressed Duenna, alias the Countess Trifaldi, together with a letter which Sancho Panza wrote to his wife, Teresa Panza**
The duke's majordomo, who played Merlin, now orchestrates a new joke. The duchess asks Sancho if he has started his whipping. Sancho says he has given himself five lashes with his hand. The duchess insists on a more painful scourge. Sancho agrees to do it, "provided it does not hurt too much."
Sancho then offers his letter to his wife, Teresa Panza, to the duchess for reading. He claims to have dictated it himself. The duchess reads it: Sancho mentions being whipped for his government, sending Teresa a green hunting suit (from the duchess) for Sanchica, and his belief that Don Quixote is a "madman of some sense." He tells her he was in the cave of Montesinos, and Merlin required 3,300 lashes (minus five) to disenchant Dulcinea. He asks Teresa to keep it secret and says he expects to make money as governor. He sends Dapple's regards.
The duchess criticizes Sancho's greed and the contradiction about the lashes. Sancho offers to write another letter. The duchess takes the letter to the duke, who is highly amused.
At dinner, they hear fife and drum music. Two men in black robes beating drums, and a fife player, enter the garden. Following them is a gigantic figure in black, with a long white beard. This figure, Trifaldin of the White Beard, announces he is squire to the Countess Trifaldi, the "Distressed Duenna," who has come to seek Don Quixote's help for a strange misfortune. He asks if Don Quixote is present. The duke confirms Don Quixote is there and invites the Countess to enter.
Don Quixote expresses his willingness to help, criticizing the ecclesiastic's earlier scorn for knights-errant.

**CHAPTER XXXVII: Wherein is continued the notable adventure of the Distressed Duenna**
Sancho expresses his distrust of duennas, fearing this "Countess Three-skirts" will interfere with his government. Don Quixote defends the duenna, saying she is a countess. Doña Rodriguez (the duenna of the house) joins the argument, defending duennas but admits they are often maligned. Sancho continues his criticisms.
The fife and drums announce the Distressed Duenna's entrance. Twelve duennas in black robes and white hoods, followed by the Countess Trifaldi, led by Trifaldin of the White Beard, enter. The Countess's robe ends in three points, giving her the name Trifaldi. Don Quixote, the duke, and duchess rise to greet her. She kneels, speaking in a hoarse voice, and begs for Don Quixote's help, confirming his fame. Sancho, addressing her as "Duenissima," also promises aid.
Don Quixote assures her of his help. The Trifaldi begins her story: Queen Doña Maguncia of Kandy, mother of Princess Antonomasia (Trifaldi's charge), died of grief after her daughter married Don Clavijo, a gentleman of lower rank.

**CHAPTER XXXVIII: Wherein is told the Distressed Duenna’s tale of her misfortunes**
Sancho interrupts the Trifaldi, amused by her story. The Trifaldi continues: The marriage was secret due to the social disparity, but Antonomasia became pregnant. To conceal this, Don Clavijo and Antonomasia married before the Vicar, based on a pre-existing agreement. The Queen, Doña Maguncia, died of grief.
After the Queen's burial, the giant Malambruno, her cousin and an enchanter, appeared on a wooden horse. To avenge the Queen's death, punish Don Clavijo, and in wrath at Antonomasia, he enchanted them both, turning Antonomasia into a brass ape and Don Clavijo into a metal crocodile, with a pillar between them bearing an inscription. This enchantment would only be broken when the "valiant Manchegan" (Don Quixote) fought Malambruno in single combat. Malambruno then threatened Trifaldi and all the duennas, covering their faces with rough beards as a "civil death."
The Distressed One and the duennas lift their veils, revealing their bearded faces. The duke and duchess feign astonishment, while Don Quixote and Sancho are truly amazed. The Trifaldi laments their fate, asking how a bearded duenna can live. Sancho, moved, resolves to help his master.

**CHAPTER XLI: Of the arrival of Clavileño and the end of this protracted adventure**
As night falls, Don Quixote grows impatient for the arrival of the enchanted wooden horse, Clavileño. Four wild-men enter, carrying a large wooden horse. One announces that the knight and his squire must mount, turn a peg in its forehead, and keep their eyes covered until the horse neighs, which signals the journey's end. Sancho refuses to mount, claiming he is no knight or witch. The Distressed One implores Don Quixote and Sancho to mount, as her and the duennas' shaving depends on it. Don Quixote eagerly agrees. Sancho still refuses, fearing the long journey to Kandy (3,000 leagues) and the loss of his governorship.
The duke assures Sancho his island will remain, and his goodwill depends on Sancho's participation. Sancho, yielding, agrees, but asks if he can commend himself to God during the flight. The Trifaldi assures him Malambruno is a Christian enchanter. Don Quixote, seeing Sancho's fear, takes him aside and urges him to quickly give himself 500 lashes towards Dulcinea's disenchantment. Sancho refuses to whip himself now, promising to do it later.
They return to Clavileño. Don Quixote covers his eyes. He asks about the Palladium of Troy, fearing a trick. The Trifaldi assures him. Don Quixote mounts. Sancho reluctantly mounts behind him, finding the "croup" hard. He asks for a cushion, but Trifaldi says Clavileño takes no trappings and advises him to sit sideways. Sancho does so, and, asking for prayers, covers his eyes.
The duennas and others cheer loudly, creating the illusion of flight. Sancho, hearing their voices, asks how they can be so high if the voices reach them. Don Quixote explains it is due to the nature of enchantment. The duke and duchess use bellows to create wind, and later, burning tow to simulate the region of fire. Sancho, feeling the heat, fears they are in the fiery region and wants to uncover his eyes. Don Quixote warns him, citing the story of the licentiate Torralva. Sancho expresses doubts about the journey.
To conclude the joke, they light squibs in Clavileño's tail. The horse explodes with a loud noise, throwing Don Quixote and Sancho to the ground, half-singed. The duennas vanish. Don Quixote and Sancho, amazed to find themselves in the same garden, see a placard on a lance: "The illustrious knight Don Quixote of La Mancha has, by merely attempting it, finished and concluded the adventure of the Countess Trifaldi... Malambruno is now satisfied on every point, the chins of the duennas are now smooth and clean, and King Don Clavijo and Queen Antonomasia in their original form; and when the squirely flagellation shall have been completed, the white dove shall find herself delivered from the pestiferous gerfalcons that persecute her, and in the arms of her beloved mate."
Don Quixote reads the inscription, realizing it confirms Dulcinea's disenchantment and thanks heaven. He helps the duke and duchess to recover from their feigned swoon. Sancho searches for the beard-less Trifaldi. He is told she vanished. Sancho then claims he peered from Clavileño's blindfold and saw the earth like a mustard seed, and men like hazelnuts, and that he briefly dismounted to play with "seven goats" in heaven (two green, two red, two blue, one multi-colored). Don Quixote disputes this, saying it was impossible to pass the region of fire without burning. Don Quixote reminds Sancho of his own vow to believe the cave of Montesinos story. The duke and duchess return to the castle, pleased with the joke.

**CHAPTER XLII: Of the counsels which Don Quixote gave Sancho Panza before he set out to govern the island, together with other well-considered matters**
The duke and duchess, still finding Don Quixote and Sancho amusing, resolve to continue their jokes. The duke tells Sancho to prepare for his government of the island of Barataria. Sancho is less enthusiastic, claiming that from heaven, he saw how small the earth is, reducing his desire to govern a "grain of mustard seed." The duke assures him it is a real island, offering the wealth of the world and heaven. Sancho agrees, wishing to try what it's like to be a governor.
Don Quixote, with the duke's permission, takes Sancho aside to give him advice for governing. He emphasizes fearing God, self-knowledge (remembering his pig-keeping youth, which Sancho corrects to geese), glorifying his humble birth, valuing virtue over lineage, treating kinsfolk well, and guiding his wife wisely. He advises against arbitrary law, to have compassion for the poor, seek truth, be merciful, not to let passion blind judgment, and not to abuse those he punishes. He stresses that mercy is brighter than justice.
Don Quixote then gives advice for physical conduct: be clean, cut nails, don't go ungirt, dress appropriately, eat sparingly, be temperate in drinking, and avoid belching (which Sancho confuses with eructing). He warns against excessive proverbs. He advises him to ride gracefully and sleep moderately. Finally, he tells him never to dispute about families.
Sancho, overwhelmed, says he will forget everything and asks for it in writing. Don Quixote laments that governors cannot read or write, urging Sancho to learn at least to sign his name. Sancho says he can sign and will get others to write for him. He lists more proverbs. Don Quixote, exasperated, curses his proverbs. Sancho, declaring he'd rather go to heaven as "Sancho" than to hell as a governor, agrees to try his best. They go to dinner.

**CHAPTER XLIV: How Sancho Panza was conducted to his government, and of the strange adventure that befell Don Quixote in the castle**
The chronicler, Cid Hamete, notes his difficulty in writing this history, as it limits his scope to Don Quixote and Sancho, and he avoids inserting extraneous novels as in Part I.
That afternoon, the duke gives Sancho his written counsels. Sancho lets them drop, and the duke finds and reads them, again amazed by Don Quixote's madness and wit. That evening, Sancho is dispatched to Barataria with a large retinue. The majordomo, who played Trifaldi, leads the party, having been instructed by the duke and duchess. Sancho recognizes the majordomo's face as the Distressed One's, believing it's enchantment. Don Quixote dismisses this, believing it's a trick of wicked wizards.
Sancho sets out, dressed like a lawyer, mounted on a mule, with Dapple (newly caparisoned in silk) following. He is very pleased.
Meanwhile, Don Quixote, feeling Sancho's absence, wishes he could revoke his mandate. The duchess comforts him. Don Quixote asks to be alone in his chamber, fearing temptations. The duchess promises no one will disturb him. Don Quixote praises Dulcinea and thanks the duchess. He assures her Clavileño was a smooth ride and speculates Malambruno burned it to get rid of his instruments of evil. Don Quixote locks himself in his room.
As he undresses, his stocking bursts, distressing him. He uses Sancho's traveling boots. He cannot sleep due to the warmth and his thoughts. He opens his window overlooking a garden and hears two damsels, Altisidora and Emerencia, talking. Altisidora sings a love ballad for Don Quixote, lamenting his cruelty and her suffering, and comparing Dulcinea to a fierce tiger. She offers him gifts and expresses her desire to be near him.
Don Quixote, alarmed, believes a damsel is in love with him. He resolves to remain faithful to Dulcinea. He sneezes to let them know he is there. Altisidora finishes her song.

**CHAPTER XLVI: Of the terrible bell and cat fright that Don Quixote got in the course of the enamoured Altisidora’s wooing**
Don Quixote, plagued by Altisidora's love song and his broken stocking, rises early. He dresses in his chamois suit and traveling boots. As he walks through a gallery, Altisidora fakes a swoon, supported by her friend. Don Quixote, believing it's a love sickness, suggests a prompt disillusionment is the cure and offers to sing for her. He requests a lute.
The duchess, hearing of the lute, plots with the duke and damsels to play a trick. At eleven that night, Don Quixote, finding a guitar, opens his window and sings a ballad about constancy in love, stating his heart is solely for Dulcinea.
Suddenly, from a gallery above his window, a cord with a hundred bells is lowered, followed by a sack of cats with smaller bells tied to their tails. The noise and squalling terrify everyone. Cats enter Don Quixote's room, extinguishing candles. Don Quixote, drawing his sword, fights the cats, believing them to be enchanters. One cat clings to his nose, making him shout. The duke and duchess rush in. The duke pulls the cat off. Don Quixote is left with a cut face and a damaged nose.
Altisidora, bandaging him, tells him his injuries are punishment for his insensibility. Don Quixote, sighing, blames enchanters. The duke and duchess are sorry the joke went too far.

**CHAPTER XLVII: Wherein is continued the account of how Sancho Panza conducted himself in his government**
Sancho is taken to a palace on his island of Barataria. Clarions sound. He sits at a magnificent table set for one. A physician, Doctor Pedro Recio de Aguero, stands by with a whalebone wand. The doctor removes all dishes from Sancho, deeming them unhealthy. Sancho, starving, complains. The doctor insists on a diet of wafer cakes and quince conserve. Sancho, enraged, orders the doctor out, threatening to break a chair over his head.
A courier arrives with a letter from the duke, warning Sancho of spies and assassins who want to take his life and urging him to be vigilant and eat nothing. Sancho, believing the doctor is one of the assassins, orders him confined. He asks for bread and grapes instead. He dictates a reply to the duke and sends a message to the duchess and Don Quixote, and then asks for food.
A farmer arrives, asking for a letter of recommendation for his son, who wants to marry a girl named Clara Perlerina. The farmer gives a long, grotesque description of the girl. Sancho, annoyed by his rambling, tells him to get to the point. The farmer then asks for 300-600 ducats to help his son set up house. Sancho, furious, takes his chair and threatens the farmer, believing him to be a tempter sent from hell, for asking so much money from a new governor. The farmer, playing his part, flees.
Sancho then makes several wise ordinances for his government: regulating provisions, setting prices for shoes and wages, prohibiting lewd songs, requiring authentic proof for blind men's miracle songs, and creating an alguacil for the poor. These become "The constitutions of the great governor Sancho Panza."

**CHAPTER XLVIII: Of what befell Don Quixote with Doña Rodriguez, the duchess’s duenna, together with other occurrences worthy of record and eternal remembrance**
Don Quixote, recovering from his cat scratches, lies awake. He hears someone opening his door and assumes Altisidora is coming to tempt him. He reiterates his fidelity to Dulcinea. Doña Rodriguez, the duenna, enters, carrying a candle, with spectacles, and veiled. Don Quixote, mistaking her for a witch, crosses himself. She is also terrified by his appearance.
Doña Rodriguez identifies herself as the duenna of honor and states she has a grievance for him to redress. Don Quixote, assuming it's a love message, warns her he is unavailable due to Dulcinea. Doña Rodriguez assures him her purpose is not love. She lights her candle and sits.
Don Quixote muses on duennas, concluding they are undesirable and that he is being tempted. He tries to close the door, but Doña Rodriguez returns. Both are startled again. Don Quixote, suspicious, asks for security from her. She asks from whom. He replies, from her, given the hour and secluded room. He takes her hand, commending himself to his own continence and her venerable appearance.
Doña Rodriguez then tells her story: she is a high-born Asturian, forced by poverty to become a seamstress. She married an esquire, who died. Her daughter grew up beautiful and accomplished. The son of a rich farmer seduced her daughter under promise of marriage but now refuses to keep his word. The duke refuses to intervene due to the farmer's wealth. She asks Don Quixote to redress this wrong. She then disparages Altisidora, calling her forward and having bad breath, and reveals that the duchess has issues on her legs.
Don Quixote expresses amazement at the duchess having issues. Suddenly, the door bursts open, and Doña Rodriguez's candle falls. She is seized and beaten, while Don Quixote is pinched. They are assailed in silence. The attackers flee. Doña Rodriguez leaves, bemoaning her fate. Don Quixote remains, sore and puzzled.

**CHAPTER XLIX: Of what happened Sancho in making the round of his island**
Sancho, still angry about the farmer's attempted trickery, reflects on the pressures of governing. He reaffirms that judges should be made of "brass" to withstand applicants' importunities. He again complains about Doctor Pedro Recio's hunger diet. He resolves to purge the island of idlers and protect husbandmen and the virtuous. The majordomo praises Sancho's wisdom.
That night, on his rounds, Sancho encounters two men fighting. One claims the other won money unfairly at gambling and refused to give him a share for "watching fair play." Sancho orders the winner to give the complainant 100 reals and 30 for prisoners, and banishes the complainant for ten years for idleness. He resolves to close all gambling houses.
A tipstaff brings a young man arrested for running away from officers. The youth jokes with Sancho. Sancho, realizing he can't force the youth to sleep, releases him.
Two tipstaffs then bring a woman in man's clothes. She is very beautiful. Sancho questions her. She says she is the daughter of Diego de la Llana and ran away, disguised as a man, with her brother to see the world out of curiosity. Her brother, also disguised as a woman, is then brought in. Sancho, realizing their story, dismisses them with a warning.
The head-carver, smitten by the girl's beauty, resolves to ask her father for her hand. Sancho considers marrying the boy to his daughter Sanchica. The night's round ends. The next day, Sancho's government ends, as will be seen.

**CHAPTER L: Wherein is set forth who the enchanters and executioners were who flogged the duenna and pinched Don Quixote, and also what befell the page who carried the letter to Teresa Panza, Sancho Panza’s wife**
The duchess and Altisidora, having secretly observed Doña Rodriguez's visit to Don Quixote (and heard her reveal the duchess's issues), were the ones who orchestrated the beating of the duenna and the pinching of Don Quixote, as revenge.
The page who played Dulcinea's role in the disenchantment prank is sent to Teresa Panza with Sancho's letter and a present from the duchess. The page finds Sanchica, Sancho's daughter, washing clothes. Sanchica leads him home. Teresa Panza, a strong country woman, is amazed to hear Sancho is a governor. The page kneels before her and presents the letters and a string of coral beads. Teresa, unable to read, has the page read the letters aloud.
Teresa's letter to the duchess expresses her happiness and disbelief, saying she wouldn't have believed it without the gifts. She asks for money for court expenses and promises to send acorns. She also notes village gossip and Sanchica's lace-making.
Teresa's letter to Sancho expresses her joy and fears, mentioning Doctor Pedro Recio and his hunger diet. She is concerned about Sancho's safety and his lack of payment. She discusses the gossip in the village, including the painter who married La Berrueca, Pedro Lobo's son becoming a priest, and Minguilla suing him for breach of promise. She asks about his government and her coming to court.
The letters are received with amusement. The page also recounts his adventures in Sancho's village to the duchess.

**CHAPTER LI: Of the progress of Sancho’s government, and other such entertaining matters**
Sancho, after a night of governing, breakfasts on conserve and cold water, as prescribed by Doctor Pedro Recio, who claims light diet sharpens wits.
Sancho hears a complicated case about a bridge, a gallows, and a law: anyone crossing must swear where they are going. If they swear truly, they pass; if falsely, they are hanged. A man swears he is going to die on the gallows. The judges are stumped. Sancho's solution: pass the part that swore truly, hang the part that lied, meaning the man must be set free because to hang him would make his oath true, and thus he should pass. He cites Don Quixote's advice to lean towards mercy in doubtful cases. All praise his wisdom.
Sancho receives a letter from Don Quixote, praising his good sense but advising him to dress appropriately, be civil, ensure abundant food, make few but effective proclamations, visit prisons and markets, and avoid covetousness, womanizing, and gluttony. Don Quixote also tells him he was scratched and suspects the majordomo (Trifaldi) was involved. He mentions his intention to quit his idle life.
Sancho dictates a reply to Don Quixote, complaining of hunger and Doctor Recio's diet. He mentions the warning about spies and assassins. He denies handling dues or bribes, contrary to island custom. He recounts the episode of the disguised brother and sister. He describes his market visits, confiscating mixed nuts from a stall-keeper. He sends regards to the duchess and Don Quixote. He also asks about the "scratching."
Sancho then draws up ordinances for his island: no provision hucksters, declare wine origin, reduce prices for shoes, fix servants' wages, prohibit lewd songs, require proof for blind men's miracle songs, and appoint a poor-alguacil to verify poverty. These become "The constitutions of the great governor Sancho Panza."

**CHAPTER LII: Wherein is related the adventure of the second distressed or afflicted duenna, otherwise called Doña Rodriguez**
Don Quixote, recovered from his cat scratches, plans to leave for Saragossa for jousts. At dinner, Doña Rodriguez and her daughter, both in mourning, enter the hall. Doña Rodriguez kneels before Don Quixote, kissing his feet and crying. The duke and duchess are puzzled. Doña Rodriguez explains she is the distressed duenna and her daughter was deceived by a rich farmer's son who promised marriage and then abandoned her. She complains the duke won't help her, as the farmer is wealthy. She asks Don Quixote to challenge the rustic.
Don Quixote agrees, promising to chastise the proud and help the distressed. The duke offers to arrange the challenge in his castle, fixing six days hence. Don Quixote accepts the challenge, throwing down his glove. The duennas then formally place their claim with Don Quixote.
To amuse himself, the page who carried letters to Teresa Panza returns. The duchess reads Teresa's letter, which is full of village gossip and details about her excitement for Sancho's government and her plans to go to court in a coach. The duchess reads Sancho's letter to Teresa, where Sancho confirms his government and mentions his hunger and the doctor. The letters are greatly enjoyed, though they raise doubts about Sancho's simplicity. The page explains the duchess is very unassuming and might ask a peasant for a comb. Sanchica asks if her father wears trunk-hose. The curate and bachelor recognize the page's waggishness. Teresa declares her intention to dress in a hooped petticoat and set a coach. Sanchica supports her. The curate and bachelor don't believe Sancho is really a governor. The page insists it is true. The curate accepts the page for penance. The bachelor offers to write letters for Teresa, but she gives a penman acolyte cakes and eggs to write for her.

**CHAPTER LIII: Of the troublous end and termination Sancho Panza’s government came to**
On the seventh night of his government, Sancho is woken by a clamor of bells and shouting. Twenty men with torches and swords rush into his room, shouting "To arms! The enemy is in the island!" They demand he lead them. Sancho, confused, says Don Quixote should handle arms. They arm Sancho with two large shields, front and back, tying him up so he cannot move his knees, and give him a lance. They order him to march.
Sancho, unable to move, falls. The pranksters extinguish their torches and trample on Sancho, slashing at his shields, shouting battle orders. Sancho, terrified, believes he's being crushed. He prays for the island to be lost. Suddenly, he hears shouts of "Victory! The enemy retreats!" They help him up. Sancho, bruised, asks for wine.
Sancho then declares he is leaving the government. He goes to Dapple in the stable, embraces him, and laments the miseries of ambition and power. He saddles Dapple himself. He tells the majordomo and others that he was not born to govern, prefers plowing and digging, and would rather be free and eat gazpacho than be under the constraint of government. He states he came naked to the government and leaves naked.
Doctor Recio offers him a draught and promises better food if he stays. Sancho refuses, saying the jokes won't pass a second time. He insists he is a "Panza" and obstinate. He leaves the "ant's wings" (ambition) in the stable and wants to return to the ground. The majordomo demands an account of his ten days of government. Sancho refuses, saying only the duke can demand it. Doctor Recio agrees Sancho should leave. They all embrace him. Sancho leaves, admired for his resolution.

**CHAPTER LIV: Which deals with matters relating to this history and no other**
The duke and duchess decide to proceed with the challenge Don Quixote gave on behalf of Doña Rodriguez's daughter. They substitute a lacquey, Tosilos, for the farmer. The duke instructs Tosilos to vanquish Don Quixote without killing him. Don Quixote is pleased.
Sancho, on his way back to Don Quixote, encounters six pilgrims. He gives them bread and cheese. One pilgrim, Ricote, recognizes Sancho and reveals he is the Morisco shopkeeper from their village, returned from exile. He explains the expulsion of the Moriscos, his journey through France, Italy, and Germany, and his intent to recover a buried treasure in Spain. He asks Sancho to help him. Sancho refuses, citing his loyalty to the king and his lack of covetousness (having given up a government). He recounts his government experience. Ricote is skeptical about islands on the mainland.
Ricote asks about his wife and daughter. Sancho says his daughter, Ana Felix, was beautiful and wept upon leaving, and that Don Pedro Gregorio (a rich young heir) was in love with her and has disappeared. Ricote suspects Don Pedro went after her.
Sancho refuses to help Ricote recover his treasure. They part ways.

**CHAPTER LV: Of what befell Sancho on the road, and other things that cannot be surpassed**
Sancho, delayed by Ricote, is caught by night near the duke's castle. He and Dapple fall into a deep pit. Sancho, unharmed, laments his misfortune and contrasts it with Don Quixote's adventure in Montesinos's cave. He expects to see toads and adders. He laments leaving his family. He finds a small hole and, clearing it, leads Dapple through. He wanders in the dark.
Meanwhile, Don Quixote, practicing for his duel, almost falls into the same pit. He hears Sancho's cries for help. He recognizes Sancho's voice. Sancho identifies himself as the "disgoverned governor." Don Quixote, fearing Sancho is dead and in torment, conjures him. Sancho assures him he is alive, just stuck in the pit. Dapple brays in confirmation. Don Quixote goes to the castle for help.
The duke and duchess are amazed. They retrieve Sancho and Dapple. A student mocks Sancho's poor state. Sancho defends himself, saying he governed poor and left poor. Don Quixote tells him not to mind others' words. They return to the castle. Sancho explains his resignation, saying the government was too burdensome. The duke and duchess offer him a less onerous post.

**CHAPTER LVI: Of the prodigious and unparalleled battle that took place between Don Quixote of La Mancha and the lacquey Tosilos in defence of the daughter of Doña Rodriguez**
The majordomo recounts Sancho's governorship to the duke and duchess, amusing them.
The day of Don Quixote's duel with Tosilos arrives. The duke, to ensure Don Quixote is not killed, orders the lance heads removed. Don Quixote agrees to the duke's terms. A grand stand is erected. Tosilos, on a Frieslander horse and in shining armor, enters the lists. He is secretly instructed by the duke to yield without injuring Don Quixote. Tosilos, however, is smitten by Doña Rodriguez's daughter, the appellant.
At the signal, Don Quixote charges. Tosilos, instead of charging, calls the marshal and declares he yields, wishing to marry the lady due to qualms of conscience. The marshal is bewildered. Don Quixote pulls up. The duke is angry. Tosilos approaches Doña Rodriguez's daughter and declares his willingness to marry her. Don Quixote declares himself absolved from his promise.
Tosilos removes his helmet, revealing his lacquey features. Doña Rodriguez and her daughter cry out, realizing the trick and accusing them of putting a lacquey in place of the real husband. Don Quixote, however, insists it is an enchantment by his enemies and urges them to marry Tosilos anyway. The duke, amused, suggests a fortnight's confinement to see if Tosilos returns to his "original shape." Sancho insists Tosilos will remain a lacquey. Doña Rodriguez's daughter, undeterred, declares she'd rather be a lacquey's lawful wife than a gentleman's cheated mistress. Tosilos is confined. Don Quixote is hailed as victor.

**CHAPTER LVII: Which treats of how Don Quixote took leave of the duke, and of what followed with the witty and impudent Altisidora, one of the duchess’s damsels**
Don Quixote, weary of idleness, requests leave to depart. The duke and duchess express regret. Sancho, receiving letters from his wife, is saddened that his "grand hopes" are over. He notes his departure from government "naked," but is comforted by the 200 gold crowns given by the majordomo.
Don Quixote, in full armor, appears in the courtyard. Altisidora, feigning despair, sings a ballad lamenting Don Quixote's cruelty and accusing him of stealing three kerchiefs and garters. Sancho admits to having the kerchiefs but denies the garters. The duchess is surprised by Altisidora's boldness. The duke, playing along, demands Don Quixote return the garters or fight. Don Quixote denies the theft, saying the garters must be in Altisidora's hiding places, and attributes the accusations to love. He again declines to fight his hosts. Altisidora confesses she has the garters on, comparing her blunder to the braying townsman. Don Quixote, bowing, departs for Saragossa with Sancho.

**CHAPTER LVIII: Which tells how adventures came crowding on Don Quixote in such numbers that they gave one another no breathing-time**
Don Quixote and Sancho, now free, discuss the value of freedom. Sancho is happy about the 200 crowns he received. They encounter a group of laborers carrying images for a retablo (altarpiece), covered with cloths. Don Quixote examines them, identifying Saint George, Saint Martin (dividing his cloak), and Saint James the Moorslayer (patron saint of Spain). He praises them as knights-errant and takes their sighting as a good omen. Sancho, impressed by his master's knowledge, is glad to have a peaceful adventure. Don Quixote explains that omens are often just coincidences. Sancho asks about the Spanish battle cry "Santiago and close Spain!"
Sancho then talks about Altisidora's enduring love for Don Quixote. Don Quixote explains that love is blind and powerful.
They enter a wood and are caught in nets of green cord. Don Quixote believes enchanters are trying to delay him. Two beautiful shepherdesses (actually disguised ladies) appear, explaining they are playing "pastoral Arcadia" with friends. They invite Don Quixote to join them. Don Quixote is charmed and accepts, identifying himself as the Knight of the Lions. One shepherdess recognizes him from his history. They go to the tents, where a lavish meal is served.
