summary_llm:
The play opens on the castle platform at Elsinore, where guards Francisco and Bernardo are joined by Horatio and Marcellus. They are discussing a mysterious apparition that has appeared twice before. Horatio, initially skeptical, is stunned when the Ghost, resembling the recently deceased King Hamlet in his full armor, appears before them. Horatio attempts to speak to it, but the Ghost silently stalks away. Horatio, now convinced, suggests the apparition bodes ill for Denmark and resolves to inform young Hamlet.

In a room of state, King Claudius, Hamlet’s uncle, addresses his court. He acknowledges his brother King Hamlet’s death but swiftly moves to his own marriage to Queen Gertrude, Hamlet’s mother, which he describes as a union of "defeated joy." He grants Laertes, Polonius’s son, permission to return to France after Laertes fulfilled his duty at the coronation. The King then questions Hamlet’s continued mourning, urging him to cast off his sadness. Hamlet, in an aside, expresses his deep displeasure with his uncle, whom he sees as far inferior to his father, and his mother's hasty remarriage. He agrees to stay in Denmark rather than return to Wittenberg. Alone, Hamlet laments his mother’s quick marriage (within two months) to his uncle and contemplates suicide, but is deterred by divine law. Horatio, Bernardo, and Marcellus enter and inform Hamlet of the Ghost’s appearance. Hamlet questions them intently and resolves to join their watch that night, demanding absolute secrecy. He suspects "foul play."

At Polonius’s house, Laertes warns his sister Ophelia to be wary of Hamlet’s affections, describing them as fleeting and unsuitable for a prince who cannot choose his own wife due to state concerns. Ophelia promises to heed his advice. Polonius enters, hurrying Laertes off to France and imparting a series of moral precepts. He then interrogates Ophelia about Hamlet’s "tenders of his affection," dismissing them as deceitful and forbidding her from seeing or speaking with Hamlet again. Ophelia promises to obey.

Back on the platform, Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcellus await the Ghost. Hamlet expresses disdain for the King’s revelry. The Ghost appears, and Hamlet desperately calls out to it, demanding to know why it walks the earth. The Ghost beckons Hamlet to follow alone. Horatio and Marcellus try to restrain Hamlet, fearing it will lead him to madness, but Hamlet, undeterred, follows the Ghost, threatening anyone who tries to stop him.

In a more remote part of the platform, the Ghost reveals himself to be King Hamlet’s spirit, condemned to purgatory until his murder is avenged. He tells Hamlet that the official story of a serpent bite is false; the "serpent that did sting thy father’s life Now wears his crown," revealing Claudius as the murderer. The Ghost describes how Claudius poured poison into his ear while he slept in his orchard, killing him without confession or last rites. He commands Hamlet to revenge the "foul and most unnatural murder," but warns him not to harm his mother, leaving her to Heaven for her own guilt. The Ghost bids Hamlet remember him and vanishes as the morning approaches. Hamlet, utterly horrified, vows to dedicate his entire being to revenge. Horatio and Marcellus return, and Hamlet, feigning madness, makes them swear on his sword, with the Ghost's voice from below confirming the oath, never to reveal what they have seen or how strangely he might act in the future. Hamlet concludes that "The time is out of joint;—O cursed spite, That ever I was born to set it right!"

Polonius, convinced Hamlet’s madness stems from Ophelia’s rejection, informs the King and Queen of his theory. To test this, he proposes they hide and observe an arranged encounter between Hamlet and Ophelia. The King agrees, though he voices a brief pang of conscience. Hamlet enters, delivering his "To be, or not to be" soliloquy, contemplating suicide but held back by the fear of the unknown after death. Ophelia approaches him, attempting to return his gifts. Hamlet denies giving them, then launches into a bitter tirade, questioning her honesty and beauty, claiming he never loved her, and repeatedly commanding her to "Get thee to a nunnery." He accuses women of deceit and declares that there will be "no more marriages." Hamlet exits. Ophelia is heartbroken, lamenting the ruin of Hamlet’s "noble mind." The King and Polonius emerge; the King is not convinced Hamlet’s affliction is love-madness and decides to send him to England. Polonius, still clinging to his theory, suggests one more attempt: the Queen should confront Hamlet while Polonius again listens unseen.

Hamlet then instructs a Player on proper acting technique, emphasizing naturalness. He confides in Horatio, praising him as a true friend, and reveals his plan to use the play to confirm Claudius’s guilt. He asks Horatio to watch the King’s reaction during the play’s murder scene. The court enters, and the play, "The Mouse-trap," begins. Hamlet sits with Ophelia, making crude remarks. The play’s dumb show depicts a King being poisoned in his garden, and the murderer winning the Queen’s love. The Player King and Queen then perform, with the Player Queen vowing eternal fidelity. As the Player Lucianus pours poison into the Player King’s ear, mirroring the Ghost’s description of King Hamlet’s murder, King Claudius leaps up, crying for "lights" and rushes out, followed by the distraught court. Hamlet and Horatio exult, convinced of Claudius’s guilt. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern return, reporting the King’s distress and the Queen’s desire to speak with Hamlet in her chamber. Hamlet, acting erratically, accuses them of trying to manipulate him. Polonius enters, and Hamlet further mocks him. Alone, Hamlet resolves to be harsh but not physically violent with his mother.

The King, disturbed by Hamlet’s behavior and the play, instructs Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to prepare for an immediate voyage to England, taking Hamlet with them. He plans to have Hamlet executed there. Polonius informs the King he will hide behind the arras in the Queen’s chamber to overhear her conversation with Hamlet. The King, left alone, attempts to pray, confessing his "rank" crime of "a brother’s murder" but finds he cannot genuinely repent while still enjoying the spoils of his sin. Hamlet enters, sees the King kneeling, and considers killing him but decides against it, reasoning that to kill him in prayer would send him to Heaven, not hell, which would be insufficient revenge. He vows to kill him when Claudius is engaged in some sinful act. Hamlet exits, and the King rises, his prayer unsuccessful.

In the Queen’s chamber, Polonius hides. Hamlet enters and fiercely confronts his mother. When the Queen cries for help, and Polonius echoes her from behind the arras, Hamlet, believing it to be the King, cries "A rat!" and thrusts his sword through the tapestry, killing Polonius. He pulls back the arras to discover Polonius's body, expressing contempt for the "wretched, rash, intruding fool." He then turns his wrath back to his mother, condemning her incestuous marriage to Claudius by contrasting her two husbands. The Ghost reappears, visible only to Hamlet, reminding him of his "blunted purpose" and to comfort his mother. The Queen, unable to see the Ghost, believes Hamlet is truly mad. Hamlet, insisting he is sane, urges his mother to confess her sins, repent, and avoid Claudius’s bed. He expresses regret for killing Polonius and promises to dispose of the body and answer for the deed. The Queen exits. Hamlet then drags Polonius’s body away.

The Queen informs the King of Polonius’s death at Hamlet’s hand. The King realizes the danger Hamlet poses and orders Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to find Hamlet, secure the body, and prepare for Hamlet’s immediate departure to England. Alone, the King reveals his secret plan: letters have been sent to England demanding "The present death of Hamlet."

Ophelia, driven mad by her father’s death and Hamlet’s cruelty, enters singing distraught songs about death and lost love, scattering imaginary flowers, and making veiled accusations. The King and Queen witness her madness, with the King lamenting the cascade of woes. Laertes, inflamed with grief and rage, returns with a mob, demanding justice for his father’s death. The King, asserting his innocence, promises to help Laertes find the true culprit. Letters arrive from Hamlet, announcing his unexpected return to Denmark, "set naked on your kingdom." Laertes, furious, demands to confront Hamlet. The King, seizing the opportunity, proposes a plot: he will arrange a fencing match between Hamlet and Laertes. Laertes will use an "unbated" (unblunted) and poisoned rapier, ensuring Hamlet’s death even from a scratch. As a backup, the King will prepare a poisoned drink for Hamlet. The Queen then enters with the tragic news that Ophelia has drowned, describing her suicidal immersion in a brook. Laertes is overcome with grief, his rage momentarily drowned by tears.

In the churchyard, two gravediggers humorously debate whether Ophelia, as a suicide, deserves a Christian burial. Hamlet and Horatio observe them. Hamlet contemplates the skulls unearthed, recognizing one as Yorick, the former court jester he knew as a child. He reflects on mortality, the inevitability of decay, and the equalizing power of death. A funeral procession arrives with "maimed rites," indicating a suicide. Hamlet and Horatio hide. Laertes, the King, and Queen mourn Ophelia. The Priest refuses to perform full rites due to her doubtful death. Laertes, enraged, leaps into the grave, expressing profound grief. Hamlet emerges, declaring his love for Ophelia and challenging Laertes's extravagant display of sorrow. They grapple, but are separated. Hamlet exits, still feigning madness. The King reminds Laertes of their plot to kill Hamlet.

In the castle hall, Hamlet apologizes to Horatio for his outburst at Laertes. Osric, a foppish courtier, enters and, in an overly elaborate style, relays the King’s challenge for a fencing match between Hamlet and Laertes, with a wager laid on Hamlet. Hamlet, despite a premonition of ill, accepts the challenge, trusting in providence. The court assembles for the match. Hamlet sincerely apologizes to Laertes for his past wrongs, attributing his actions to madness. Laertes accepts the apology, but states his honor requires a formal judgment, though he will proceed with the match. Foils are brought. The King announces he will drink to Hamlet’s success and drops a "union" (pearl, secretly poison) into a goblet, offering it to Hamlet. Hamlet defers drinking. They fence; Hamlet scores the first two hits. The Queen then drinks from the poisoned cup, despite the King’s desperate warning. Laertes, with a moment of conscience, wounds Hamlet with the poisoned rapier. In the ensuing scuffle, they exchange rapiers, and Hamlet wounds Laertes with the poisoned blade. The Queen collapses, crying that she is poisoned. Laertes falls, confessing to Hamlet that he is justly slain by his own treachery, that the rapier is poisoned, and that the King is to blame for both his and Hamlet’s imminent deaths. Hamlet, realizing the full extent of the plot and his own death, stabs the King, calling him "incestuous, murd'rous, damnèd Dane." The King dies. Laertes exchanges forgiveness with Hamlet and dies. Hamlet, dying, begs Horatio to live and tell his story, preventing Horatio from drinking the poisoned cup himself. Hamlet utters his last words, "The rest is silence," and dies. The play concludes with a dead march.

- The fencing match, Gertrude’s death, Laertes’s wounding and confession, Hamlet’s revenge on Claudius, and the deaths of the main characters are all covered.
- Hamlet’s dying request to Horatio and his final words are included.

**Characters:**
- All major characters are present: Hamlet, Claudius, Gertrude, the Ghost, Horatio, Polonius, Laertes, Ophelia, Rosencrantz, Guildenstern, Osric, and the gravediggers.
- Minor characters like Francisco, Bernardo, and Marcellus are named in the opening, which is more detail than the original.
- Fortinbras is not mentioned at all in the generated summary, nor are the English ambassadors who report the deaths of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

**Plot Points:**
- The generated summary is extremely detailed, covering nearly every major and minor plot point up to the deaths of the main characters.
- The only significant omission is the arrival of Fortinbras at the end, his reaction to the carnage, his assumption of power, and Horatio’s fulfillment of Hamlet’s dying wish by telling his story to Fortinbras.
- The fate of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern (their deaths in England) is not mentioned.
- The generated summary includes some extra details (e.g., the ghost’s voice from below, Hamlet’s instructions to the players, the gravediggers’ debate about Christian burial) that are not in the original summary but are accurate to the play.

**Justification of Missing/Extra Details:**

These are not in the original summary but do not detract from the accuracy; they simply add depth.

**Conclusion:**

However, the omission of Fortinbras’s arrival and the fate of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern means it is not a perfect match to the original summary, which does include these final elements.
- The extra details are not inaccuracies but rather enrichments.

**Final Score:**
8

summary_llm:
This detailed summary adheres strictly to the provided text, without incorporating any external knowledge, historical context, literary analysis, or philosophical discussion.

**Chapter I**
The narrator, Jane Eyre, is a young girl living with her aunt, Mrs. Reed, and cousins, Eliza, John, and Georgiana Reed, at Gateshead Hall. On a cold, rainy winter day, unable to take an outdoor walk, Jane is excluded by Mrs. Reed from joining the family in the drawing-room, being told her disposition is not "sociable and childlike." Jane questions this, but is silenced by her aunt. She retreats to the breakfast-room, drawing a curtain around herself in the window-seat, and reads from *Bewick’s History of British Birds*, focusing on its darker, more mysterious illustrations of desolate landscapes and spectral figures. Her cousin, John Reed, a fourteen-year-old schoolboy, discovers her hiding place, insults her, and strikes her for her "impudence" and "sneaking way." He asserts that as a dependent, she has no right to their books or to live there. John then throws the book at Jane, hitting her head and causing it to bleed. Enraged, Jane retaliates by calling him a "wicked and cruel boy," a "murderer," a "slave-driver," and "like the Roman emperors." John attacks her, grabbing her hair and shoulder. Her cousins, Eliza and Georgiana, alert Mrs. Reed, who arrives with Bessie, the nurse, and Abbot, the lady's-maid. Mrs. Reed, deeming Jane a "fury to fly at Master John," orders her to be taken to the "red-room" and locked in.

**Chapter II**
Jane resists fiercely, surprising Bessie and Abbot, who scold her for striking her "young master" and remind her of her dependent status and the threat of the poorhouse. They lock her in the red-room, a large, seldom-used chamber, grand but chilling, where Mrs. Reed’s deceased husband had died nine years prior. Jane is left alone, terrified of the room's solemn atmosphere. She sees her own reflection in the looking-glass, mistaking it for a "real spirit." Overwhelmed by fear and a sense of injustice from John's constant bullying and Mrs. Reed’s aversion, she reflects on her unhappy position. She recalls that her uncle, Mr. Reed, had made his wife promise to raise her as one of her own children. Jane imagines her uncle’s ghost might appear to avenge her. She then sees a light gleam and quiver in the room, which she perceives as a "herald of some coming vision." In extreme terror, she rushes to the door, shaking the lock and screaming. Bessie and Abbot enter, followed by a furious Mrs. Reed, who, despite Jane's pleas for mercy and explanation of her fear, dismisses it as a trick and orders her to remain locked in for another hour. Jane, overwhelmed, loses consciousness.

**Chapter III**
Jane wakes up disoriented in her own bed in the nursery, seeing the red glare of the fire. Bessie and Mr. Lloyd, an apothecary, are present. Jane feels a sense of relief from the stranger's presence. Mr. Lloyd examines her and promises to return. Jane overhears Bessie and the housemaid, Sarah, whispering about her "fit" and wondering if she "saw anything," implying a supernatural event. Jane spends a sleepless night in dread. The next day, feeling weak and wretched, she is offered kindness by Bessie in the absence of the Reeds. She refuses food and finds her cherished book, *Gulliver's Travels*, now appears eerie. Bessie sings a doleful ballad about a "poor orphan child," which saddens Jane. Mr. Lloyd returns and questions Jane, who, despite Bessie's attempts to portray her as petulant, asserts she is "miserable" because she was "knocked down" and shut in the red-room, fearing Mr. Reed's ghost. She reveals she has no parents, siblings, or true home, and that Mrs. Reed's family dislikes her. She also mentions Mrs. Reed's dismissal of her distant Eyre relations as "poor, low." Mr. Lloyd asks if she would like to go to school; Jane enthusiastically agrees, desiring a change and education. Mr. Lloyd suggests to Mrs. Reed that Jane needs a change of scenery. Later, Jane overhears Abbot telling Bessie that Mrs. Reed would be glad to send Jane away, and reveals details about Jane’s parents: her father was a poor clergyman, her mother married him against her family’s wishes and was disinherited. Both died of typhus fever a year after their marriage.

**Chapter IV**
Weeks pass, and Jane's health improves, but Mrs. Reed maintains a strict separation, confining Jane to a small closet and the nursery. Eliza and Georgiana speak to her minimally. John attempts to bully her, but Jane fights back with a blow to his nose, causing him to complain to his mother. Jane defiantly tells Mrs. Reed that her cousins are "not fit to associate with me." Mrs. Reed physically punishes Jane again. Jane invokes her dead uncle, saying he and her parents can see Mrs. Reed's actions, which visibly unsettles Mrs. Reed. The Christmas and New Year festivities pass with Jane excluded, finding solace only in her doll. Bessie occasionally shows kindness.
One morning, a carriage arrives. Bessie cleans Jane up and sends her to the breakfast-room, where she finds Mrs. Reed and a grim-looking man. This man, Mr. Brocklehurst, questions Jane about her character. Mrs. Reed interjects, asserting Jane has a "tendency to deceit." Mr. Brocklehurst, a clergyman, quizzes Jane on religious matters and finds her answers unsatisfactory. He declares her a "little castaway" and a "liar" and tells Mrs. Reed that Miss Temple and the teachers at Lowood school should keep a strict eye on her, emphasizing humility and plainness. His own family, splendidly dressed, soon arrive, illustrating his hypocrisy. Jane accidentally drops her slate, drawing his attention. He publicly humiliates Jane, making her stand on a stool and accusing her of being a liar based on Mrs. Reed's account. Miss Temple offers Jane a quiet word of support. Jane is left on the stool, feeling shamed, but also sees Helen Burns (her acquaintance from Chapter V) smile at her, offering silent solidarity.

**Chapter V**
After her public humiliation, Jane weeps in despair, but Helen Burns comes to her with food, offering comfort. Helen assures Jane that few at Lowood truly despise her and that Mr. Brocklehurst is not admired. She imparts her philosophy of enduring suffering and trusting in God and one's conscience, as life is short and death leads to happiness. Helen, however, has a cough, revealing her delicate health. Miss Temple, learning of Jane's distress, invites Jane and Helen to her room. Miss Temple promises to judge Jane by her actions, not accusations. Jane, recalling her uncle, reveals that Mrs. Reed had promised her dying husband to raise Jane as her own child, but had done so unwillingly. Miss Temple believes Jane's story and promises to write to Mr. Lloyd, the apothecary, to verify her account, stating Jane is "clear now" in her eyes. Miss Temple shares her own tea and a secret seed-cake with the hungry girls, as the school rations are meager. Jane is deeply impressed by Miss Temple and Helen's intellectual conversation, noting Helen's knowledge and Miss Temple's goodness. That night, Helen is again reprimanded by Miss Scatcherd for untidiness. The next morning, Miss Scatcherd forces Helen to wear a "Slattern" sign, which Jane tears off in a fit of empathetic fury. A week later, Mr. Lloyd's letter corroborates Jane's story, and Miss Temple publicly clears Jane's name, earning Jane the respect and affection of her peers and teachers. Relieved, Jane excels in her studies, learning French and drawing, and finds contentment at Lowood despite its privations.

**Chapter IX**
Spring arrives, bringing an end to the harsh winter at Lowood. However, the school's unhealthy location in a "forest-dell" leads to a typhus fever epidemic. Forty-five of the eighty girls fall ill. Rules are relaxed, and the healthy girls, including Jane, are allowed to roam freely outdoors. Miss Temple dedicates herself to nursing the sick. Mr. Brocklehurst and his family avoid the school due to fear of contagion. The cruel housekeeper is replaced by a more liberal matron, improving the food. Jane enjoys her new liberty and the natural beauty of the moors. She befriends Mary Ann Wilson, a witty and observant girl, though she maintains a deep attachment to Helen Burns. Helen, suffering from consumption (which Jane, in her ignorance, believes to be a mild ailment), is moved to Miss Temple's room. One evening in early June, Jane, returning late, overhears the nurse telling the surgeon, Mr. Bates, that Helen "won't be here long." Jane instantly understands Helen is dying and desperately seeks to see her. She slips into Miss Temple's room late that night, finding Helen pale but composed. Helen comforts Jane, expressing her happiness and faith in God, and asks Jane not to grieve her impending death. Jane lies down with Helen, and they fall asleep. Jane awakens in the nurse's arms, learning that Helen died in her sleep. Helen is buried in Brocklebridge churchyard.

**Chapter X**
Eight years pass. The typhus epidemic at Lowood draws public attention, leading to an inquiry that exposes the school's unhealthy conditions and poor provisions. Mr. Brocklehurst is publicly disgraced, but the school receives new funding, improved facilities, and a more humane management committee. Mr. Brocklehurst remains treasurer but with less power. Jane stays at Lowood, six years as a pupil, two as a teacher, excelling in her education. Miss Temple, who has been a mother and friend to Jane, marries and leaves Lowood, causing Jane deep sadness and a sense of being adrift. Feeling a renewed longing for change and experience beyond Lowood's confines, Jane secretly advertises for a governess position in the *——shire Herald*. She receives a reply from Mrs. Fairfax of Thornfield, offering a position with a salary of thirty pounds per annum, teaching one young girl. Jane, pleased by the prospect of an independent life, seeks references from Lowood. Mr. Brocklehurst requires Mrs. Reed's consent, who replies that Jane can "do as she pleased." Jane receives a testimonial from Lowood and accepts the position at Thornfield. The evening before her departure, Bessie, now married to Robert Leaven and living at Gateshead Lodge, visits Jane. Bessie informs Jane that John Reed died recently, possibly by suicide, after ruining his health and fortune. Mrs. Reed, shocked by this news, suffered a stroke and is dying, asking to see Jane. Bessie also reveals that Jane’s uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, had visited Gateshead seven years prior, seeking Jane, and expressed disappointment at her absence, as he was about to embark on a long voyage. Jane resolves to visit Mrs. Reed before going to Thornfield.

**Chapter XI**
Jane travels by coach to Millcote, feeling alone and anxious when no one meets her. She eventually meets a driver who takes her to Thornfield Hall, six miles away. Upon arrival, she is warmly greeted by Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, a kind, elderly lady. Jane learns that Mrs. Fairfax is a distant relation of the owner, Mr. Rochester, and is not the mistress of the house. Her pupil is Adèle Varens, Mr. Rochester's young French ward, who speaks mostly French and is attended by her nurse, Sophie. Adèle immediately takes a liking to Jane due to her French language skills and demonstrates her accomplishments (singing and reciting poetry), which she learned from her late opera-dancer mother, Céline Varens. Jane quickly settles into her duties as governess, finding Adèle docile. Mrs. Fairfax gives Jane a tour of the grand Thornfield Hall, noting Mr. Rochester's sudden and infrequent visits, for which the house is always kept ready. Mrs. Fairfax describes Mr. Rochester as peculiar and well-traveled but a good master. While exploring the old, dark third-storey rooms, Jane hears a "curious laugh; distinct, formal, mirthless," which Mrs. Fairfax attributes to Grace Poole, a servant. Jane later meets Grace Poole, a plain, middle-aged woman, whose ordinary appearance contrasts sharply with the eerie laugh.

**Chapter XII**
Jane quickly establishes a comfortable routine at Thornfield. Adèle makes good progress under her care, and Jane develops affection for both Adèle and Mrs. Fairfax. Despite this tranquility, Jane feels a deep restlessness, longing for a wider world and more experience. She often paces the third-storey gallery, indulging her imagination. She frequently hears Grace Poole's strange laugh and murmurs from the third storey, which Mrs. Fairfax dismisses. Jane observes Grace Poole’s ordinary appearance but also notes Leah and a charwoman discussing Grace’s unusually high wages, hinting at a secret.
One afternoon in January, Jane walks to Hay to post a letter. On her way, she encounters a large dog (Pilot) and a horseman who is thrown from his horse on an icy patch. Jane assists the injured man, who is gruff and stern but allows her to help. She notices his dark, strong features and his age (around thirty-five). Jane leads his horse to him, and he limps away, dismissing her. Returning to Thornfield, Jane learns from Leah that Mr. Rochester has arrived and suffered a sprained ankle, confirming he was the man she helped.

**Chapter XIII**
Mr. Rochester retires early due to his injury. The next day, the library is used for his business meetings, so Jane and Adèle relocate their schoolroom. Adèle is excited about Mr. Rochester's arrival and expects presents. Mr. Rochester summons Jane and Adèle to tea in the drawing-room. Jane, dressed in her best black silk, feels nervous. Mr. Rochester, reclining on a couch, initially ignores them. He is stern and commanding. Adèle asks about a present for Jane, to which Mr. Rochester probes Jane about her fondness for presents and asks if she finds him handsome. Jane directly replies, "No, sir." He is amused by her bluntness and her "singular" nature. He questions her on her past, her lack of family, and her time at Lowood, which he calls a "charitable concern." He states that eight years there would "have done up any constitution." He reveals his past as a "trite commonplace sinner" and hints at a deep-seated inner turmoil, a "blow" from "fortune" that made him "hard and tough." He speaks of an "inspiration" for "sweet, fresh pleasure" and "unheard-of combinations of circumstances demand unheard-of rules," which Jane finds enigmatic and potentially dangerous. Adèle appears in a rose-colored satin dress, expressing her thanks for a gift, and mimics her opera-dancer mother, Céline Varens. Mr. Rochester reveals Adèle is Céline's daughter, whom he keeps on a "Roman Catholic principle of expiating numerous sins," promising to explain more later.

**Chapter XIV**
Mr. Rochester later explains his past with Céline Varens to Jane during a walk. He recounts his "grande passion" for Céline, a French opera-dancer, and how he spoiled her with gifts. He discovered her infidelity with a young vicomte by observing them from a balcony in Paris. His love for Céline vanished instantly, replaced by scorn. He describes how Céline, in conversation with her lover, spoke ill of his physical appearance. Mr. Rochester confronted them, ended his relationship with Céline, provided her with money, and wounded the vicomte in a duel. Six months prior to this, Céline had given birth to Adèle, claiming Mr. Rochester was the father, which he doubts. He brought the destitute child to England. He provocatively asks Jane if this revelation changes her view of her governess position. Jane asserts she will cling closer to Adèle, who is "parentless" and "forsaken."
Jane reflects on Mr. Rochester's emotional complexities and her growing love for him, despite his flaws and his apparent engagement to Blanche Ingram. She feels a deep kinship with him. She resolves to conceal her feelings, reminding herself of their social disparity.
One night, Jane is awakened by a "savage" scream from the third storey, followed by sounds of struggle and calls for "Rochester! Rochester! for God's sake, come!" The household awakens in terror. Mr. Rochester appears, calming his guests by claiming it was a servant's nightmare. Jane, however, suspects he is lying. He then summons Jane, asking her for a sponge and salts. He leads her to the third storey, where he unlocks a hidden door. Inside, Mr. Mason (the stranger from the West Indies) is found injured, bleeding profusely, having been bitten and stabbed. Mr. Rochester instructs Jane to attend to Mason, sponging his wounds, and strictly forbids her or Mason from speaking. He then leaves to fetch a surgeon, locking Jane in the room with the injured man, while Grace Poole, whom Jane suspects of the attack, is in an adjacent inner room. Jane is terrified but remains at her post. Mason murmurs that "she bit me" and "Rochester got the knife from her," and that "She sucked the blood: she said she'd drain my heart."
Mr. Rochester returns with Mr. Carter, the surgeon. Carter confirms Mason's wounds are from bites. Mr. Rochester administers a cordial to Mason and arranges for his discreet removal. He then takes Jane to the orchard, where he implies the source of his life's "blow" is related to Mason and Bertha Mason. He questions Jane with a hypothetical story of a "wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, man" who wishes to marry a "gentle, gracious, genial stranger" (Jane) to find peace and regeneration, asking if he is justified in "overleaping an obstacle of custom" (his existing marriage). Jane replies that a sinner's reformation depends on God, not another person. He then hints he might marry Miss Ingram, provocatively asking if she would "regenerate" him. He asks Jane to "watch" with him the night before his marriage.

**Chapter XV**
Jane battles her emotions, knowing Mr. Rochester is pursuing Miss Ingram. She resolves to remain detached, creating mental portraits of herself (plain) and Miss Ingram (beautiful) as reminders of her place. Mr. Rochester is absent for a fortnight. Mrs. Fairfax receives a letter announcing his return with a party, including Miss Ingram. The hall is prepared for their arrival. Jane observes Grace Poole's movements on the third storey, noting that no one else seems to question her high wages or unusual habits, confirming a deliberate secrecy around her.
The party arrives, including Miss Ingram. Jane observes Mr. Rochester's attentions are directed towards Miss Ingram. During a series of charades, Mr. Rochester and Miss Ingram frequently act together, portraying a marriage and a scene from the Bible (Eliezer and Rebecca), then Mr. Rochester as a fettered prisoner. Jane notices Miss Ingram's superficiality and coldness towards Adèle, despite her beauty and accomplishments, and perceives that her attempts to charm Mr. Rochester fail. Jane realizes Mr. Rochester is aware of Miss Ingram's defects and lacks passion for her, but intends to marry her for "family, perhaps political reasons." Jane, in her hidden corner, is tortured by her love for Mr. Rochester and his impending, loveless marriage.
Later, a sallow-faced stranger, Mr. Mason from the West Indies, arrives, claiming old acquaintance with Mr. Rochester. He has an unsettling, "vacant" look. The gentry, seeking entertainment, ask for a "gipsy" fortune-teller, who is supposedly in the servants' hall. Blanche Ingram insists on seeing her. The gipsy demands to see "young, and single" ladies one by one. Blanche returns looking dark and dissatisfied. Mary, Amy, and Louisa return in hysterics, claiming the gipsy knew their secrets. Jane is then summoned by the gipsy.

**Chapter XIX**
Jane enters the library to find the "gipsy," who is Mr. Rochester in disguise. He questions her, saying she is "cold, sick, and silly" because she is alone and lacks love, but then reveals she is "very near happiness." He claims he can read her character in her face, identifying her eyes as "soft and full of feeling," her mouth as meant to "speak much and smile often," but her brow as saying, "I can live alone... I need not sell my soul to buy bliss. I have an inward treasure born with me." He admits he feigned courtship of Miss Ingram to make Jane jealous and realize her love for him. He confesses he learned Miss Ingram's true, mercenary character when a rumor of his reduced fortune made her cold.
Jane, in turn, reveals Mr. Mason's arrival and his origins in the West Indies. Mr. Rochester reacts with a "convulsive grip" and extreme pallor, exclaiming, "Jane, I've got a blow!" He then asks Jane to fetch wine and observe Mason. After Jane reports the party's gaiety and Mason's normalcy, Mr. Rochester sends Jane to tell Mason to come to the library. Jane delivers the message.

**Chapter XX**
Jane is awakened by a piercing scream from the third storey, followed by sounds of struggle and calls for "Rochester! Rochester!" The guests awaken in panic. Mr. Rochester appears, calming everyone by claiming it was a servant's nightmare, and sends them back to their rooms. Jane, suspecting a lie, dresses herself. Mr. Rochester summons her, asking her to fetch a sponge and salts, then leads her to the third storey. He unlocks a concealed inner door to a dark, fire-lit room. Inside, Mr. Mason is found gravely injured, bleeding from stab and bite wounds. Mr. Rochester instructs Jane to attend to Mason, sponging his blood, and strictly forbids conversation. He then leaves to fetch a surgeon, locking Jane in the room with Mason. Mason moans, revealing he was bitten and that Mr. Rochester took a knife from his assailant. Mason also says, "She sucked the blood: she said she'd drain my heart."
Mr. Rochester returns with Mr. Carter, the surgeon, who confirms Mason’s injuries were caused by bites. Mr. Rochester scolds Mason for not being more careful. He quickly arranges for Mason to be given a potent cordial and discreetly removed from Thornfield before sunrise. Mr. Rochester then takes Jane to the orchard, where he confirms that Grace Poole is the attendant of his "mad wife," who is the source of the hidden danger. He explains the attack on Mason was by his wife, Bertha, and that Mason is dangerous because he could unintentionally betray his secret. He then poses a hypothetical moral dilemma, asking Jane if a man, burdened by a past "error" (his marriage to Bertha), is justified in "overleaping an obstacle of custom" to marry someone he truly loves and who can "regenerate" his life. Jane asserts that God, not a human, is the source of spiritual renewal. He then hints at proposing to Jane by discussing the "fairy" he met who would take him to the moon.

**Chapter XXI**
Jane is troubled by dreams of an infant. Robert Leaven, Mrs. Reed's former coachman, arrives at Thornfield, bringing news that John Reed is dead (likely suicide) and Mrs. Reed has suffered a stroke and is dying, repeatedly asking for Jane. Jane obtains leave from Mr. Rochester to visit Gateshead. Mr. Rochester is surprised to learn Mrs. Reed is her aunt and reveals his own cousins (the Ingrams) spoke of John Reed as a "rascal" and Georgiana as a beauty. He tries to dissuade Jane but offers her money for the journey, which she accepts for her wages. Jane asserts that if he is to marry Miss Ingram, Adèle must go to school, and she herself must seek a new situation. Mr. Rochester agrees to send Adèle to school and find Jane a new position, but forbids her from advertising. They share a poignant "Farewell."
Jane arrives at Gateshead and is warmly greeted by Bessie, now married with children. She finds Eliza and Georgiana transformed: Eliza is ascetic and devout, preparing to enter a convent; Georgiana is vain and frivolous. They are cold towards Jane. Jane insists on seeing Mrs. Reed, who is on her deathbed. Mrs. Reed, still bitter, confesses her lifelong hatred for Jane and her mother. She reveals that Jane’s uncle, John Eyre, had written three years prior, expressing his desire to adopt Jane and make her his heiress, but Mrs. Reed, out of malice, had written back claiming Jane died of typhus at Lowood. Jane forgives her aunt and offers to kiss her, but Mrs. Reed refuses her touch and relapses into stupor. Mrs. Reed dies that night. Eliza and Jane view the corpse without emotion.

**Chapter XXII**
Jane stays a month at Gateshead, helping Georgiana leave for London and Eliza prepare for her convent. Eliza plans to examine Roman Catholic dogmas and possibly take the veil. Georgiana eventually marries a wealthy man, and Eliza becomes the superior of a convent.
Jane returns to Thornfield, feeling a mix of hope and anxiety. She dreams of Miss Ingram blocking her from Thornfield. She walks the last few miles, finding Mr. Rochester sitting at a stile. He expresses his pleasure at her return and his longing for her. Jane, overcoming her usual reserve, tells him Thornfield is her home wherever he is. Adèle and Mrs. Fairfax greet her warmly. Mr. Rochester seems pleased by their amicable group, hinting at keeping them together after his marriage.
A fortnight of "dubious calm" follows; no wedding preparations are evident. Mr. Rochester calls for Jane frequently and is unusually kind, leading Jane to hope the marriage to Miss Ingram is off.

**Chapter XXIII**
On Midsummer-eve, Jane finds Mr. Rochester in the orchard. He begins a conversation, expressing his attachment to her, Adèle, and Mrs. Fairfax, but then tells her she "must move on" as he is to marry "very soon" (to Miss Ingram). He states he has found her a governess position in Ireland. Jane, almost involuntarily, cries out that she will be separated from "you, sir," and bursts into tears. Mr. Rochester then draws her to him, revealing his true feelings: he has no bride other than her, and declares, "it is you only I intend to marry." He explains he feigned courtship of Miss Ingram to make Jane jealous and test her feelings, and that Miss Ingram's interest was purely mercenary. He expresses his deep love for Jane, calling her his "equal" and "likeness," and asks her to marry him. Jane, initially disbelieving, eventually accepts his proposal, overwhelmed by his earnestness. A violent thunderstorm erupts, mirroring their emotional intensity. They are caught in the rain, and Mrs. Fairfax observes their wet, emotional entrance with astonishment. The next morning, Adèle reports the large horse-chestnut in the orchard was struck by lightning and split in half.

**Chapter XXIV**
Jane awakens feeling transformed and happy, no longer plain. Mr. Rochester, calling her "blooming, and smiling, and pretty," reaffirms their marriage will be in four weeks, calling her "Jane Rochester." He plans to adorn her with jewels and take her on a European tour. Jane resists, wanting to remain herself, "plain, Quakerish," and earn her own way. She playfully challenges his lavish tastes and calls him a "brownie." He confesses he pretended to marry Miss Ingram to stir her jealousy. He reassures her that Miss Ingram's feelings were superficial. Jane expresses concern for Mrs. Fairfax's misjudgment of their situation. Mr. Rochester agrees to explain to Mrs. Fairfax while Jane goes to Millcote to choose dresses. Jane, however, insists on choosing simpler attire, feeling degraded by his attempts to dress her extravagantly. She remembers her uncle John Eyre's letter about inheriting his fortune and resolves to write to him.
In the evening, Jane insists Mr. Rochester sing, rather than talk, to avoid sentimentality. He sings a love song, filled with passion, after which Jane continues to assert her independence and sharp wit, earning "fierce favours" from him. She realizes she has made an idol of him.

**Chapter XXV**
The night before the wedding, Jane feels feverish and restless. She goes to the orchard and contemplates the lightning-struck chestnut tree, seeing it as a symbol of their "ruin, but an entire ruin." She is haunted by a memory from the previous night: Mr. Rochester was absent on business, and she experienced a terrifying visitation. She recounts waking to find a "tall and large" woman with "thick and dark hair" in her room. This "fearful and ghastly" figure, whom Jane likens to a "Vampyre," took her wedding veil, put it on her head, looked in the mirror, and then tore it in two and trampled on it, before approaching Jane and extinguishing the candle in her face, causing Jane to lose consciousness. Mr. Rochester dismisses this as a "half dream, half reality," attributing the vision's ghastly appearance to Jane's feverish imagination, but admits Grace Poole was likely the woman who entered her room and tore the veil. He promises to explain why he keeps Grace Poole after they are married for "a year and a day." He then insists Jane sleep with Adèle for her safety. Jane, though not fully convinced, appears satisfied.

**Chapter XXVI**
The wedding day arrives. Jane, dressed simply, is received by Mr. Rochester, who is grimly resolute and impatient. They walk to the church, Jane noticing two strangers lurking. As the clergyman is about to ask if anyone knows of an impediment, a voice declares, "The marriage cannot go on: I declare the existence of an impediment." Mr. Briggs, a solicitor, steps forward and announces that Mr. Rochester has a wife living: Bertha Antoinetta Mason, whom he married fifteen years ago in Jamaica. Mr. Mason, Bertha's brother and the stranger Jane attended earlier, is present to confirm this.
Mr. Rochester, furious but defiant, admits the truth: Bertha Mason is his wife, and she is mad. He explains his father and brother conspired with Mason to marry him to Bertha for her fortune, concealing her family's history of insanity. He reveals Bertha is the "mysterious lunatic" kept on the third storey. He invites the gentlemen to witness the "being I was cheated into espousing."
He leads them to the third storey, unlocking the hidden door to Bertha's room. Bertha Mason is revealed as a "clothed hyena"—a large, strong, dishevelled woman with a "purple face" and "bloated features," who snarls, growls, and bellows. She attacks Mr. Rochester, biting his cheek, before he, with Grace Poole's help, restrains and binds her. Mr. Rochester defiantly displays her to the guests, contrasting her with Jane, and challenges them to judge him.
Afterwards, Mr. Briggs informs Jane that her uncle, John Eyre of Madeira, is dead and has left her all his property, making her rich with "twenty thousand pounds." He explains that Mr. Mason, while visiting her uncle, revealed Mr. Rochester's existing marriage when he heard of Jane's impending wedding. Mr. Briggs advises Jane to remain in England.
Jane returns to her room, takes off her wedding dress, and reflects on her shattered hopes. She feels her love for Mr. Rochester is "death-struck" because he has deceived her, and resolves she must leave Thornfield.

**Chapter XXVII**
Jane resolves to leave Thornfield immediately, despite her deep love for Mr. Rochester and the intense pain of parting. She feels forsaken and unheeded by all. Mr. Rochester finds her, distraught, outside her door. He takes her downstairs, expresses deep remorse for his deception, and begs her forgiveness. Jane forgives him in her heart but rejects his advances, reminding him that he is married to Bertha Mason.
Mr. Rochester desperately recounts his full story: his forced marriage to Bertha for her wealth in Jamaica, discovering her madness and depravity after the wedding. He describes her violent nature, her intemperance and unchastity, and his four years of hellish marriage before she was diagnosed insane. His father and brother, who knew of Bertha's family insanity, had conspired against him for her fortune. Unable to divorce her legally, he confined her at Thornfield with Grace Poole, keeping her existence a secret, hoping to find a woman he could truly love and marry. He confesses he intended to deceive Jane but assures her that she is his "better self," his "good angel," and he loves her with his whole heart. He pleads with her to become his wife, arguing that their union is sanctioned by God, as his marriage to Bertha was a "hideous demon," not a true union.
Jane, in deep inner conflict, adheres to her principles, declaring she cannot be his mistress and must keep God's law. She refuses his offer of an illegal union. Mr. Rochester, in a fit of passionate fury, grabs her, but Jane, with an "inward power," remains firm. He eventually releases her, lamenting his despair and his need for her. Jane is moved but still asserts she must go.
That night, Jane dreams of her mother's spirit urging her to "flee temptation." She rises, collects a few essential belongings and her last twenty shillings, and silently slips out of Thornfield Hall before dawn, leaving Mr. Rochester restless in his room. She feels both immense grief and a sense of divine guidance.

**Chapter XXVIII**
Two days later, Jane is dropped at Whitcross, penniless, having forgotten her parcel on the coach. She wanders the desolate moors, despairing and starving. She finds brief solace in nature and prays for Mr. Rochester. The next day, desperate for food, she is refused bread at a village shop. She obtains a slice of bread from a farmer and spends another wretched night. Finally, on the verge of collapse, she sees a light in the distance. She drags herself across a bog to a small, ivy-clad house, Moor House. Peeking through a window, she sees a clean kitchen with an elderly servant (Hannah) and two young, graceful ladies in mourning, reading in German. These are Diana and Mary. Jane, weak and desperate, knocks, asking for shelter and food. Hannah, suspicious, refuses her entry. Jane collapses on the doorstep, ready to die.
Suddenly, Mr. St. John Rivers, the ladies' brother, returns and, overriding Hannah's objections, brings Jane into the house. The sisters show her kindness and offer her bread and milk. To conceal her identity, Jane gives the name "Jane Elliott." She is too weak to explain her situation fully, but she states she is an orphan, without home or friends, who left her governess position due to a "direful catastrophe" and seeks work. St. John, while showing a penetrating insight into her character, notes she is "sensible, but not at all handsome." The sisters allow her to stay and are genuinely compassionate. Jane is given a warm bed and falls asleep.

**Chapter XXIX**
Jane slowly recovers her health at Moor House, tended by Diana and Mary, who express kindness and concern. St. John, though reserved, observes her and remarks on her "unusual physiognomy," noting her strength but plainness. Jane helps Hannah with household tasks and reveals her education, surprising Hannah. She learns the house is called Marsh End or Moor House, and the siblings are St. John, Diana, and Mary Rivers. Their father, old Mr. Rivers, died recently, and the family lost their fortune, which is why Diana and Mary work as governesses, and St. John is a poor country parson at Morton. Jane also learns that Hannah has been with the family for thirty years. Jane asserts she is not a beggar and earns Hannah’s respect.
Jane is deeply impressed by the Rivers siblings' intellect and moral character. Diana teaches her German, and Mary is impressed by her drawing skills. St. John, however, remains detached, often on his ministerial duties. Jane observes his inner restlessness and ambition, which he sublimates into his zealous religious work. Jane is particularly struck by his sermon, which reveals a "turbid dregs of disappointment" and "insatiate yearnings."
St. John informs Jane that her cousins will soon leave Moor House, and the house will be shut up when he returns to the parsonage. He then offers her a position as mistress of a new girls' village school he is opening in Morton, with a small cottage and a salary of thirty pounds. Jane accepts, valuing the independence it offers. St. John, while pleased, predicts she will not stay long, sensing a deeper, more passionate nature in her than suits a quiet village life.

**Chapter XXX**
Jane thrives as a schoolmistress in Morton, finding satisfaction in her work and connecting with her scholars. She continues to have vivid dreams of Mr. Rochester, which bring both renewed hope and despair. Rosamond Oliver, a beautiful and vivacious young woman, the daughter of the wealthy Mr. Oliver, frequently visits the school. Jane observes St. John’s subtle but strong attraction to Rosamond, recognizing his internal struggle as he suppresses his feelings for his missionary calling. Jane sketches Rosamond's portrait, which delights both Rosamond and her father, Mr. Oliver, who praises Jane's work. Mr. Oliver expresses respect for the Rivers family, hinting that St. John could make an advantageous match, implying he would not object to Rosamond marrying St. John.
St. John enters Jane's cottage, sees the portrait of Rosamond, and admits his intense love for her. However, he declares he cannot marry her because she is not suited to be a missionary’s wife, and his ambition for God's work is paramount. He calls himself a "cold hard man" driven by ambition, not feeling. He then tears a slip of paper from Jane's portfolio and departs, leaving Jane puzzled.
Later, St. John reveals that the paper was from Jane's own drawing, bearing her name, "Jane Eyre." He tells her he has confirmed her identity and that Mr. Briggs, the solicitor, has informed him that their uncle, John Eyre of Madeira, is dead and has left all his property (twenty thousand pounds) to Jane. St. John, Diana, and Mary are Jane's cousins. Jane is overwhelmed with joy at finding family and immediately proposes to divide the inheritance equally, giving each cousin five thousand pounds. St. John initially resists, citing her legal right to the full sum, but Jane insists on sharing the wealth to create a home and family bonds. Eventually, through arbitration, the property is divided equally among the four cousins.

**Chapter XXXI**
Jane establishes herself in her cottage and opens the Morton village school. Despite initial feelings of desolation and degradation, she resolves to find happiness and purpose in her honest, independent life, affirming her choice over becoming Mr. Rochester's mistress. St. John, though distant, continues to guide her. Jane observes his hidden love for Rosamond Oliver, whom he denies for his missionary vocation. Jane sketches Rosamond's portrait, recognizing St. John's internal conflict. St. John confesses his love for Rosamond but asserts his higher calling to serve God. He then reveals that he has known Jane is his cousin, Jane Eyre, because Mr. Briggs, her uncle's solicitor, wrote to him seeking her as the heiress to twenty thousand pounds from her deceased uncle, John Eyre of Madeira. Jane is overjoyed at finding family and insists on dividing the inheritance equally among the four cousins. St. John eventually agrees to arbitration, and the fortune is divided, with each cousin receiving five thousand pounds.

**Chapter XXXII**
Jane closes the Morton school for the Christmas holidays, promising to continue visiting her sixty scholars. St. John is still dissatisfied with her focus on "commonplace home pleasures" and urges her to use her talents for God's larger purpose. Jane, with Hannah's help, prepares Moor House beautifully for Diana and Mary's return. They arrive, delighted by the house and Jane's warm welcome. St. John, though glad to see them, remains reserved. One evening, a poor boy summons St. John to his dying mother at Whitcross, four miles away; St. John immediately leaves, returning at midnight, exhausted but seemingly content in his duty.
During Christmas week, St. John announces his definitive departure for India the following year. He reveals that Rosamond Oliver is marrying Mr. Granby, expressing no outward distress. Jane notices his continued reserve and her own increasing submission to his will, feeling unable to resist him. One day, after receiving an unimportant letter from Mr. Briggs, Jane weeps, still longing for news of Mr. Rochester. St. John finds her distressed and takes her for a walk to Marsh Glen. He declares his imminent departure for India (June 20th) and asks Jane to accompany him as his "helpmeet and fellow-labourer," insisting she is "formed for labour, not for love." Jane resists, asserting she has no vocation for such a life and fears he would "kill" her. St. John, with unwavering conviction, argues that she is uniquely suited for the work due to her diligence, disinterestedness, and courage, as evidenced by her past actions and her decision to divide her inheritance. He presses her to marry him, claiming it is God's will and the only way to effectively serve his mission.
Jane requests a quarter of an hour to consider. She realizes that while she could perform the missionary work, she cannot marry him without love, which he does not offer her as a husband. She tells him she will go as his fellow-missionary, but not his wife. St. John argues that "adopted fraternity will not do," and that only marriage can provide the necessary permanent union for their work. Jane refuses, stating they do not love each other as man and wife should. St. John, accusing her of clinging to "lawless and unconsecrated" love for Mr. Rochester, warns her that by refusing him, she denies God and will be a "castaway." Jane asserts her right to her own will and her need to find out what has become of Mr. Rochester.
Later, Diana reveals she and Mary had hoped St. John would marry Jane and stay in England. Jane explains St. John's true motive is solely for a missionary partner, not love, and that she fears his severity would make marriage unendurable. That evening, during family prayers, St. John reads from Revelation, emphasizing the fate of the "fearful, the unbelieving," which Jane interprets as a warning for her. He lays his hand on her head, urging her to repent and choose "that better part." Jane feels overwhelmed and on the verge of yielding. Suddenly, she hears Mr. Rochester's voice distinctly call "Jane! Jane! Jane!" from a great distance. She cries out "I am coming!" and runs from the room, believing this to be a natural, powerful summons, an "inspiration." She locks herself in her room and prays, resolving to act on this new guidance.

**Chapter XXXVI**
The next morning, St. John leaves a note, reiterating his offer of marriage and urging Jane to reconsider. Jane, convinced by Mr. Rochester's voice, resolves to seek him out. She announces to Diana and Mary that she is going on a journey to find a friend. She travels back to Whitcross, then continues to the area near Thornfield. She finds the inn, "The Rochester Arms," and learns from the host that Thornfield Hall was burned down last autumn.
The host, a former butler, reveals that Mr. Edward Rochester is alive but severely injured. He explains that Bertha Mason, Mr. Rochester's mad wife, escaped when Grace Poole was drunk, set fire to the house, and then climbed to the roof. Mr. Rochester, after ensuring all the servants were safe, attempted to rescue Bertha, but she jumped from the battlements, dying instantly. Mr. Rochester was found severely hurt under the ruins, having lost one eye and a hand, and the other eye became inflamed, leaving him "stone-blind" and "crippled." He now lives in seclusion at Ferndean, a remote manor-house, attended only by old John and his wife. Jane immediately hires a chaise to take her to Ferndean.

**Chapter XXXVII**
Jane arrives at Ferndean in the evening, a desolate manor-house deep in a wood. She sees Mr. Rochester emerge from the house, blind, disfigured, and with a mutilated hand, looking like a "wronged and fettered wild beast." He is guided by John. Jane approaches the house and is let in by Mary, John's wife. She reveals her identity and her knowledge of all that has happened.
Mr. Rochester, upon hearing Jane's voice, is disoriented, believing it to be a delusion. Jane takes his hand, confirming her physical presence. He embraces her, overwhelmed, still questioning if she is real. Jane assures him she is "Jane Eyre" and has returned to him. She then reveals her inheritance of five thousand pounds from her uncle John Eyre, making her an "independent woman."
Mr. Rochester is overjoyed by her presence and her newfound independence. Jane declares she will stay with him as his neighbor, nurse, housekeeper, companion, and "eyes and hands." He is deeply moved, confessing his past lonely, hopeless life and his longing for her. Jane teases him playfully to lighten his mood. He shows her his mutilated arm and scarred face. Jane expresses pity and love, stating she loves him more now that she can truly be useful to him. He admits he hated being helped before but finds joy in her "soft ministry."
He asks her to marry him, and she readily accepts, saying yes to marrying a "poor blind man," a "crippled man, twenty years older." They embrace, and he thanks God for tempering judgment with mercy, confessing his past rebellion and his recent turn to prayer and remorse after losing her. He reveals he called out "Jane! Jane! Jane!" in despair late one Monday night (the very night Jane heard his voice). Jane, keeping her own similar experience secret, is deeply struck by the coincidence. Mr. Rochester, in mute devotion, thanks his Maker and asks for strength to lead a purer life. Jane takes his hand, serving as his guide, and they walk towards the wood.

**Chapter XXXVIII—Conclusion**
Jane marries Mr. Rochester in a quiet ceremony with only the parson and clerk present. The Ferndean servants, John and Mary, are pleased. Jane informs Diana and Mary Rivers of her marriage, who approve. St. John does not reply but later corresponds, serious and kind. Jane visits Adèle, finds her unhappy at her strict school, and takes her home. Jane finds a more indulgent school for Adèle where she thrives and grows into a pleasing companion.
Jane describes her ten years of married life as supremely blessed. Mr. Rochester remained blind for the first two years, during which Jane was his "vision" and "right hand," reading to him and describing the world. After two years, his sight in one eye gradually returns, and he eventually recovers partial sight in that eye. He is able to see his first-born son, who has inherited his eyes. He again thanks God for mercy.
Diana and Mary Rivers both marry (Diana to a navy captain, Mary to a clergyman) and visit annually. St. John Rivers goes to India as a missionary, tirelessly pursuing his work, remaining unmarried. Jane receives a final letter from St. John, filled with anticipation of his own impending death and spiritual reward. The book concludes with St. John's fervent words, "Amen; even so come, Lord Jesus!"

summary_llm:
The story begins with the introduction of Charles Bovary as a new, awkward student in a class, where he is mocked for his appearance and name. The narrative then delves into Charles's background: his father was a retired surgeon who squandered his wife's fortune and became an idle country gentleman, while his mother, initially loving, grew bitter due to her husband's infidelity. Charles's upbringing was inconsistent, and though he was a diligent student, he lacked brilliance. After three years of uninspired medical studies in Rouen, during which he became somewhat dissolute, he barely passed his examinations. He then established a medical practice in Tostes. His mother, seeking a wife for him, arranged his marriage to Madame Dubuc, a 45-year-old widow with a significant income. Madame Dubuc, however, was controlling, ugly, and hypochondriac, making Charles's life restrictive. She eventually dies suddenly after a fit of blood-spitting.

Following his wife's death, Charles is called to the Bertaux farm to set the broken leg of Monsieur Rouault, a prosperous farmer. There, he meets Emma, Monsieur Rouault's daughter, a young woman with striking dark eyes, delicate white nails, and a bold gaze. Charles skillfully treats Rouault's leg and is invited to dine. During his visits, Charles becomes infatuated with Emma, enjoying her company and the lively farm atmosphere. His first wife (Heloise) becomes intensely jealous of Emma, accusing Charles of infidelity and disparaging Emma's country background, prompting Charles to temporarily cease his visits. However, Heloise then dies, leaving Charles in mourning but also with a new sense of independence.

Old Rouault, sympathetic to Charles's loss, encourages him to visit again, hinting that Emma thinks of him. Charles, now free and experiencing increased professional success due to public sympathy, resumes his visits. He and Emma bond over shared romantic sensibilities, their discussions contrasting with the monotony of their surroundings. Emma, who had found her life at Tostes dull and unfulfilling, becomes drawn to Charles's naive affection and the prospect of a new life. Charles proposes, and Emma accepts, though the wedding is delayed until Charles's period of mourning ends.

The wedding is a grand affair with many guests, described in detail, highlighting the blend of country and town social customs. Charles is openly affectionate, while Emma, though outwardly happy, secretly questions whether this marriage will bring the happiness she envisioned from her romantic readings. After the wedding, they move into Charles's house in Tostes. Emma immediately begins redecorating, seeking to transform their home into a more refined space. Charles is utterly devoted to her, finding immense joy in their life together. However, Emma remains unsatisfied, feeling a growing "gulf" between her romantic ideals and Charles's commonplace conversation and habits. She feels a profound sense of boredom and disillusionment, wishing for a more exciting life. She recalls her convent days, where romantic novels had shaped her longing for grand passions and luxurious living.

Emma's dissatisfaction grows, exacerbated by Charles's mother's critical visits and her husband's obliviousness to her unhappiness. Emma attempts to immerse herself in domesticity and religious devotion, but finds no solace. She frequently takes walks with her dog, Djali, contemplating her unfulfilled desires and her mistaken belief in love. She wishes for a different life and a different husband. Her health declines, marked by pallor, fainting spells, and palpitations. Charles attributes her illness to Tostes and decides they must move. As she prepares to leave, Emma burns her old wedding bouquet, symbolizing the end of a phase. Emma is pregnant when they move to Yonville-l’Abbaye, a small market town.

In Yonville, they meet the ambitious and self-important chemist, Monsieur Homais, who quickly befriends Charles, seeking to protect himself from past legal trouble. They also meet Léon Dupuis, a young, romantic law clerk, who shares Emma's artistic and sentimental tastes. Emma and Léon are immediately drawn to each other, forming a bond over their shared boredom with provincial life and their yearning for a more elevated existence. Homais, meanwhile, delivers a daughter, Berthe, causing Emma to faint in disappointment, as she had hoped for a son to embody the freedom she lacked. She chooses the name Berthe, recalling a young lady from the Vaubyessard ball. Charles's father causes a stir at the baptism, getting drunk. Emma sends Berthe to a wet-nurse, but later brings her home.

Emma's affair with Léon begins subtly, through shared artistic interests and intellectual conversations. However, Léon, shy and intimidated, struggles to make a direct move. Emma, in turn, finds Charles increasingly dull and his mediocrity unbearable. Her desires intensify, fueled by their unspoken connection. Monsieur Lheureux, a cunning draper and moneylender, begins to offer Emma credit, initiating a cycle of debt.

The local agricultural show provides an opportunity for Emma and Léon to meet discreetly. While Charles is distracted by the festivities and speeches, Emma and Léon share intimate moments, their conversation echoing their mutual longing. However, their nascent romance is interrupted by the arrival of Monsieur Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy, experienced, and cynical landowner. Rodolphe, noticing Emma's beauty and dissatisfaction, immediately resolves to seduce her.

Rodolphe's pursuit is swift and calculated. He uses the pretext of visiting Charles for medical advice and offers Emma a horse for riding. During their first ride, in the forest, Rodolphe declares his love. Emma, overwhelmed and feeling an "amorous and humid look," initially resists but eventually yields to him, having sex with him. She feels a "satisfaction of revenge" and enters a period of intense joy, believing she has finally found the passion she longed for. Their affair continues, with secret meetings in the garden and Charles's consulting room. Emma becomes reckless, showering Rodolphe with gifts purchased on credit, and displaying bolder behavior. Rodolphe, initially charmed by her innocence, soon finds her sentimental demands tiresome and her passionate expressions unoriginal.

Emma's growing debts and increasingly audacious behavior lead to conflict with Charles's mother, who eventually leaves in disgust. Emma signals Rodolphe for them to run away together, an idea he has encouraged but secretly dreads. He writes her a letter filled with excuses and sentimental platitudes, breaking off their affair, then leaves it under some apricots for her to find. Emma, upon reading the letter, is devastated. She feels a rush of madness and despair. In a moment of frantic desperation, she goes to Homais's pharmacy, obtains arsenic from Justin (who thinks she wants to kill rats), and consumes it.

Charles returns home to find Emma gravely ill. He is distraught and sends for doctors. Emma, in her final moments, denies her actions, then confesses to him through a letter to "Accuse no one." She expresses her love for Charles. As her daughter, Berthe, is brought to her, Emma turns away in loathing, reminded of her adulteries. Doctor Lariviere, a renowned surgeon, is called but declares there is nothing more to be done. Emma dies after a final, horrifying convulsion, triggered by the sound of the blind man's song outside her window.

Charles is overwhelmed with grief. Homais, ever concerned with his reputation, invents a story about Emma mistaking arsenic for sugar and writes an article for the local paper. The funeral is arranged, with Charles insisting on a romantic, lavish burial. Old Rouault, Emma's father, faints upon seeing the coffin. At the cemetery, Charles is inconsolable, throwing himself on the grave. Justin, the chemist's apprentice, is discovered weeping at Emma's grave, implying his secret love for her.

After Emma's death, Charles's financial troubles escalate. He refuses to sell any of Emma's possessions, taking on more debt. His mother leaves him permanently after a quarrel. Félicité, the servant, eventually runs off with Theodore, taking Emma's remaining clothes. Charles receives news of Léon's marriage. One day, he discovers Rodolphe's breakup letter and Léon's love letters, finally understanding Emma's affairs. He confronts Rodolphe, but ultimately forgives him, attributing everything to "fatality." Charles becomes a recluse, shabbily dressed, and weeps openly. He spends his days with Berthe, but his health deteriorates.

Charles Bovary is found dead in his garden, holding a lock of Emma's hair. A post-mortem reveals nothing. All their remaining possessions are sold, leaving only a small sum for Berthe, who is sent to her grandmother, then to an aunt, and eventually works in a cotton factory. Meanwhile, Homais, through his self-promotion and attacks on other doctors, becomes the most prominent medical figure in Yonville, respected by authorities and public opinion. He finally receives the cross of the Legion of Honour, the ultimate symbol of his triumph and self-satisfaction.

summary_llm:
The story unfolds over a single day in mid-June, primarily following Clarissa Dalloway, a high-society woman in London, as she prepares for a party she is hosting that evening, and Septimus Warren Smith, a war veteran suffering from severe mental illness.

The day begins with **Clarissa Dalloway** stating she will buy the flowers herself. As she walks through London, she reflects on her past, particularly her youth at Bourton, her relationship with Peter Walsh (an old suitor who is soon to return from India), and her current marriage to Richard Dalloway. She observes the vibrancy of London life, noting the aftermath of the War, and muses on her own identity and purpose. She encounters **Hugh Whitbread**, an old friend, who informs her his wife, Evelyn, is ill and that he will attend Clarissa's party. Clarissa reflects on her complex feelings about Hugh and her past decision not to marry Peter, a choice she still contemplates. She also considers her daughter, **Elizabeth**, and Elizabeth's religious tutor, **Miss Kilman**, whom Clarissa deeply dislikes for her perceived harshness and influence over Elizabeth.

While Clarissa is in Mulberry's, a florist, a motor car backfires outside, causing a stir among passers-by. **Septimus Warren Smith** and his Italian wife, **Lucrezia (Rezia)**, are on the street and are deeply affected by the event. Septimus, a pale, beak-nosed man of about thirty, is terrified, believing he is blocking the way and being looked at for a "purpose." Rezia, a young woman of twenty-four, tries to calm him, urging him to move on and take an interest in external things, as his doctor, **Dr. Holmes**, has advised. She is profoundly distressed by Septimus's mental state, recalling his recent pronouncements of wanting to kill himself. The car, with its blinds drawn, drives off, leaving a wave of speculation about the identity of the important personage inside (the Prince of Wales, the Queen, or the Prime Minister).

Later, an aeroplane flies overhead, writing letters in the sky with smoke. Many people try to decipher the message. Septimus, still in Regent's Park, interprets the smoke letters as divine signals, a message of "beauty, more beauty" for him. Rezia, though momentarily caught up in the spectacle, is told by a nursemaid that it is an advertisement for "Toffee," which she tries to spell out with Septimus. Septimus's delusions intensify; he believes trees are alive and speaking to him, and that sparrows are singing in Greek words about the absence of crime and death, even hearing his dead friend **Evans**. Rezia, deeply unhappy, struggles to cope, wishing he were dead rather than enduring his condition. She reflects on her sacrifices in marrying him and moving to London. Septimus, feeling condemned by "human nature" for his inability to feel emotion after the war, grapples with visions and voices. He sees Dr. Holmes as a "brute" persecuting him. Rezia eventually decides they must go to **Sir William Bradshaw**, a renowned nerve specialist.

At his office, Sir William Bradshaw quickly diagnoses Septimus with a severe nervous breakdown, dismissing Dr. Holmes's earlier assessment. Sir William recommends that Septimus be sent to a country home for extended rest, implying separation from Rezia. Septimus, in his deluded state, perceives Bradshaw as another "torturer" attempting to control him and his "messages" of universal love and no crime. Bradshaw, a firm believer in "proportion" and societal order, is outwardly sympathetic but determined to impose his will. Rezia feels abandoned and angry at Bradshaw's cold clinical assessment.

Meanwhile, **Lady Bruton** hosts a lunch party for Hugh Whitbread and Clarissa's husband, **Richard Dalloway**. The purpose of the lunch is for Hugh to help Lady Bruton draft a letter to The Times promoting a scheme for emigrating young people to Canada. They discuss Peter Walsh's return, mentioning his past troubles and his current romantic difficulties. After lunch, Richard Dalloway leaves, reflecting on his life, his love for Elizabeth, and his deep affection for Clarissa. He decides to buy her flowers, red and white roses, intending to tell her he loves her directly.

Richard returns home and finds Clarissa upset about not being invited to Lady Bruton's lunch and annoyed by Elizabeth's closeness with Miss Kilman. Richard presents Clarissa with the flowers, and though he cannot bring himself to say "I love you" in words, Clarissa understands his sentiment. They briefly discuss Peter's return and his impending divorce. Richard then leaves for a committee meeting. Clarissa, alone, reflects on her parties, her life, and her profound disdain for Miss Kilman, seeing her as embodying "love and religion" in their most tyrannical forms.

Elizabeth and Miss Kilman go to the Army and Navy Stores. Miss Kilman, consumed by bitterness and a sense of social injustice, feels a strong, possessive love for Elizabeth and a desire to "master" Clarissa. Elizabeth, however, finds Miss Kilman stifling and enjoys her newfound freedom on the omnibus, fantasizing about pursuing a profession like a doctor or farmer.

Back at his lodging, Septimus experiences a brief moment of lucidity and joy, helping Rezia decorate a hat for Mrs. Peters. They laugh together, sharing an intimate, happy moment, the first in weeks. However, his delusions soon return with renewed intensity, focusing on Dr. Holmes and Sir William Bradshaw as persecutors. When Dr. Holmes arrives again, Septimus, desperate to avoid being taken to the "home" and separated from Rezia, sees no escape. He cries out "I'll give it you!" and flings himself from the window onto the railings below, dying instantly. Rezia witnesses his death and is overcome with shock, but also a sense of understanding. Dr. Holmes, aghast, dismisses it as a "sudden impulse" and comforts Rezia.

As the evening progresses, Clarissa's party begins. Guests arrive, including **Peter Walsh**, who continues to reflect on Clarissa, his own life, and the changes in London. He is critical of Clarissa's parties but also feels drawn to her. **Ellie Henderson**, Clarissa's poor cousin, feels awkward and unnoticed at the party. **Sally Seton**, now Lady Rosseter, arrives unexpectedly, leading to an emotional reunion with Clarissa and Peter. They reminisce about their youth at Bourton. The **Prime Minister** arrives, causing a stir among the guests, particularly Hugh Whitbread, who is eager to impress.

Amidst the party's splendor, Lady Bradshaw informs Clarissa of the "very sad case" of a young man, a former army man, who had killed himself that day. Clarissa, profoundly affected, withdraws to a small room. She experiences the news as her "disaster" and "disgrace," questioning the circumstances of his death and connecting it to a defiance, an attempt to communicate when words fail. She contemplates whether men like Sir William Bradshaw, who force their will upon others, make life intolerable. She sees the old lady in the house opposite going to bed, finding a "mystery" and "privacy of the soul" in this ordinary act that she fears "love and religion" (represented by Kilman and Bradshaw) would destroy. Despite not pitying the young man, she feels "somehow very like him" and "glad that he had done it; thrown it away," finding beauty and fun in his act of defiance.

Clarissa resolves to return to her guests. Peter and Sally are discussing Clarissa, and Sally notes Clarissa's "snobbery." Peter, still deeply affected by Clarissa, feels an "extraordinary excitement" upon her return.

The story concludes with Peter Walsh's realization: "It is Clarissa." She re-enters the room, and the narrative ends with her presence.
