He dismisses complaints about the stories' length, stating they are for idle women who wish to pass the time, not for scholars. Finally, he defends his occasional criticism of friars, and, with a humorous self-deprecating remark about his "lightness," concludes his work, offering it as solace and diversion to noble ladies.

summary_llm:
Nick Carraway, the narrator, reflects on his return from the East, noting his general disillusionment with humanity, but exempting Jay Gatsby, the book's namesake, who possessed an extraordinary gift for hope. Nick, a graduate of New Haven and a veteran of the Great War, moves from the Middle West to West Egg, New York, in the spring of 1922 to learn the bond business. He rents a modest house next door to a colossal, elaborate mansion belonging to Mr. Gatsby.

Nick visits his second cousin once removed, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy, arrogant husband, Tom Buchanan, at their fashionable East Egg mansion. There, he meets Jordan Baker, a professional golfer. During dinner, Tom expresses racist views, and the phone rings, subtly revealing his affair. Jordan later confirms to Nick that Tom has a mistress in New York. Daisy, cynical and restless, speaks of her daughter, Pammy, wishing she would be "a beautiful little fool." Nick notes the insincerity in her words. Later that night, Nick sees Gatsby for the first time, standing on his lawn, stretching his arms towards a distant green light across the bay, which is at the end of Daisy's dock.

Nick is unwillingly drawn into Tom's world when Tom forces him to accompany him to the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial area. There, they stop at a garage owned by George B. Wilson, a "spiritless" man. Tom introduces Nick to Wilson's wife, Myrtle, Tom's mistress, a woman of vibrant physicality. Tom arranges to meet Myrtle in New York. In the city, Myrtle buys a dog and then takes Tom and Nick to a small apartment she shares with Tom. Myrtle invites her sister, Catherine, and a couple named the McKees. As the party progresses, fueled by alcohol, Myrtle's personality becomes more affected. Catherine tells Nick that Tom and Myrtle are both unhappy in their marriages and that Daisy is supposedly Catholic, preventing a divorce—a lie Nick discerns. Myrtle recounts how she met Tom. Later, an argument erupts between Tom and Myrtle over her mentioning Daisy's name, and Tom violently breaks Myrtle's nose. Nick, disgusted, leaves the party with Mr. McKee.

Gatsby hosts lavish, uninvited parties every weekend, with guests coming and going like "moths." Nick receives an actual invitation to one such party. At the party, Nick feels out of place and overhears various rumors about Gatsby's past, including that he killed a man or was a German spy. He meets a drunk man with "owl-eyed" spectacles in Gatsby's library, who is amazed that the books are real. Nick finally meets Gatsby, who reveals himself after inviting Nick on his hydroplane. Gatsby has a captivating smile and a formal way of speaking. Gatsby's butler informs him of a call from Chicago, and Gatsby excuses himself. Jordan tells Nick that Gatsby claims to be an Oxford man, but she doesn't believe it. Gatsby's butler then summons Jordan for a private conversation with Gatsby. Jordan returns, excited, but swears not to reveal what she heard, only hinting that Nick should call her. After the party, a car crashes, and the "owl-eyed" man, who was a passenger, reveals he wasn't driving and there was another, very drunk, man behind the wheel. Nick leaves Gatsby standing alone on his porch.

Nick details his daily life in New York, his brief affair, and his studies. He reconnects with Jordan Baker and discovers her "incurably dishonest" nature, recalling a past golf scandal. Despite this, he feels a "tender curiosity" toward her. He decides he needs to break off a previous, vague engagement back home.

Gatsby drives Nick to lunch in his cream-colored car. Gatsby, anticipating rumors, tells Nick an elaborate but inconsistent story about his wealthy Middle Western family (from "San Francisco"), his Oxford education, and his time as a war hero, showing him a Montenegrin medal and an Oxford photograph as proof. Nick is initially skeptical but persuaded by the evidence. Gatsby then reveals he has a "big request" for Nick, which Jordan will explain. Gatsby and Nick are stopped for speeding, but Gatsby flashes a white card to the police officer, who immediately lets them go. In New York, Gatsby introduces Nick to Meyer Wolfshiem, who fixed the 1919 World's Series and offers Nick a "business gonnegtion." Tom Buchanan appears at the restaurant, and Gatsby awkwardly disappears.

Jordan then explains Gatsby's "big request" to Nick during tea. Five years prior, in 1917 Louisville, Daisy Fay (now Buchanan) was a popular girl, seen with a young officer named Jay Gatsby. Rumors circulated about Daisy wanting to run off with him before he went overseas. Daisy later married Tom Buchanan, receiving an expensive pearl necklace from him. The day before the wedding, Jordan found Daisy drunk, with a letter, wanting to call off the marriage and return the pearls, but she was eventually convinced to go through with it. Tom's infidelity was revealed shortly after their marriage when he crashed his car with a chambermaid. Jordan reveals that Gatsby bought his West Egg mansion specifically to be across the bay from Daisy and hoped she would attend his parties. He wants Nick to invite Daisy to his house for tea so he can "come over." Nick finds himself drawn to Jordan and asks her to dinner.

Nick finds Gatsby's house ablaze with lights late one night. Gatsby is nervous about the upcoming tea with Daisy and attempts to offer Nick a discreet business opportunity, which Nick declines. The day of the tea party is rainy. Gatsby sends his gardener to cut Nick's lawn and fills Nick's house with flowers. Gatsby arrives, extremely nervous and pale. Daisy arrives, and the initial reunion is awkward and strained, with Gatsby nearly knocking over a clock. Nick leaves them alone for a while. When he returns, Gatsby is glowing with happiness. Gatsby then takes Daisy and Nick on a tour of his mansion, explaining it took him three years to earn the money, contradicting his earlier inheritance story. He shows Daisy his extravagant collection of shirts, which brings her to tears. From his window, Gatsby points out the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, realizing its symbolic significance has changed now that Daisy is physically present. Klipspringer, "the boarder," plays the piano. Nick observes Gatsby, realizing that Daisy cannot live up to the "colossal vitality of his illusion."

Nick learns Gatsby's true history: born James Gatz, he came from a poor North Dakota farming family. At 17, he changed his name to Jay Gatsby upon meeting Dan Cody, a wealthy magnate, on Lake Superior. Gatsby worked for Cody for five years on his yacht, gaining an education in the ways of the wealthy, but Cody's mistress, Ella Kaye, illegally inherited Cody's fortune, leaving Gatsby nothing. Weeks later, Tom, Mr. Sloane, and a woman visit Gatsby's house, revealing their disdain for Gatsby's new money. The following Saturday, Tom and Daisy attend Gatsby's party, but Daisy is uncomfortable with the "raw vigour" of West Egg. Tom suspects Gatsby is a bootlegger. Gatsby later confides in Nick that Daisy didn't enjoy the party and that he wants her to tell Tom she never loved him, divorce Tom, and marry him as if five years hadn't passed. Gatsby believes he can "repeat the past."

Gatsby stops his parties and fires his old servants, replacing them with people connected to Wolfshiem, to prevent gossip as Daisy now visits him frequently. Gatsby, Nick, Daisy, and Jordan gather for lunch at the Buchanan's on a sweltering day. Daisy openly kisses Gatsby in front of Tom and declares her love. Daisy's young daughter, Pammy, makes a brief appearance. Daisy, restless, suggests they all go to town. Tom insists on driving Gatsby's yellow car with Nick and Jordan, while Daisy drives Tom's blue coupé with Gatsby. Tom, driving, reveals his investigation into Gatsby's affairs, accusing him of being a bootlegger selling illegal alcohol through "drugstores." They stop for gas at Wilson's garage in the valley of ashes. Wilson appears ill and tells Tom he needs money to move West with Myrtle, having recently discovered "something funny" about his wife's secret life. As they leave, Myrtle Wilson, seeing Tom in the yellow car, mistakes Jordan for Daisy and rushes out into the road. Daisy, driving Gatsby's car, accidentally hits and kills Myrtle. The car speeds away. Tom, Nick, and Jordan arrive at the scene shortly after. Tom is horrified and takes Wilson aside, denying the yellow car is his, implying Gatsby owned it. Tom then drives Nick and Jordan away, sobbing and cursing the hit-and-run driver. Nick returns to the Buchanan's, finding Gatsby waiting outside. Gatsby reveals Daisy was driving and he intends to take the blame, and will wait to ensure Tom doesn't hurt her. Nick sees Tom and Daisy in the kitchen, seemingly reconciling and conspiring. Nick leaves Gatsby standing alone, watching the house.

Nick cannot sleep. He finds Gatsby still waiting outside Daisy's house in the morning. Gatsby recounts his true past with Daisy, how he fell in love with her as a penniless officer, deceiving her into believing he was from her social class. He acknowledges Daisy chose Tom for his security. Nick urges Gatsby to leave, as his car will be traced, but Gatsby refuses, clinging to the hope of Daisy. Gatsby's gardener asks to drain the pool for the season, but Gatsby tells him not to. Nick bids Gatsby farewell, calling him "worth the whole damn bunch put together."

Meanwhile, Michaelis, the coffee shop owner, stayed with the grieving George Wilson. Wilson, in his distraught state, speaks of the yellow car and reveals Myrtle came home with a bruised face months ago. He finds a dog leash, confirming Myrtle's secret life, and becomes convinced that the driver of the yellow car was Myrtle's lover and murderer. Looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, Wilson declares, "God sees everything." The next day, Wilson disappears, searching for the yellow car and its owner. By afternoon, he finds Gatsby's house. Gatsby, expecting a call from Daisy, is floating in his pool on an air mattress. Wilson shoots Gatsby, killing him, then commits suicide.

The aftermath is chaotic with police and reporters. Catherine, Myrtle's sister, falsely testifies at the inquest that Myrtle was happily married and never knew Gatsby, simplifying the official account to Wilson being "deranged by grief." Nick tries to contact Daisy, but she and Tom have left without a trace. Nick tries to reach Meyer Wolfshiem for the funeral, but Wolfshiem refuses to get involved, sending a letter of regret. A call for Gatsby from Chicago reveals his involvement in illegal bond sales. Only Nick, Gatsby's father (Henry C. Gatz, who arrives from Minnesota), the minister, and the "owl-eyed" man attend Gatsby's sparsely attended funeral. Gatsby's father proudly shows Nick an old schedule of his son's ambitious self-improvement resolves. Nick tries to invite Klipspringer ("the boarder"), but he declines, only calling to ask for his tennis shoes.

Disillusioned with the East, Nick decides to return West. Before leaving, he encounters Jordan Baker, who reveals she's engaged and accuses Nick of carelessly ending their relationship. Nick then sees Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue. Tom admits he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car, claiming Wilson was about to kill him, and that Gatsby "had it coming to him." Nick realizes Tom and Daisy are "careless people" who "smashed up things and creatures" and then retreated into their wealth, leaving others to clean up their mess. Nick shakes Tom's hand and leaves.

Nick visits Gatsby's empty mansion one last time, erasing an obscene word scrawled on the steps. He reflects on Gatsby's dream, connecting it to the lost wonder of the new world. He concludes that Gatsby's dream of the green light (Daisy) was already behind him, a "future that year by year recedes before us." Nick states that they "beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."

summary_llm:
The plot of the provided text, "The Iliad," unfolds as follows:

**Book I: The Contention of Achilles and Agamemnon.**
The war in Troy is in its tenth year. The Greeks have sacked neighboring towns, taking two beautiful captives: Chryseïs, allotted to Agamemnon, and Briseïs, allotted to Achilles. Chryses, a priest of Apollo and father of Chryseïs, comes to the Greek camp to ransom his daughter. Agamemnon insolently refuses him. Chryses prays to Apollo for vengeance, and the god sends a pestilence upon the Greeks.

Achilles calls a council, and the prophet Chalcas reveals that Apollo's rage is due to Agamemnon's refusal to return Chryseïs. Agamemnon is compelled to return her, but in a furious rage, he seizes Briseïs, Achilles' captive, as recompense. Angered and dishonored, Achilles withdraws himself and his Myrmidon forces from the fighting.

Achilles complains to his mother, the sea goddess Thetis. Thetis ascends to Olympus and supplicates Jupiter (Jove) to grant victory to the Trojans until the Greeks realize their mistake and honor Achilles. Jupiter grants her request, which provokes a heated debate with his wife, Juno. Vulcan intervenes and successfully reconciles the divine couple.

**Book II: The Trial of the Army, and Catalogue of the Forces.**
Jupiter, to fulfill his promise to Thetis, sends a deceptive dream (in the likeness of Nestor) to Agamemnon, urging him to lead the Greeks to battle immediately, claiming Troy is ripe for destruction. Agamemnon, though deluded, fears the army is disheartened and devises a test: he will propose returning home, and his chiefs are to stop them.

He gathers the troops and suggests abandoning the siege. The Greeks, weary of war, unanimously rush to prepare their ships for departure. Juno, seeing this, sends Minerva to intervene. Minerva, disguised, finds Ulysses and urges him to stop the flight. Ulysses seizes Agamemnon's scepter and, using persuasion and physical force, stops the soldiers and quells the insolence of Thersites, a common soldier who openly criticizes Agamemnon.

The assembly is recalled. Nestor advises Agamemnon to organize the troops by their nations before battle. Agamemnon agrees. The text then details a comprehensive catalogue of the Greek forces, listing their leaders and origins, including important figures like the Ajaces, Diomed, Ulysses, Menelaus, Idomeneus, and Nestor, noting Achilles' inactive Myrmidons. Iris, sent by Jove, warns Priam of the impending Greek advance. Priam rallies the Trojan and auxiliary forces, whose leaders include Hector, Aeneas, Pandarus, Sarpedon, and Glaucus.

**Book III: The Duel of Menelaus and Paris.**
As the armies prepare for battle, Paris, conspicuous in his armor, challenges the bravest Greek to single combat. Menelaus eagerly steps forward to face him. Paris, however, recoils in fear at the sight of Menelaus and retreats into the Trojan ranks. Hector fiercely rebukes Paris for his cowardice and proposes a single combat between Paris and Menelaus to decide the war, with Helen and the stolen treasures as the prize. Paris accepts.

Heralds are sent to summon Priam to witness the oaths for the combat. Iris, disguised as Laodice, informs Helen of the impending duel, and Helen goes to the Scaean gate. There, she identifies Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Ajax for Priam and the Trojan elders. Priam, Menelaus, and Ulysses take solemn oaths over sacrificial lambs. Priam returns to Troy, unable to watch.

Paris and Menelaus arm themselves. Paris throws his spear first, which glances off Menelaus's shield. Menelaus's spear penetrates Paris's shield and corslet, but Paris dodges a fatal wound. Menelaus then strikes Paris's helmet with his sword, but the blade shatters. Menelaus seizes Paris by the helmet and begins to drag him towards the Greek lines. Venus intervenes, breaking the helmet strap and whisking Paris away in a cloud to his apartment in Troy.

Venus then, disguised, persuades a reluctant Helen to join Paris in his apartment. Helen reproaches Paris for his defeat, but he seduces her. On the battlefield, Agamemnon declares Menelaus the victor and demands the return of Helen and the treasure, to which the Greeks loudly assent.

**Book IV: The Breach of the Truce, and the First Battle.**
On Olympus, Jove and the gods discuss the war. Juno and Minerva insist on Troy's destruction. Jove allows Minerva to break the truce, making the Trojans guilty of violating the oath. Minerva, disguised as Laodocus, persuades Pandarus, a Lycian archer, to shoot an arrow at Menelaus. The arrow wounds Menelaus in the shoulder, but Minerva deflects it from being fatal.

Agamemnon, seeing his brother wounded, laments the breach of the truce and fears for the Greeks. Machaon, a physician, is summoned to treat Menelaus. The Trojans then rush forward, initiating a general battle. Agamemnon, despite his own anguish, rallies the Greek troops, encouraging the brave and shaming the fearful. He inspects the ranks, praising Idomeneus and the Ajaces, and advising Nestor on troop deployment. He initially reproaches Ulysses and Diomed for their perceived inaction, but they quickly assert their readiness to fight.

The battle intensifies. Antilochus kills Echepolus. Agenor wounds Elphenor. Ajax kills Simoisius. Antiphus kills Leucus. Ulysses kills Democoon. Apollo then inspires the Trojans, reminding them that Achilles is absent. Pyrus kills Diores. Thoas kills Pyrus. The fighting rages, with many heroes falling on both sides.

**Book V: The Acts of Diomed.**
Minerva empowers Diomed, granting him divine strength and the ability to distinguish gods from mortals, with a specific instruction to wound Venus if she appears in battle. Diomed slays Phegeus, but Vulcan saves Phegeus's brother Idæus. Minerva and Mars temporarily withdraw from the fray. Diomed kills a series of Trojan warriors.

Pandarus wounds Diomed with an arrow. Diomed retreats and prays to Minerva, who removes the arrow, heals him, and reiterates her command. Diomed returns to battle with tenfold fury, killing more Trojans, including two sons of Priam. Aeneas and Pandarus confront Diomed in a chariot. Diomed kills Pandarus with a spear. Aeneas attempts to protect the body, but Diomed throws a massive stone, injuring Aeneas in the hip.

Venus rescues her son Aeneas, covering him in her veil. Diomed pursues Venus and wounds her hand with his spear. Venus drops Aeneas, who is then rescued by Apollo and healed in Troy. Venus, weeping, flies to Olympus with Iris, where Dione, her mother, comforts her. Juno and Pallas mock Venus, and Jove tells her to avoid battle. Apollo returns to the battlefield, creates a phantom of Aeneas to keep the Trojans fighting, and urges Mars and Hector to renew their assault.

Sarpedon reproaches Hector for inaction. Hector, stung, rallies his troops. Mars and Bellona join the Trojans. Diomed, recognizing Mars, advises a tactical retreat. Hector kills several Greeks. Ajax kills Amphius. Tlepolemus challenges Sarpedon; Sarpedon kills Tlepolemus but is wounded himself. Ulysses kills several Lycians. Hector rallies the Trojans around Sarpedon, who is carried off and healed by Pelagon and Boreas.

Juno and Minerva descend from Olympus in their war chariots, intending to aid the Greeks. Jove sends Iris to stop them, threatening severe punishment. They reluctantly comply and return to Olympus. Jove reaffirms his plan: Hector will continue to triumph until Patroclus's death brings Achilles back to the fight. Night falls, and the Trojans, emboldened, camp on the plain, lighting many fires, determined to burn the Greek ships at dawn.

**Book VI: The Episodes of Glaucus and Diomed, and of Hector and Andromache.**
With the gods largely withdrawn, the Greeks initially gain the upper hand. Ajax kills Acamas. Diomed kills Axylus and Calesius. Many other Greeks slay Trojans. Menelaus captures Adrastus, who begs for ransom, but Agamemnon, recalling Trojan treachery, orders Menelaus to kill him, which he does. Nestor urges the Greeks to prioritize victory over spoils.

Helenus, a Trojan seer, advises Hector to return to Troy. He tells him to instruct Hecuba and the Trojan women to make offerings and prayers to Minerva to curb Diomed's rampage. Hector agrees and departs.

Meanwhile, Glaucus (a Lycian) and Diomed (a Greek) meet between the armies. Diomed questions Glaucus's identity. Glaucus recounts his lineage, tracing it to Bellerophon, and mentions a past bond of hospitality between their ancestors. Recognizing this ancient bond, they declare friendship and exchange armor, with Glaucus giving his golden armor for Diomed's bronze, a significant loss for Glaucus.

Hector reaches Troy, where his mother Hecuba offers him wine. He refuses, stating he is too blood-stained to offer libations. He relays Helenus's instructions to Hecuba, who then leads the Trojan matrons in a procession to Minerva's temple to offer a prized mantle and sacrifice, but their prayers are in vain.

Hector then seeks Paris, reproaching him for his absence from battle. Paris, admitting his fault, states he is ready to fight. Helen also laments her role in the war and urges Paris to return to battle. Hector declines to rest and expresses his duty to fight for Troy. He then goes to his home to find his wife, Andromache, and their infant son, Astyanax.

Andromache, filled with foreboding, pleads with Hector to stay within the city walls, fearing his death and the inevitable enslavement of herself and Astyanax. Hector explains his duty to defend Troy and his honor, though he also expresses his deep love and fear for Andromache's future as a widow and slave. He embraces his son, who is frightened by his helmet, and prays to Jove for Astyanax's future glory. Hector then comforts Andromache, telling her to focus on her domestic duties. He arms himself and leaves to rejoin the battle with Paris.

**Book VII: The Single Combat of Hector and Ajax.**
Hector and Paris return to the battle, reinvigorating the Trojans. Paris kills Menestheus. Hector kills Eioneus. Glaucus kills Iphinous. Minerva, concerned for the Greeks, meets Apollo near the Scaean gate. They agree to stop the general battle for the day and inspire Hector to challenge a Greek to single combat. Helenus relays this divine message to Hector.

Hector issues a challenge, offering terms for the body and spoils of the vanquished. The Greeks are silent, until Menelaus indignantly rises to accept, but Agamemnon and other chiefs restrain him. Nestor then inspires the Greeks by recounting his own youthful prowess and urges them to accept the challenge. Nine chiefs volunteer. Lots are cast, and Ajax Telamon is chosen.

Ajax and Hector exchange defiant words. They cast their spears, which hit but do not penetrate their respective shields. They close in with lances; Ajax wounds Hector in the neck. They then hurl massive stones, with Ajax knocking Hector down with a prodigious rock. As they prepare to draw swords, heralds (Idæus for Troy, Talthybius for Greece) intervene to stop the fight as night falls, by divine command. Hector and Ajax exchange gifts as a sign of mutual respect: Hector gives Ajax a sword, and Ajax gives Hector a belt.

The Trojans joyfully receive Hector back in Troy. The Greeks return to Agamemnon's tent, where Ajax is honored. Nestor advises the Greeks to burn their dead and then build a defensive wall, trench, and gates around their camp and ships.

In Troy, a council is held. Antenor proposes returning Helen and her treasures to the Greeks, but Paris refuses to return Helen, offering only her wealth and additional Trojan treasures. Priam proposes a truce for burning the dead and relays Paris's offer to the Greeks. Diomed rejects the offer of wealth and Helen, asserting that Troy is destined to fall completely. Agamemnon accepts only the truce for the dead.

Both armies collect and burn their dead. The Greeks then construct their proposed fortifications. Neptune is angered that such a monument was built without sacrifices to the gods, but Jove assures him he will destroy it later. Both armies feast. Jove sends thunder and lightning, signs of his wrath, to the Trojans.

**Book VIII: The Second Battle, and the Distress of the Greeks.**
Jove convenes the gods, forbidding any to assist either side directly, under threat of Tartarus. Minerva is permitted only to give counsel. Jove travels to Mount Ida to oversee the battle. The armies clash. At noon, Jove weighs the fates, and the Greek scale sinks. He sends thunder and lightning, terrifying the Greeks, who begin to retreat.

Nestor's horse is wounded by Paris, putting Nestor in danger from Hector. Diomed rescues Nestor, while Ulysses flees. Diomed and Nestor, in Diomed's chariot, confront Hector. Diomed's spear misses Hector but kills his charioteer, Eniopeus. Jove sends another lightning bolt, forcing Diomed and Nestor to retreat from Hector's charge. Hector pursues them, mocking Diomed.

Jove sends an omen of success to the Trojans. Hector rallies his troops, urging them to breach the Greek wall and burn the ships. Juno appeals to Neptune for aid, but Neptune refuses to defy Jove. Agamemnon, inspired by Juno, rallies the Greeks and prays to Jove. Jove sends an eagle as a favorable omen.

The Greeks renew the attack. Diomed and other Greek chiefs cross the ditch. Teucer, protected by Ajax's shield, shoots arrows, killing many Trojans. Agamemnon praises Teucer. Teucer attempts to shoot Hector, but Jove diverts the arrow; he kills Gorgythio instead. Another of Teucer's arrows kills Hector's charioteer, Archeptolemus. Hector, enraged, leaps from his chariot and throws a stone at Teucer, breaking his bow. Ajax covers Teucer, who is carried off.

Jove continues to empower the Trojans, who drive the Greeks back behind their wall. Hector leads the charge. Juno and Minerva again attempt to intervene, but Jove sends Iris to warn them, threatening punishment. They return to Olympus. Jove reaffirms his decree that Hector will triumph until Patroclus's death. Night falls. The Trojans, victorious, camp on the plain outside the Greek fortifications, lighting numerous fires to prevent the Greeks from escaping by sea. Hector addresses his troops, planning to burn the Greek fleet at dawn.

**Book IX: The Embassy to Achilles.**
The Greeks are in despair. Agamemnon calls a council and proposes abandoning the siege. Diomed vehemently opposes this, declaring he will fight even if alone. Nestor praises Diomed's spirit and advises Agamemnon to reconcile with Achilles through gifts. Agamemnon admits his fault and offers lavish gifts: gold, tripods, horses, captive women (including Briseïs, sworn untouched), and if Troy falls, more Trojan women, one of his daughters in marriage with a dowry of seven cities, and equal honors to his son Orestes.

Nestor proposes sending Phœnix, Ajax, and Ulysses as ambassadors. They find Achilles playing the lyre with Patroclus. Achilles welcomes them and offers a feast. Ulysses presents Agamemnon's offer, recounting the dire state of the Greeks and recalling Peleus's advice to Achilles to curb his anger. Achilles rejects the gifts and reconciliation, consumed by his anger at Agamemnon's dishonor. He states he will return home to Phthia and will not fight until Hector sets fire to his own ships.

Phœnix tearfully appeals to Achilles, recalling how he raised him and recounting the story of Meleager, who refused to fight but eventually saved his city, though without reward. Achilles, while expressing affection for Phœnix, reiterates his refusal of Agamemnon's offer but allows Phœnix to stay in his tent until morning. Ajax reproaches Achilles for his stubbornness, reminding him of the suffering of his countrymen. Achilles, while respecting Ajax, remains unyielding to Agamemnon's pleas. The ambassadors return to the Greek camp and report Achilles' refusal. Diomed urges the Greeks to fight bravely without Achilles. The Greeks prepare for sleep.

**Book X: The Night-Adventure of Diomed and Ulysses.**
Agamemnon, unable to sleep due to anxiety, consults with Menelaus, who is also awake. They decide to summon Nestor and other chiefs for a night council. Nestor and Agamemnon find Ulysses and Diomed awake, and they all meet at a council near the trenches. Nestor proposes sending a spy into the Trojan camp. Diomed volunteers, choosing Ulysses as his companion.

They arm themselves. Minerva sends a favorable omen. They proceed towards the Trojan camp. Meanwhile, Hector also holds a council, offering Achilles' chariot and horses as a reward for a spy. Dolon, a swift but unattractive Trojan, volunteers, asking Hector to swear to give him Achilles' chariot. Hector swears.

Dolon sets out, dressed in a wolf's hide. Diomed and Ulysses intercept him. Diomed throws his spear, intentionally missing him. Dolon, terrified, begs for his life. Ulysses questions him, and Dolon reveals the Trojan battle plans and the location of their allies, specifically mentioning Rhesus, the Thracian king, and his famous white horses. Diomed then kills Dolon. They strip Dolon's spoils and dedicate them to Pallas.

They proceed to the Thracian camp. Diomed kills Rhesus and twelve of his men in their sleep. Ulysses moves the bodies and leads Rhesus's immortal white horses away. Minerva appears and warns them to return. Apollo wakes Hippocoon, a Thracian, who discovers the slaughter. Diomed and Ulysses return to the Greek camp with the horses and Dolon's spoils. Nestor greets them, recognizing the horses. They feast and pour libations to Pallas.

**Book XI: The Third Battle, and the Acts of Agamemnon.**
Eris, sent by Jove, inspires the Greeks to battle. Agamemnon arms himself in splendid, divine armor and leads the charge. Jove sends drops of blood from the sky as an omen of slaughter. The Trojans, led by Hector, Polydamas, and Aeneas, meet them. The battle is fierce. Agamemnon slaughters many Trojans, including Bienor, Oïleus, Isus, Antiphus, Pisander, and Hippolochus, driving the Trojans back towards their walls.

Jove sends Iris to Hector, instructing him to retreat while Agamemnon is in his fury, but to attack fiercely once Agamemnon is wounded and withdraws. Coön wounds Agamemnon in the arm, forcing him to retreat to his ship. Hector, seeing Agamemnon depart, rallies the Trojans and leads a devastating charge, killing many Greeks.

Ulysses and Diomed stand firm against Hector's assault. Diomed kills Thymbraeus and his charioteer, then two sons of Merops, and Agastrophus. Paris wounds Diomed in the foot with an arrow from a distance, forcing Diomed to retreat. Ulysses is left alone and surrounded but fights bravely, killing several Trojans. Menelaus and Ajax rescue Ulysses, who is wounded.

Hector continues his rampage. Paris wounds Machaon, the physician, with an arrow. Idomeneus urges Nestor to carry Machaon from the field in his chariot. Nestor complies. Cebriones tells Hector of Ajax's success. Hector rides to confront Ajax. Jove causes Ajax to retreat, sensing divine opposition. Eurypylus aids Ajax but is wounded by Paris.

Achilles, observing the battle from his ship, sees Machaon being carried away and sends Patroclus to Nestor's tent to inquire about the wounded man. Nestor recounts the dire state of the Greeks and Achilles' continued inaction. He urges Patroclus to lead the Myrmidons into battle, clad in Achilles' armor, to frighten the Trojans and save the fleet. Patroclus agrees and returns. On his way, he finds the wounded Eurypylus and tends to his wound.

**Book XII: The Battle at the Grecian Wall.**
While Patroclus tends to Eurypylus, the battle intensifies at the Greek wall. The narrator foretells the eventual destruction of the Greek fortifications by Neptune and Apollo after the war. For now, the Trojans, led by Hector, press the Greeks back to their ships. Polydamas advises Hector to dismount from their chariots and attack the wall on foot, dividing the army into five columns, as the trench is impassable for chariots. Hector agrees.

Asius, however, disobeys and attempts to charge a gate with his chariot, but is bravely repelled by the Lapith chiefs, Polypoetes and Leonteus. An omen appears: an eagle carrying a serpent drops it among the Trojans. Polydamas interprets this as a sign of future defeat even if they breach the wall, and advises retreat. Hector vehemently rejects this counsel, asserting Jove's favor and threatening any who show fear.

Hector rallies his troops, and Jove sends a whirlwind to aid them. The Trojans begin to dismantle the wall. The Ajaces rally the Greeks. Sarpedon, inspired by Jove, charges the wall, making a breach. Ajax kills Epicles, a friend of Sarpedon, with a large stone. Teucer wounds Glaucus with an arrow, forcing Glaucus to withdraw. Sarpedon, enraged, kills Alcmaon and tears down more of the wall. Hector then lifts a massive stone and shatters one of the gates, bursting through into the Greek camp, leading the Trojans who pour in behind him. The Greeks flee in terror toward their ships.

**Book XIII: The Fourth Battle Continued, in which Neptune Assists the Greeks: The Acts of Idomeneus.**
Jove, having secured Hector's advantage, looks away from the battle. Neptune seizes this opportunity to aid the Greeks. Disguised as Calchas, the seer, he inspires the Ajaces with fresh courage and divine strength, then rallies other Greek leaders. The Greeks form a strong phalanx.

Hector charges. Merion's spear breaks on Deiphobus's shield, so Merion returns to his tent for a new one. Teucer kills Imbrius. Hector misses Teucer but kills Amphimachus, a grandson of Neptune. Ajax kills Schedius and Phorcys. Enraged by Amphimachus's death, Neptune further inspires the Greeks. He finds Idomeneus, King of Crete, and urges him to fight, revealing his divine presence. Idomeneus arms himself and returns to battle.

Merion joins Idomeneus. Idomeneus kills Othryoneus and Asius (who had earlier tried to breach the gates in his chariot). Deiphobus, angered by Asius's death, throws a spear that misses Idomeneus but kills Hypsenor. Idomeneus kills Alcathous, Deiphobus's brother-in-law. Deiphobus seeks Aeneas's help. Aeneas, also angered by Priam's perceived injustice, joins Deiphobus. Idomeneus calls for support from other Greek chiefs.

A fierce battle rages around Alcathous's body. Idomeneus kills OEnomas. Deiphobus's spear misses Idomeneus but kills Ascalaphus, a son of Mars. Merion wounds Deiphobus in the arm as he tries to strip Ascalaphus's helmet, forcing Deiphobus to retreat. Aeneas kills Aphareus. Antilochus kills Thoon. Merion kills Adamas, son of Asius. Helenus kills Deipyrus. Menelaus wounds Helenus and then kills Pisander. Harpalion is killed by Merion. Paris kills Euchenor.

The Greeks push back the Trojans on the left wing. In the center, Hector continues to hold his ground against the Ajaces. Polydamas advises Hector to call a council, fearing Achilles' return. Hector, after reproaching Paris for his previous idleness, agrees to the council but first goes to rally his forces. Ajax defies Hector, reminding him of Jove's role in the Greek plight. Both armies shout their defiance.

**Book XIV: Juno Deceives Jupiter by the Girdle of Venus.**
Nestor, alarmed by the battle's renewed intensity, leaves Machaon's tent and finds Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Diomed, all wounded, discussing the desperate situation. Agamemnon proposes abandoning the siege by sailing away under cover of night. Ulysses vehemently rejects this, shaming Agamemnon for his cowardice. Diomed advises that, despite their wounds, they should return to the front to inspire the troops but stay out of direct combat. The wounded kings follow this advice.

Neptune, disguised, meets Agamemnon and encourages the Greeks, promising victory. Juno, observing from Olympus, sees Neptune aiding the Greeks and Hector wounded. She devises a plan to distract Jove. She enhances her beauty and obtains Venus's magic girdle (cestus) of love and desire. She then persuades Sleep to put Jove into a deep slumber after she seduces him, promising him Pasithaë, one of the Graces, as his wife. Sleep reluctantly agrees after Juno swears a solemn oath.

Juno and Sleep travel to Mount Ida. Juno seduces Jove, who, overcome with desire and the power of the girdle, falls asleep. Sleep then flies to Neptune and informs him of Jove's slumber, urging him to aid the Greeks. Neptune, invigorated, rallies the Greeks and leads them back into battle.

Hector throws a javelin at Ajax, which glances off his shield. Ajax then throws a massive stone, striking Hector in the breast and knocking him unconscious. Hector's comrades carry him from the field. Hector is revived at the Xanthus river. The Greeks, seeing Hector's retreat, press their advantage, killing many Trojans.

**Book XV: The Fifth Battle at the Ships; and the Acts of Ajax.**
Jove awakens on Ida, sees the Trojans routed, Hector in a swoon, and Neptune leading the Greeks. Enraged, he confronts Juno, accusing her of deceit. Juno denies direct involvement, blaming Neptune's initiative. Jove, accepting her oath, reveals his full plan: Iris will order Neptune to withdraw, Apollo will heal Hector and inspire him, Hector will drive the Greeks to their ships, Patroclus will fight in Achilles' armor and kill Sarpedon, but then Patroclus will be slain by Hector, and only then will Achilles return to battle, leading to Troy's fall.

Juno flies to Olympus and falsely implies Jove is threatening the gods. Mars, infuriated by the death of his son Ascalaphus, attempts to join the battle, but Pallas restrains him. Juno then sends Iris to Neptune, commanding him to withdraw. Neptune, asserting his equal status as a brother of Jove, reluctantly complies, though he warns of his lasting wrath if Jove does not ensure Troy's destruction.

Jove then sends Apollo to heal Hector and re-inspire the Trojans. Apollo finds Hector recovering on the riverbank, breathing new strength into him. Hector, revitalized, rallies the Trojans and charges the Greeks. Apollo, holding Jove's ægis, leads the Trojans, terrifying the Greeks. The Greeks fall back, and Apollo easily demolishes a section of the Greek wall and fills the trench, allowing the Trojans to flood into the Greek camp.

Nestor prays to Jove, and Jove sends thunder. Patroclus, seeing the ships in danger, rushes to Achilles to urge him to fight or permit Patroclus to lead the Myrmidons in his armor. The battle rages at the ships. Hector kills Clytius, who was setting fire to a ship. Ajax rallies Teucer, whose bowstring is broken by Jove as he aims at Hector. Ajax tells Teucer to use a spear. Hector drives the Trojans forward, reaching the ships and trying to set them ablaze. Ajax fights fiercely on a ship, killing twelve Trojans who attempt to fire it.

**Book XVI: The Sixth Battle, the Acts and Death of Patroclus.**
Patroclus, weeping, approaches Achilles, recounting the Greek losses and pleading with Achilles to either fight or allow him to lead the Myrmidons, clad in Achilles' armor, to save the ships. Achilles, though still angered by Agamemnon, agrees, but gives Patroclus strict orders: drive the Trojans from the ships, but do not pursue them to Troy's walls or engage Hector. Achilles then expresses a desperate wish that all others might perish, leaving only him and Patroclus to sack Troy.

Ajax, overwhelmed by the Trojan assault and Jove's favor towards Hector, is forced to retreat from Protesilaus's ship, which Hector sets on fire. Achilles, seeing the flames, tells Patroclus to arm immediately. Patroclus dons Achilles' armor (except Achilles' spear, which only Achilles can wield). Automedon harnesses Achilles' immortal horses, Xanthus and Balius, and the mortal Pedasus. Achilles rallies his Myrmidons with a fierce speech. He then pours a libation to Jove, praying for Patroclus's success and safe return. Jove grants the former but denies the latter.

Patroclus leads the Myrmidons. The Trojans, seeing Achilles' armor, are terrified and flee from the ships. Patroclus kills Pyrechmes and extinguishes the fires. The Greeks pursue. Patroclus kills many Trojans. Sarpedon, Jove's son, confronts Patroclus. Jove debates saving Sarpedon but is dissuaded by Juno. A shower of blood falls. Patroclus kills Thrasymed and Pedasus. Patroclus then kills Sarpedon with a spear through the breast.

Sarpedon, dying, calls on Glaucus to defend his body. Glaucus, still wounded, prays to Apollo for healing, which Apollo grants. Glaucus rallies the Trojans and reproaches Hector for abandoning Sarpedon. Hector, spurred to action, rallies his forces to retrieve Sarpedon's body. Patroclus and Ajax rally the Greeks. A fierce battle erupts over Sarpedon's body, which Jove covers in darkness. Epigeus falls. Patroclus kills Sthenelaus and Bathyclaeus. Jove fills Hector with dismay, causing him to retreat. The Greeks secure Sarpedon's body and armor, which Patroclus takes as spoils. Apollo, at Jove's command, takes Sarpedon's body, cleanses it, anoints it, and has Sleep and Death carry it to Lycia for burial.

Patroclus, disregarding Achilles' command, pursues the fleeing Trojans all the way to Troy's walls, killing many. He attempts to breach the wall three times, but Apollo repulses him each time, warning him that Troy is not fated to fall by his hand. Apollo, disguised as Asius, then encourages Hector to attack Patroclus. Hector, in his chariot, charges Patroclus. Patroclus kills Hector's charioteer, Cebrion, with a stone. Hector and Patroclus fight over Cebrion's body.

Apollo intervenes unseen, striking Patroclus from behind, breaking his helmet, spear, and armor. Euphorbus, a Trojan youth, then wounds Patroclus with a spear. Hector sees Patroclus disarmed and wounded, breaks through the ranks, and kills him with a spear. Hector boasts over the dying Patroclus. Patroclus, with his dying breath, prophesies Hector's own death by Achilles' hand. Patroclus dies. Hector strips Achilles' armor from Patroclus's body and pursues Automedon, Achilles' charioteer, who escapes with the immortal horses.

**Book XVII: The Seventh Battle, for the Body of Patroclus.**
Menelaus defends Patroclus's naked body from the Trojans. Euphorbus challenges Menelaus and is killed. Apollo, disguised as Mentes, urges Hector to confront Menelaus for Euphorbus's spoils and Patroclus's body. Hector charges. Menelaus retreats, calling for Ajax. Ajax arrives, and Hector retreats, taking Patroclus's armor (Achilles' original armor) to Troy. Ajax then guards Patroclus's body.

Glaucus reproaches Hector for his cowardice and for abandoning Sarpedon's body, suggesting they should capture Patroclus's body to exchange for Sarpedon's. Hector, angered, dons Achilles' armor that he had taken from Patroclus. Jove grants him a day of glory in these arms. Hector rallies the Trojans, promising rewards for bringing Patroclus's body to Troy.

Ajax rallies the Greeks. Ajax the Less, Idomeneus, and Merion join the fight. A fierce battle for Patroclus's body ensues. Jove shrouds the battle in darkness to protect Patroclus's body. Hippothous attempts to drag the body away but is killed by Ajax. Hector misses Ajax but kills Schedius. Ajax kills Phorcys. Apollo, disguised as Periphas, rallies Aeneas. Aeneas kills Leocritus and Apisaon. The battle over the body becomes a deadlock.

Achilles' immortal horses weep for Patroclus. Jove pities them and reinvigorates them for Automedon. Alcimedon takes the reins, and Automedon fights on foot. Hector and Aeneas attack Achilles' chariot. Automedon kills Aretus. The Ajaces arrive, forcing Hector and Aeneas to retreat. Automedon strips Aretus's armor, dedicating it to Patroclus.

Minerva, sent by Jove, disguised as Phœnix, inspires Menelaus, who kills Podes. Apollo, disguised as Phaenops, tells Hector about Podes's death. Hector charges. Jove shifts the balance of battle, favoring the Trojans. Peneleus and Leitus are wounded. Idomeneus's spear breaks on Hector's armor. Hector's spear kills Coeranus, Merion's charioteer. Idomeneus and Merion retreat.

Ajax, seeing Jove's hand, prays to Jove to dispel the darkness so they can see. Jove clears the air. Ajax instructs Menelaus to find Antilochus and send him to Achilles with the news of Patroclus's death. Menelaus conveys the message to Antilochus, who runs to Achilles. Menelaus returns to the battle, urging the Greeks to retrieve Patroclus's body. Menelaus and Merion lift the body, while the Ajaces protect them from the charging Trojans. The Greeks slowly retreat, bearing Patroclus's body, enduring fierce attacks from Hector and Aeneas.

**Book XVIII: The Grief of Achilles, and New Armour Made Him by Vulcan.**
Antilochus brings the news of Patroclus's death to Achilles. Achilles is overwhelmed with grief, covering himself in ashes, tearing his hair, and lamenting. His captive women join in his sorrow. Thetis, hearing his cries, comes from the sea with her Nereid sisters. Achilles tells her of Patroclus's death and his resolve to avenge him by killing Hector, even if it means his own imminent death (as prophesied). Thetis warns him that his death will follow Hector's. Achilles accepts this fate and demands new armor, as Hector has his. Thetis promises to obtain divine armor from Vulcan by dawn and tells Achilles not to fight until then.

Thetis preserves Patroclus's body with ambrosia and nectar. Meanwhile, the battle for Patroclus's body continues near the ships. Juno sends Iris to Achilles, urging him to appear at the trench to frighten the Trojans, even without armor. Achilles, empowered by Minerva, appears on the rampart, his head blazing with a divine light. He shouts three times, and the Trojans are struck with terror, fleeing in disarray. The Greeks seize the opportunity to recover Patroclus's body and carry it to Achilles' tent. Achilles laments over his friend's body.

The sun sets. The Trojans hold a council. Polydamas advises retreating into the city, fearing Achilles' return. Hector, however, rejects this, insisting they camp on the plain to attack the ships at dawn, confident he can face Achilles. Pallas deludes the Trojans into accepting Hector's poor advice.

Achilles mourns Patroclus all night, vowing to sacrifice twelve Trojan captives on his pyre and leave Hector's body to dogs. His attendants prepare Patroclus's body. Thetis visits Vulcan on Olympus, who, remembering her past kindness, agrees to forge new, magnificent armor for Achilles. Vulcan creates a wondrous shield, depicting the cosmos, two cities (one at peace, one at war), cultivated fields, a herd attacked by lions, a sheepfold, and a dancing circle. He also forges a cuirass, greaves, and a helmet. Thetis takes the blazing new armor and flies back to Achilles.

**Book XIX: The Reconciliation of Achilles and Agamemnon.**
Thetis delivers the divine armor to Achilles. Achilles is filled with awe and renewed fury. Thetis assures him she will preserve Patroclus's body from decay. Achilles then assembles the Greeks and publicly renounces his anger against Agamemnon, expressing deep regret for the quarrel and its role in Patroclus's death. He declares his immediate readiness for battle.

Agamemnon, in turn, accepts responsibility, blaming Jove and Ate (delusion) for his actions. He reaffirms his offer of lavish gifts and pledges that Briseïs was untouched. Achilles accepts the reconciliation but insists on fighting immediately, refusing to eat or rest until he has avenged Patroclus. Ulysses urges Achilles to allow the troops to refresh themselves before battle, emphasizing the need for strength in prolonged combat. He also insists on a public ceremony for the gifts and Agamemnon's oath to ensure the reconciliation is witnessed by all.

Agamemnon agrees to Ulysses's advice. The gifts are brought forth, and Agamemnon publicly takes an oath that Briseïs was untouched. Achilles, still grieving, refuses to eat, vowing to fight until his rage is sated with blood. Jove sends Minerva to infuse ambrosia and nectar into Achilles, strengthening him.

The Greek army arms itself. Achilles dons his new, blazing armor. He mounts his chariot, driven by Automedon, and addresses his immortal horses, Xanthus and Balius, reproaching them for Patroclus's death. Xanthus, miraculously, speaks, informing Achilles that his death is decreed by fate and a god, not by the horses' fault. Achilles, undeterred by the prophecy, rushes to battle.

**Book XX: The Battle of the Gods, and the Acts of Achilles.**
Jove calls a council of the gods, granting them permission to openly aid either side, fearing Achilles' unchecked rage would prematurely destroy Troy. The gods descend to the battlefield, intensifying the conflict. Pluto trembles in the underworld, fearing the earth's tremors. The divine powers engage in their own battles: Apollo against Neptune, Mars against Pallas, Latona against Hermes, Diana against Juno, and Vulcan against the river Xanthus (Scamander).

Achilles, consumed by rage, seeks Hector. Apollo encourages Aeneas to confront Achilles. Aeneas, recounting a past defeat by Achilles, is emboldened by Apollo's words and his divine lineage. Juno, seeing Aeneas's advance, expresses concern for his fate. Neptune, however, intervenes, creating a mist to shield Achilles' eyes, extracting his spear from Aeneas's shield, and whisking Aeneas away to the rear of the battle, warning him to avoid Achilles until his fated death. Achilles is surprised to find his spear returned and Aeneas gone, realizing a god intervened.

Achilles then rallies the Greeks and unleashes his fury on the Trojan ranks. He kills Iphytion, Demoleon, Hippodamas, Laoganus, Dardanus, Alastor, Mulius, Echeclus, Deucalion, Rhigmas, and Rhigmas's charioteer, driving his chariot over the bodies and drenching the field in blood. Hector, warned by Apollo to avoid single combat with Achilles, remains within the mingled ranks.

**Book XXI: The Battle in the River Scamander.**
The Trojans flee Achilles, some towards the city, others towards the river Scamander (Xanthus). Juno covers those fleeing to the city in a mist. Achilles pursues the rest to the river, slaughtering many. He takes twelve Trojan youths alive as captives, destined for sacrifice to Patroclus.

Achilles encounters Lycaon, a son of Priam whom he had previously captured and sold into slavery. Lycaon begs for mercy, but Achilles, hardened by Patroclus's death, refuses and kills him, casting his body into the river for the fish. Achilles then fights Asteropeus, a Paeonian chief and grandson of the river Axius. Asteropeus wounds Achilles' elbow, but Achilles kills him with his sword and boasts of his superior divine lineage.

The Scamander river, choked with Trojan bodies, speaks to Achilles in human form, demanding he cease defiling its waters. Achilles agrees to stop fighting in the river but vows to continue until Troy is taken and Hector is slain. He then charges the Trojans again, causing the river to swell in rage and attack him with its waves, throwing bodies and rocks. Achilles is swept away, but Neptune and Pallas appear in human form, reassuring him and instructing him to fight on.

Scamander then calls upon Simois to join forces and overwhelm Achilles. The two rivers unleash a massive flood. Juno, seeing Achilles in danger, calls on Vulcan. Vulcan unleashes his fire, burning the dead bodies, drying the land, and causing the river to boil and evaporate. Scamander pleads with Vulcan and Juno to stop, promising to cease aiding Troy. Juno commands Vulcan to extinguish his flames. The river subsides.

The other gods resume their conflicts. Pallas strikes Mars with a huge stone, knocking him down. Venus helps Mars away, but Pallas lightly strikes Venus as well, knocking both gods down. Neptune challenges Apollo, recalling Troy's treachery. Apollo refuses to fight over mortals and withdraws. Diana upbraids Apollo. Juno then attacks Diana, disarming and striking her. Diana flees to Jove, complaining. Latona gathers Diana's weapons. Hermes declines to fight Latona. Apollo enters Troy to protect its walls.

Achilles continues his slaughter, driving the remaining Trojans towards the city. Priam, from the walls, sees the rout and orders the gates opened to let the Trojans in. Apollo rushes forth to cover the retreat and, disguised as Agenor, challenges Achilles, allowing the rest of the Trojans to escape into the city while Achilles pursues the disguised god.

**Book XXII: The Death of Hector.**
All Trojans flee into the city except Hector, who remains outside the Scaean gate, determined to face Achilles. Apollo (still disguised as Agenor) reveals himself to Achilles, mocking him for chasing a god while the Trojans escaped. Achilles, angered, turns towards Troy. Priam and Hecuba, from the city walls, desperately plead with Hector to come inside, foreseeing his death. Hector, consumed by shame and pride, rejects their pleas, resolves to fight, dismissing retreat or parley.

Achilles approaches, shining terribly. Hector, overcome by terror, flees. Achilles pursues him three times around the walls of Troy. The gods watch. Jove weighs their fates in his golden scales; Hector's scale sinks. Apollo abandons Hector. Pallas, disguised as Deiphobus (Hector's brother), appears beside Hector, encouraging him to stand and fight Achilles. Hector, relieved, agrees and proposes an oath for honorable treatment of the vanquished.

Achilles fiercely rejects any pact, vowing merciless vengeance for Patroclus. He throws his spear. Hector ducks, and the spear flies past. Pallas retrieves the spear and returns it to Achilles, unseen by Hector. Hector, thinking he has missed, throws his spear at Achilles, but it bounces off the divine shield. Hector calls for Deiphobus, but realizes he is alone and has been deceived. Accepting his fate, he draws his sword and charges Achilles.

Achilles, with his Pelian spear, strikes Hector in the throat, his only vulnerable spot. Hector falls, mortally wounded. Achilles boasts over him. Hector, dying, begs Achilles to return his body for burial. Achilles refuses, declaring Hector's body will be devoured by dogs and birds. Hector, with his last breath, prophesies Achilles' own death by Paris and Apollo at the Scaean gate. Hector dies, his soul departing to the underworld.

Achilles strips Hector's armor, and other Greeks gather to mutilate the body. Achilles then performs a cruel act of vengeance: he pierces Hector's ankles, binds them with thongs, and ties them to his chariot. He mounts his chariot and drags Hector's body three times around Troy's walls, in full view of Priam, Hecuba, and the horrified Trojans. Priam and Hecuba lament uncontrollably. Andromache, unaware, hears the wailing and rushes to the walls, where she sees Hector's body being dragged and faints. Upon recovering, she mourns her husband and fears for their son, Astyanax, who will now be an orphan and slave.

**Book XXIII: Funeral Games in Honour of Patroclus.**
The Greeks return from battle, mourning Patroclus. Achilles gathers his Myrmidons, and they drive their chariots three times around Patroclus's body, lamenting. Achilles reaffirms his vow to sacrifice twelve Trojan captives on the pyre and give Hector's body to dogs. He then invites his men to a funeral feast. Achilles refuses to eat or wash until Patroclus is buried and instructs Agamemnon to prepare a pyre.

Achilles sleeps on the shore. The ghost of Patroclus appears to him, pleading for burial rites so his soul can find rest and asking for their bones to be mixed in a single urn. Achilles attempts to embrace the ghost, but it vanishes. Achilles awakens, realizing the survival of the soul after death.

The next morning, the Greeks gather wood from Mount Ida and build a large funeral pyre. The funeral procession takes place, with Achilles leading, supporting Patroclus's head. Achilles cuts a lock of his hair, dedicated to the river Sperchius, and places it on Patroclus's hand. They place the body on the pyre, along with slain sheep, oxen, goats, four horses, and two dogs. Achilles then sacrifices twelve Trojan captives on the pyre. He calls out to Patroclus's ghost. Venus and Apollo protect Hector's body from mutilation and decay.

The pyre does not ignite. Achilles prays to the Winds, and Iris, sent by Achilles, summons Zephyr and Boreas. The Winds arrive, igniting the pyre. The fire burns all night, with Achilles mourning beside it. At dawn, the flames subside. Achilles, exhausted, gives instructions to collect Patroclus's bones in a golden urn and build a tomb.

Achilles then announces funeral games with prizes:
*   **Chariot Race:** Diomed wins (with Minerva's aid, after Apollo interferes with Eumelus and Pallas causes Eumelus to crash). Antilochus gets second (by cutting off Menelaus). Menelaus is third. Merion is fourth. Eumelus is last, but Achilles gives him a separate gift. Menelaus and Antilochus reconcile after a dispute over a prize. Nestor receives an honorary gift from Achilles.
*   **Caestus Fight (boxing):** Epeüs defeats Euryalus with a single powerful blow.
*   **Wrestling:** Ajax Telamon and Ulysses wrestle to a draw, and Achilles awards them equal prizes.
*   **Foot Race:** Ulysses wins (with Pallas's aid, as Ajax slips). Antilochus gets third.
*   **Single Combat (with spears):** Diomed and Ajax Telamon contend. Achilles stops the fight before it concludes, awarding Diomed the victory due to his superior strike.
*   **Discus Throw:** Polypoetes wins the heavy iron discus.
*   **Archery:** Merion wins (by hitting the dove) after Teucer (who cut the cord but missed the bird) shoots first.
*   **Javelin Throw:** Agamemnon is awarded the prize without competition, and Merion receives a consolation prize.

**Book XXIV: The Redemption of the Body of Hector.**
After the games, the Greeks sleep, but Achilles, restless with grief, continues to mourn Patroclus. Each morning, he drags Hector's body around Patroclus's tomb. Apollo protects Hector's body from mutilation and decay. The gods, except Juno, Neptune, and Pallas, pity Hector. On the tenth day, Apollo complains to the gods about Achilles' cruelty. Juno defends Achilles. Jove, however, decrees that Achilles must return Hector's body for ransom, and sends Thetis to command Achilles to comply.

Thetis finds Achilles mourning and delivers Jove's command. Achilles agrees to obey. Jove then sends Iris to Priam, instructing him to go alone to Achilles' tent with gifts to ransom Hector's body, promising divine protection. Hecuba tries to dissuade Priam, fearing Achilles, but Priam insists, trusting Jove's command. He prepares lavish gifts. Both Priam and Hecuba pray to Jove for a favorable omen. Jove sends an eagle.

Priam, accompanied by his herald Idæus, sets out in a mule-drawn wagon. Jove sends Hermes, disguised as a young Myrmidon, to guide and protect them. Hermes puts the Greek guards to sleep, opens Achilles' tent, reveals his divine identity, and advises Priam how to appeal to Achilles. Hermes then departs.

Priam enters Achilles' tent, prostrates himself, embraces Achilles' knees, and kisses his hands, appealing to Achilles' memory of his own father, Peleus. Achilles is deeply moved by Priam's grief and remembers his father and Patroclus. Both men weep together. Achilles then raises Priam and counsels him to control his sorrow, explaining the human condition of receiving both good and evil from Jove's urns.

Achilles orders Hector's body to be washed and anointed away from Priam's sight. He himself lifts Hector's body onto the wagon and calls out to Patroclus's shade, asking for forgiveness for returning Hector. Achilles and Priam share a meal. Priam asks for a truce for Hector's funeral. Achilles grants a twelve-day truce.

Priam and Idæus sleep in the porch. Hermes awakens Priam, urging him to leave before the Greek chiefs discover him. They depart with Hector's body. Cassandra, from Troy's walls, spots the wagon, alerting the city. The Trojans rush out to meet the body, lamenting. Priam calms them and directs the body to the palace.

Hector's body is laid on a bed of state. Andromache, Hecuba, and Helen each deliver heartfelt lamentations over Hector's body, expressing their profound sorrow and fears for the future. Priam orders the Trojans to gather wood for the pyre. For nine days, they gather wood. On the tenth day, Hector's body is placed on the pyre and burned. At dawn on the eleventh day, the ashes are quenched, Hector's bones are collected in a golden urn, wrapped in purple, and buried in a tomb. Guards watch during the rites. The Trojans then share a final funeral feast. The text concludes by stating the honors paid to Hector and the peaceful rest of his shade.
